predicted_text:
Abetalipoproteinemia (often shortened to “ABL” or “Bassen-Kornzweig disease”) is a very rare, inherited disorder of fat absorption and transport.  Because it is uncommon, patients and clinicians sometimes struggle to find trustworthy information, experienced specialists, and day-to-day support.  Below is a summary of how the condition is usually confirmed, how it is treated, and where individuals and families can find expert care and peer support.

----------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Getting a firm diagnosis
----------------------------------------------------------------
A. Typical laboratory clues  
• Very low or undetectable plasma levels of apolipoprotein-B, LDL-C, and triglycerides.  
• Fat-soluble vitamin deficiency (vitamins A, D, E, K).  
• Acanthocytosis (spiky red blood cells) on a blood film.  
• Fat in stool (steatorrhoea) and failure to thrive/growth delay in childhood.

B. Confirmatory test  
• Molecular genetic testing of the MTTP gene (microsomal triglyceride-transfer-protein).  
• A single pathogenic variant on each copy of MTTP (biallelic) confirms the diagnosis.

How to arrange this  
1. Ask your GP or primary-care doctor for referral to one of the following services (names vary by country):
   • Inherited/metabolic disease clinic.  
   • Tertiary lipid disorders clinic.  
   • Clinical genetics service.
2. These centres can order MTTP sequencing (often funded through national health services or insurance when clinically indicated).
3. A registered genetic counsellor can explain the test, inheritance pattern (autosomal recessive), and implications for family members.

----------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Principles of management
----------------------------------------------------------------
There is no cure, but early, life-long treatment aimed at preventing fat-soluble-vitamin deficiency and reducing long-term complications (neuropathy, retinal degeneration, scoliosis) is effective.

1. High-dose fat-soluble vitamins  
   • Vitamin E: 100–300 IU/kg/day in children or 2,000–4,000 IU/day in adults (adjust to achieve normal plasma α-tocopherol).  
   • Vitamin A: age- and weight-adjusted (monitor retinol levels and liver function).  
   • Vitamins D and K: dose to maintain normal serum 25-OH-D and prothrombin time.

2. Dietary fat modification  
   • Limit long-chain triglycerides (animal fats, most vegetable oils).  
   • Liberal use of medium-chain triglyceride (MCT) oil, which is absorbed without chylomicrons.  
   • Ensure adequate calories and essential fatty acids (linoleic, α-linolenic acids).  
   • Regular input from a metabolic dietitian.

3. Surveillance  
   • Annual ophthalmology (retinitis pigmentosa and night blindness).  
   • Neurological exam ± nerve-conduction studies.  
   • Growth charts (children), bone density (vitamin D).  
   • Liver ultrasound and clotting profile (fatty liver, vitamin K).

4. Multidisciplinary team  
   • Metabolic physician/lipidologist  
   • Dietitian  
   • Ophthalmologist  
   • Neurologist/physiatrist  
   • Genetic counsellor

----------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Finding clinical expertise
----------------------------------------------------------------
United Kingdom  
• National specialist metabolic centres (e.g., Great Ormond Street Hospital, Evelina London, Birmingham Children’s, Salford Royal, Addenbrooke’s, UCLH).  
• Adult Inherited Metabolic Disorders (AIMD) clinics in most major teaching hospitals.  
• Refer through NHS e-Referral or the Highly Specialised Services route.

United States / Canada  
• “Genetic & Metabolic Clinics” at most children’s hospitals and academic medical centres.  
• Lipid clinics affiliated with NIH Rare Lipid Consortium, Columbia University, UT Southwestern, etc.

Europe  
• MetabERN (European Reference Network for Hereditary Metabolic Disorders) has a directory of accredited centres.  
• Contact national patient organisations (see below).

Australia / New Zealand  
• Metabolic clinics in Sydney (Westmead), Melbourne (Royal Children’s), Brisbane (QCH), Auckland (Starship).

If you are unsure where to go, ask your local genetic service or search the Orphanet directory (www.orpha.net) for “abetalipoproteinemia” to find national experts.

----------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Patient & family support organisations
----------------------------------------------------------------
Dedicated ABL/MTTP communities  
• RareConnect – Abetalipoproteinemia Community  
  www.rareconnect.org/en/community/abetalipoproteinemia  
• Several private Facebook groups (search “Abetalipoproteinemia Support”).

Broad rare-disease organisations (often have helplines, grants, and peer mentors)  
• Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center (GARD

<gold_response>
Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome: Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome is a rare disease passed down through families. The person is unable to fully absorb dietary fats through the intestines. Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome is caused by a defect in a gene that tells the body to create lipoproteins (molecules of fat combined with protein). The defect makes it hard for the body to properly digest fat and essential vitamins. It is an autosomal recessive condition that more often affects males. Symptoms include: - Balance and coordination difficulties - Curvature of spine - Decreased vision that gets worse over time - Developmental delay - Failure to thrive (grow) in infancy - Muscle weakness - Poor muscle coordination that usually develops after age 10 - Protruding abdomen - Slurred speech - Stool abnormalities, including fatty stools that appear pale in color, frothy stools, and abnormally foul-smelling stools There may be damage to the retina of the eye (retinitis pigmentosa). Tests that may be done to help diagnose this condition include: - Apolipoprotein B blood test - Blood tests to look for vitamin deficiencies (fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, and K) - "Burr-cell" malformation of the red cells (acanthocytosis) - Complete blood count (CBC) - Cholesterol studies - Electromyography - Eye exam - Nerve conduction velocity - Stool sample analysis Genetic testing may be available for mutations in the MTP gene. Treatment involves large doses of vitamin supplements containing fat-soluble vitamins (vitamin A, vitamin D, vitamin E, and vitamin K). Linoleic acid supplements are also recommended. People with this condition should talk to a nutritionist. Diet changes are needed to prevent stomach problems. This involves: - Limiting fat intake to 5 to 20 grams per day. - Do not eat more than 5 ounces daily (140 grams) of lean meat, fish, or poultry. - Use skim milk instead of whole milk. Supplements of medium-chain triglycerides are taken under the supervision of a health care provider. They should be used with caution, because they may cause liver damage. How well a person does depends on the amount of brain and nervous system problems. Complications may include: - Blindness - Mental deterioration - Loss of function of peripheral nerves, uncoordinated movement (ataxia) Call your provider if your infant or child has symptoms of this disease. Genetic counseling can help families understand the condition and the risks of inheriting it, and learn how to care for the person. High doses of fat-soluble vitamins may slow the progression of some problems, such as retina damage and decreased vision. Updated by: Chad Haldeman-Englert, MD, FACMG, Fullerton Genetics Center, Asheville, NC. Review provided by VeriMed Healthcare Network. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.
</gold_response>

I am sorry to hear how ill your friend is.  Below is practical information on  

• what is happening in thalassaemia major  
• why she may now be coughing blood  
• the treatments that have to be started or optimised immediately  
• centres around the world (and in India, because your e-mail address suggests that may be home) that regularly treat large numbers of thalassaemia patients and can perform the only curative procedure, stem-cell / bone-marrow transplantation.  

Because a person who is coughing up blood can deteriorate quickly, please take her to the nearest large hospital (department of Haematology or Internal Medicine) TODAY rather than waiting until you can reach a distant centre.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  What is happening in thalassaemia major
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• In β-thalassaemia major the body cannot make normal haemoglobin, so red-blood-cells are destroyed almost as fast as they are produced.  
• White cells and platelets are not truly “absent”, but the spleen often enlarges and traps or destroys them, so blood counts can look very low.  
• To stay alive the patient needs regular packed-red-cell transfusions every 2–4 weeks.  
• Each unit of blood contains iron; after months or years the extra iron settles in the heart, liver, hormone-producing glands and lungs → heart failure, diabetes, early puberty failure, osteoporosis and lung/airway problems.  The excess iron must be removed continuously with iron-chelating medicines.  
• A matched-sibling or matched-unrelated stem-cell / bone-marrow transplant (SCT / BMT) done early in life can cure about 80–90 % of children and 65–80 % of well-prepared adults.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Coughing up blood (“haemoptysis”) – this needs URGENT evaluation
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Blood in the sputum is NOT a usual part of thalassaemia.  Common causes that need to be ruled out quickly are  
• Severe chest or throat infection (e.g. tuberculosis, fungal infection, bacterial pneumonia)  
• Heart failure or pulmonary hypertension from iron overload  
• Bleeding tendency because platelet count is low or the spleen is very large  
• Lung scarring (bronchiectasis) from repeated infections  
She needs:  
– Physical examination, full blood count, clotting tests  
– Chest X-ray or CT scan  
– Echocardiogram ± cardiac MRI (to look for iron in the heart)  
– Urgent adjustment of transfusion programme and chelation.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  Essential day-to-day treatment until transplant is possible
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Regular packed-RBC transfusions every 3–4 weeks aiming for a pre-transfusion Hb ≥ 9–10 g/dL  
   – Extend intervals only under specialist guidance.  
2. Iron chelation started after 10–15 transfusions or serum ferritin > 1000 ng/mL  
   • Deferasirox tablets (once daily) OR  
   • Deferiprone tablets (three times daily) ± Deferoxamine night pump infusions.  
   Adjust using ferritin and yearly MRI to see liver/heart iron.  
3. Folic-acid 1 mg daily; do NOT give iron tablets.  
4. Yearly screen for viruses (Hep B, Hep C, HIV), thyroid, diabetes, bone density, hormones.  
5. Vaccinate: Hep B, pneumococcal, Haemophilus, meningococcal, annual ‘flu.  
6. Consider low-dose hydroxyurea or luspatercept in non-transplant candidates (specialist decision).  

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Curative options
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A. Stem-cell / bone-marrow transplant (SCT/BMT)  
   • Best results if donor is an HLA-matched brother/sister.  
   • Matched-unrelated or haplo-identical (half-matched parent) transplants are now performed with success in experienced centres.  
   • Age < 14 yr, liver not yet badly iron-overloaded and no serious infections → survival > 90 %.  

B. Gene therapy  
   • β-thalassaemia gene addition (betibeglogene, “Zynteglo”) and gene-editing trials are available in a few research centres in Europe and the USA.  Cost is currently very high (USD > 1 million) and long-term data are still being gathered.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Hospitals with established thalassaemia programmes
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A. India / South Asia  
• Christian Medical College, Vellore, Tamil Nadu – Thalassaemia & BMT Unit  
• Tata Medical Center, Kolkata (and Institute of Haematology & Transfusion Medicine, Calcutta Medical College)  
• Apollo Hospitals (Chennai, Hyderabad, Delhi) – paediatric B

<gold_response>
Thalassemia (Treatment): Treatment for thalassemia depends on which type you have and how severe it is. Treatments for mild thalassemia Signs and symptoms are usually mild with thalassemia minor and little, if any, treatment is needed. Occasionally, you may need a blood transfusion, particularly after surgery, after having a baby or to help manage thalassemia complications. People with severe beta-thalassemia will need blood transfusions. And because this treatment can cause iron overload, they will also need treatment to remove excess iron. An oral medication called deferasirox (Exjade, Jadenu) can help remove the excess iron. Treatments for moderate to severe thalassemia Treatments for moderate to severe thalassemia may include: - Frequent blood transfusions. More-severe forms of thalassemia often require frequent blood transfusions, possibly every few weeks. Over time, blood transfusions cause a buildup of iron in your blood, which can damage your heart, liver and other organs. To help your body get rid of the extra iron, you may need to take medications that rid your body of extra iron. - Stem cell transplant. Also called a bone marrow transplant, a stem cell transplant may be an option in select cases, including children born with severe thalassemia. It can eliminate the need for lifelong blood transfusions and drugs to control iron overload. During this procedure, you receive infusions of stem cells from a compatible donor, usually a sibling.
</gold_response>

Short answer  
Most children and adults who have ordinary ( “typical” ) absence seizures do ​not​ suffer permanent brain, mental or physical damage from the seizures themselves.  The spells are very brief (a few-seconds of staring or blinking) and there is no violent muscle activity or lack of oxygen, so they usually leave no mark on the brain or body.

Longer answer  

1.  What actually happens during an absence seizure  
   • Electrical activity in the brain pauses normal awareness for 3–20 seconds.  
   • There is no drop in blood oxygen and no strong muscular contraction.  
   • Consciousness returns immediately and the person continues what he or she was doing.

2.  Physical harm  
   • Because there is no collapse or convulsion, injuries are rare.  
   • The biggest risk is doing something that needs continuous attention (swimming alone, climbing, cycling in traffic, etc.) when a spell occurs.

3.  Brain or “mental” harm  
   • A single seizure, or even dozens a day, does not “kill brain cells.”  
   • However, frequent untreated spells can interrupt class work or conversations and may be mistaken for day-dreaming or attention-deficit problems.  Over time this can affect learning or school performance, but that is due to lost instructional time, not brain damage.  
   • Some epilepsy syndromes that include “atypical” absence seizures (e.g., Lennox-Gastaut) are linked to developmental delay; in those cases the underlying brain disorder, not the brief staring spells, is responsible for cognitive problems.

4.  When can absence seizures become dangerous?  
   • Very prolonged absence status epilepticus (minutes to hours of continuous or back-to-back spells) is uncommon but can cause confusion and requires urgent treatment.  
   • Side-effects of medicines (sleepiness, attention problems, weight gain, etc.) can sometimes feel worse than the seizures themselves; dose adjustment or a different drug usually helps.

5.  Outlook  
   • With proper medication (ethosuximide, valproate, lamotrigine, etc.) 60–80 % of children become seizure-free.  
   • Many outgrow absence epilepsy by their teens and live completely normal lives.

Bottom line  
Ordinary absence seizures do not injure the brain or body, but they should still be evaluated and treated to prevent learning interference and to ensure safety during activities.  Always discuss your or your child’s specific situation with a neurologist or epilepsy specialist.

The reference answer will be provided in these tags:
<gold_response>
Absence seizure: An absence seizure is the term for a type of seizure involving staring spells. This type of seizure is a brief (usually less than 15 seconds) disturbance of brain function due to abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Absence seizures occur most often in people under age 20, usually in children ages 6 to 12. In some cases, the seizures are triggered by flashing lights or when the person breathes faster and more deeply than usual (hyperventilates). They may occur with other types of seizures, such as generalized tonic-clonic seizures (grand mal seizures), twitches or jerks (myoclonus), or sudden loss of muscle strength (atonic seizures). Most absence seizures last only a few seconds. They often involve staring episodes. The episodes may: - Occur many times a day - Occur for weeks to months before being noticed - Interfere with school and learning - Be mistaken for lack of attention, daydreaming or other misbehavior Unexplained difficulties in school and learning difficulties may be the first sign of absence seizures. During the seizure, the person may: - Stop walking and start again a few seconds later - Stop talking in mid-sentence and start again a few seconds later The person usually does not fall during the seizure. Right after the seizure, the person is usually: - Wide awake - Thinking clearly - Unaware of the seizure Specific symptoms of typical absence seizures may include: - Changes in muscle activity, such as no movement, hand fumbling, fluttering eyelids, lip smacking, chewing - Changes in alertness (consciousness), such as staring episodes, lack of awareness of surroundings, sudden halt in movement, talking, and other awake activities Some absence seizures begin slower and last longer. These are called atypical absence seizures. Symptoms are similar to regular absence seizures, but muscle activity changes may be more noticeable. The doctor will perform a physical exam. This will include a detailed look at the brain and nervous system. An EEG (electroencephalogram) will be done to check the electrical activity in the brain. People with seizures often have abnormal electrical activity seen on this test. In some cases, the test shows the area in the brain where the seizures start. The brain may appear normal after a seizure or between seizures. Blood tests may also be ordered to check for other health problems that may be causing the seizures. Head CT or MRI scan may be done to find the cause and location of the problem in the brain. Treatment for absence seizures includes medicines, changes in lifestyle for adults and children, such as activity and diet, and sometimes surgery. Your doctor can tell you more about these options. Updated by: Amit M. Shelat, DO, FACP, Attending Neurologist and Assistant Professor of Clinical Neurology, SUNY Stony Brook, School of Medicine, Stony Brook, NY. predicted_text:
Adrenoleukodystrophy (often shortened to ALD) is a rare, inherited, neuro-metabolic disorder.  Below is a plain-language overview and a list of trustworthy places you can turn to for more detail and support.  Use it only as background—final decisions about care should always be made with the child’s physicians and, if possible, a medical geneticist.

----------------------------------------------------
1.  WHAT ALD IS
----------------------------------------------------
•  ALD is caused by a change (mutation) in the ABCD1 gene on the X-chromosome.  
•  The faulty gene keeps certain very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) from being broken down inside tiny cell structures called peroxisomes.  These fatty acids build up, damage the insulating covering (myelin) of nerves in the brain and spinal cord, and can also injure the adrenal glands (the glands that make cortisol).  
•  Because the gene is on the X-chromosome, ALD is described as “X-linked.”  Boys/men (who have only one X) are the ones who usually become ill.  Girls/women who carry the mutation usually stay healthy but can pass it on and sometimes develop a milder adult form.

----------------------------------------------------
2.  MAIN FORMS & TYPICAL AGE AT ONSET
----------------------------------------------------
1.  Childhood cerebral ALD  
    •  Onset: most often 4–8 years old.  
    •  Features: behavior or school performance changes, vision or hearing loss, clumsiness, seizures.  Symptoms can progress rapidly over months to a few years.

2.  Adrenomyeloneuropathy (AMN)  
    •  Onset: late teens to adulthood.  
    •  Features: slowly worsening stiffness/weakness of the legs, bladder or bowel problems, possible adrenal failure.  Usually progresses over decades.

3.  Addison-only form  
    •  Onset: anytime in childhood or adulthood.  
    •  Feature: adrenal insufficiency (Addison’s disease) without obvious nervous-system problems.

----------------------------------------------------
3.  SYMPTOMS TO WATCH FOR
----------------------------------------------------
•  Learning or behavioral changes, loss of attention span  
•  Balance problems, frequent falls, leg stiffness  
•  Decreased vision, hearing, or speech difficulties  
•  Seizures  
•  Extreme fatigue, weight loss, darkening of the skin (possible adrenal failure)

----------------------------------------------------
4.  HOW ALD IS DIAGNOSED
----------------------------------------------------
•  Blood test for very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs)  
•  Brain MRI (characteristic white-matter changes)  
•  Genetic testing for an ABCD1 mutation  
•  Adrenal hormone tests (cortisol, ACTH)

----------------------------------------------------
5.  TREATMENT & MANAGEMENT
----------------------------------------------------
There is no cure yet, but several treatments can slow or prevent damage if started early:

1.  Adrenal hormone replacement  
    •  Daily hydrocortisone or similar medications if adrenal insufficiency is present.

2.  Hematopoietic stem-cell transplant (HSCT) or gene-corrected stem-cell therapy  
    •  Can halt the childhood cerebral form if done very early, before major symptoms appear (requires specialized centers).

3.  Gene therapy (Skysona®/elivaldogene autotemcel in the U.S.)  
    •  Approved for certain boys without an available matched donor; available only at selected centers.

4.  “Lorenzo’s Oil” (a mix of oleic and erucic acids) plus a low-VLCFA diet  
    •  Can lower VLCFA levels.  Evidence shows it may delay, but not stop, brain disease when started before MRI changes appear.

5.  Symptomatic and supportive care  
    •  Physical, occupational, and speech therapy  
    •  Anti-spasticity or seizure medicines if needed  
    •  Educational supports, vision/hearing aids, psychological counseling

----------------------------------------------------
6.  WHAT FAMILIES CAN DO
----------------------------------------------------
•  Genetic counseling: offers risk assessment for parents and relatives, carrier testing for sisters/daughters, and prenatal or newborn testing if desired.  
•  Regular MRI and adrenal testing: even symptom-free boys with the gene need periodic screening so treatment can start at the first sign of brain changes.  
•  Build a multidisciplinary team: pediatric neurologist, endocrinologist, transplant/gene-therapy center if appropriate, rehabilitation specialists, school professionals.  
•  Connect with experienced families: support groups can help you navigate insurance, equipment, school plans, and the emotional burden.

----------------------------------------------------
7.  RELIABLE RESOURCES & SUPPORT
----------------------------------------------------
•  Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center (GARD) – U.S. NIH  
  https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/diseases/6163/adrenoleukodystrophy  

•

<gold_response>
Adrenoleukodystrophy: Adrenoleukodystrophy describes several closely related disorders that disrupt the breakdown of certain fats. These disorders are passed down (inherited) in families. Adrenoleukodystrophy is usually passed down from parent to child as an X-linked genetic trait. It affects mostly males, although some women who are carriers can have milder forms of the disease. It affects about 1 in 20,000 people from all races. The condition results in the buildup of very-long-chain fatty acids in the nervous system, adrenal gland, and testes. This disrupts normal activity in these parts of the body. There are 3 major categories of disease: - Childhood cerebral form -- appears in mid-childhood (at ages 4 to 8) - Adrenomyelopathy -- occurs in men in their 20s or later in life - Impaired adrenal gland function (called Addison disease or Addison-like phenotype) -- adrenal gland does not produce enough steroid hormones Childhood cerebral type symptoms include: - Changes in muscle tone, especially muscle spasms and uncontrolled movements - Crossed eyes - Handwriting that gets worse - Difficulty at school - Difficulty understanding what people are saying - Hearing loss - Hyperactivity - Worsening nervous system damage, including coma, decreased fine motor control, and paralysis - Seizures - Swallowing difficulties - Visual impairment or blindness Adrenomyelopathy symptoms include: - Difficulty controlling urination - Possible worsening muscle weakness or leg stiffness - Problems with thinking speed and visual memory Adrenal gland failure (Addison type) symptoms include: - Coma - Decreased appetite - Increased skin color - Loss of weight and muscle mass (wasting) - Muscle weakness - Vomiting Tests for this condition include: - Blood levels of very long chain fatty acids and hormones that are produced by the adrenal gland - Chromosome study to look for changes (mutations) in the ABCD1 gene - MRI of the head Adrenal dysfunction may be treated with steroids (such as cortisol) if the adrenal gland is not producing enough hormones. A specific treatment for X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy is not available. A bone marrow transplant can cure a people of the condition. The childhood form of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy is a progressive disease. It leads to a long-term coma (vegetative state) about 2 years after nervous system symptoms develop. The child can live in this condition for as long as 10 years until death occurs. The other forms of this disease are milder. These complications can occur: - Adrenal crisis - Vegetative state Call your health care provider if: - Your child develops symptoms of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy - Your child has X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy and is getting worse Genetic counseling is recommended for couples with a family history of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy. Mothers of affected sons have an 85% chance of being a carrier for this condition. Prenatal diagnosis of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy is also available. It is done by testing cells from chorionic villus sampling or amniocentesis. These tests look for either a known genetic change in the family or for very long chain fatty acid levels. Updated by: Chad Haldeman-Englert, MD, FACMG, Fullerton Genetics Center, Asheville, NC. Review provided by VeriMed Healthcare Network. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
I’m not your personal medical provider, but I can give you general information that many people find helpful when they’re dealing with anal fissures. Use this as background only, and be sure to speak with a clinician (family doctor, nurse-practitioner, or colorectal specialist) for advice that’s specific to you.

1. What an anal fissure is  
• A small tear in the thin lining of the anal canal.  
• Often causes a sharp “cutting” pain during or after a bowel movement, sometimes with bright-red blood on the toilet paper or stool.  
• The internal anal sphincter can go into spasm, leading to lingering pain or a feeling of tightness.

2. Why it happens  
• Passing large, hard, or dry stools (constipation).  
• Frequent loose stools or diarrhea (the irritation can also cause a tear).  
• Straining for long periods, chronic coughing, heavy lifting, childbirth, anal intercourse, or inflammatory bowel diseases such as Crohn’s.

3. How long it lasts  
• Acute fissure: <6 weeks—most heal with conservative care.  
• Chronic fissure: ≥6 weeks—may need prescription medication or, rarely, surgery.

4. Self-care measures that usually help healing  
Diet and bowel habits  
• Fiber: Aim for 25–35 g a day from whole grains, fruits, vegetables, beans, or a fiber supplement (psyllium, methylcellulose).  
• Fluids: 6–8 glasses of water or other non-caffeinated, non-alcoholic drinks daily (unless your provider limits your fluid intake).  
• Stool softeners (docusate) or an osmotic laxative (polyethylene glycol) if stools remain hard.  
Moving your bowels  
• Go as soon as you feel the urge; don’t hold it in.  
• Avoid prolonged straining or sitting on the toilet—prop your feet on a small stool to straighten the anorectal angle.  
Comfort measures  
• Warm Sitz baths: sit in a few inches of lukewarm water for 10–20 min, 2–3 times a day and after each bowel movement.  
• Apply a plain barrier ointment (petroleum jelly, zinc-oxide cream) inside the anal opening before you poop to reduce friction and again afterward to protect the skin.  
• OTC topical lidocaine 5 % cream/gel can numb the area temporarily.  
• Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen (if you can take them safely) help pain and spasm.  
Lifestyle  
• Moderate daily exercise can keep bowels moving.  
• Manage chronic cough or allergies (coughing strains the area).  
• Pause anal sexual activity until completely healed.

5. When to call or see a clinician promptly  
• Bleeding that’s more than just a few drops on the tissue or that continues between bowel movements.  
• Pain persisting >1–2 weeks despite home care, or fissure present >6 weeks.  
• Fever, chills, drainage, or swelling (could signal an abscess).  
• Blood mixed into the stool, black/tarry stool, or other signs that bleeding might be coming from higher in the gut.  
• Severe constipation, inability to pass gas/stool, or worsening spasm.  
• Any concern about Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, or other conditions.

6. Medical treatments if conservative care isn’t enough  
A colorectal surgeon or gastroenterologist may prescribe:  
• Topical nitroglycerin 0.2 % ointment (relaxes the sphincter, increases blood flow).  
• Topical calcium-channel blockers (nifedipine or diltiazem), similar rationale but fewer headaches than nitroglycerin.  
• Botox injections into the internal sphincter to relax the muscle.  
• Lateral internal sphincterotomy (minor outpatient surgery) for chronic fissures that don’t heal otherwise—high success rate, low complication rate.

7. Emotional and practical support

I’m not your personal medical provider, but I can give you general information that many people find helpful when they’re dealing with anal fissures. Use this as background only, and be sure to speak with a clinician (family doctor, nurse-practitioner, or colorectal specialist) for advice that’s specific to you.

1. What an anal fissure is  
• A small tear in the thin lining of the anal canal.  
• Often causes a sharp “cutting” pain during or after a bowel movement, sometimes with bright-red blood on the toilet paper or stool.  
• The internal anal sphincter can go into spasm, leading to lingering pain or a feeling of tightness.

2. Why it happens  
• Passing large, hard, or dry stools (constipation).  
• Frequent loose stools or diarrhea (the irritation can also cause a tear).  
• Straining for long periods, chronic coughing, heavy lifting, childbirth, anal intercourse, or inflammatory bowel diseases such as Crohn’s.

3. How long it lasts  
• Acute fissure: <6 weeks—most heal with conservative care.  
• Chronic fissure: ≥6 weeks—may need prescription medication or, rarely, surgery.

4. Self-care measures that usually help healing  
Diet and bowel habits  
• Fiber: Aim for 25–35 g a day from whole grains, fruits, vegetables, beans, or a fiber supplement (psyllium, methylcellulose).  
• Fluids: 6–8 glasses of water or other non-caffeinated, non-alcoholic drinks daily (unless your provider limits your fluid intake).  
• Stool softeners (docusate) or an osmotic laxative (polyethylene glycol) if stools remain hard.  
Moving your bowels  
• Go as soon as you feel the urge; don’t hold it in.  
• Avoid prolonged straining or sitting on the toilet—prop your feet on a small stool to straighten the anorectal angle.  
Comfort measures  
• Warm Sitz baths: sit in a few inches of lukewarm water for 10–20 min, 2–3 times a day and after each bowel movement.  
• Apply a plain barrier ointment (petroleum jelly, zinc-oxide cream) inside the anal opening before you poop to reduce friction and again afterward to protect the skin.  
• OTC topical lidocaine 5 % cream/gel can numb the area temporarily.  
• Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen (if you can take them safely) help pain and spasm.  
Lifestyle  
• Moderate daily exercise can keep bowels moving.  
• Manage chronic cough or allergies (coughing strains the area).  
• Pause anal sexual activity until completely healed.

5. When to call or see a clinician promptly  
• Bleeding that’s more than just a few drops on the tissue or that continues between bowel movements.  
• Pain persisting >1–2 weeks despite home care, or fissure present >6 weeks.  
• Fever, chills, drainage, or swelling (could signal an abscess).  
• Blood mixed into the stool, black/tarry stool, or other signs that bleeding might be coming from higher in the gut.  
• Severe constipation, inability to pass gas/stool, or worsening spasm.  
• Any concern about Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, or other conditions.

6. Medical treatments if conservative care isn’t enough  
A colorectal surgeon or gastroenterologist may prescribe:  
• Topical nitroglycerin 0.2 % ointment (relaxes the sphincter, increases blood flow).  
• Topical calcium-channel blockers (nifedipine or diltiazem), similar rationale but fewer headaches than nitroglycerin.  
• Botox injections into the internal sphincter to relax the muscle.  
• Lateral internal sphincterotomy (minor outpatient surgery) for chronic fissures that don’t heal otherwise—high success rate, low complication rate.

7. Emotional and practical support  
• Many people feel embarrassed but fissures are common and treatable.  
• Your primary-care office nurse line can answer questions between visits.  
• Online communities (search “anal fissure support forum” or relevant subreddits) let you talk with others experiencing the same thing.  
• A dietitian can help you set up a high-fiber meal plan if you struggle with constipation or irritable bowel habits.

Most fissures heal with fiber, hydration, Sitz baths, gentle hygiene, and avoiding strain. If pain or bleeding continues past a couple of weeks—or if it’s severe from the start—see a clinician for prescription treatments. Don’t ignore ongoing bleeding: although fissures are the usual cause of bright-red streaks, other conditions need to be ruled out.

Anal fissure (Treatment): Anal fissures often heal within a few weeks if you take steps to keep your stool soft, such as increasing your intake of fiber and fluids. Soaking in warm water for 10 to 20 minutes several times a day, especially after bowel movements, can help relax the sphincter and promote healing. If your symptoms persist, you'll likely need further treatment. Nonsurgical treatments Your doctor may recommend: - Externally applied nitroglycerin (Rectiv), to help increase blood flow to the fissure and promote healing and to help relax the anal sphincter. Nitroglycerin is generally considered the medical treatment of choice when other conservative measures fail. Side effects may include headache, which can be severe. - Topical anesthetic creams such as lidocaine hydrochloride (Xylocaine) may be helpful for pain relief. - Botulinum toxin type A (Botox) injection, to paralyze the anal sphincter muscle and relax spasms. - Blood pressure medications, such as oral nifedipine (Procardia) or diltiazem (Cardizem) can help relax the anal sphincter. These medications may be taken by mouth or applied externally and may be used when nitroglycerin is not effective or causes significant side effects. Surgery If you have a chronic anal fissure that is resistant to other treatments, or if your symptoms are severe, your doctor may recommend surgery. Doctors usually perform a procedure called lateral internal sphincterotomy (LIS), which involves cutting a small portion of the anal sphincter muscle to reduce spasm and pain, and promote healing. Studies have found that for chronic fissure, surgery is much more effective than any medical treatment. However, surgery has a small risk of causing incontinence.

predicted_text:
Can people with Angelman syndrome (AS) have children?
• Puberty and fertility are generally normal in both males and females with Angelman syndrome.  
• Most adults with AS have severe intellectual disability and limited verbal communication, so only a few documented pregnancies have occurred, but biologically pregnancy is possible.

If they do have a child, will the child have Angelman syndrome?
That depends on the underlying genetic cause of the parent’s Angelman syndrome:

1. Maternal 15q11-q13 deletion (about 70 % of AS)  
   • The mother has one chromosome 15 that is missing the critical region.  
   • Each pregnancy has roughly a 50 % chance of receiving that deleted chromosome and, if it does, the child will have Angelman syndrome.

2. Pathogenic variant in the UBE3A gene (≈10 %)  
   • The altered gene can be passed to offspring in the usual Mendelian way.  
   • Each pregnancy carries a 50 % risk of Angelman syndrome.

3. Imprinting-center defect (≈2–3 %)  
   • If the imprinting defect is built into the DNA sequence, the recurrence risk can be up to 50 %.  
   • If it was an isolated epigenetic error, the risk is low (<1 %).

4. Paternal uniparental disomy (UPD) or a non-heritable imprinting error (≈5 % each)  
   • The error is ordinarily “reset” in egg or sperm formation, so the chance of passing on Angelman syndrome is very small, close to the population risk.

Bottom line
• Biological fertility is usually intact, so a person with Angelman syndrome can conceive a child.  
• The chance their child will also have Angelman syndrome ranges from virtually none to 50 %, depending on the specific genetic mechanism.  
• Anyone with Angelman syndrome (or the parent of a person with AS) who is considering pregnancy should meet with a clinical geneticist or genetic counselor for individualized risk assessment and support.

Is Angelman syndrome inherited?: Most cases of Angelman syndrome are not inherited, particularly those caused by a deletion in the maternal chromosome 15 or by paternal uniparental disomy. These genetic changes occur as random events during the formation of reproductive cells (eggs and sperm) or in early embryonic development. Affected people typically have no history of the disorder in their family. Rarely, a genetic change responsible for Angelman syndrome can be inherited. For example, it is possible for a mutation in the UBE3A gene or in the nearby region of DNA that controls gene activation to be passed from one generation to the next.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
I am not a substitute for your father’s doctors, but I can give you general, up-to-date information.

1. What Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL) is  
• HCL is an uncommon, slow-growing cancer of a type of white blood cell (a B-lymphocyte).  
• It is called “hairy” because the cells look ragged or “hair-like” under the microscope.  
• Most people are diagnosed between 40 – 60 years of age, and it is about 4 times more common in men than women.

2. How serious is it?  
• Before modern medicine it was life-threatening, mainly because patients became very prone to infections and severe anemia.  
• Today, thanks to effective treatments discovered in the late 1980s and 1990s, HCL is considered one of the most treatable leukemias.  
• It is still a cancer, so it requires expert care and lifelong follow-up, but it is generally not as aggressive as many other leukemias.

3. Typical treatment and success rates  
First-line (initial) therapy  
• Cladribine (2-CDA) – given by IV infusion over 5–7 days or by injection for 5 days.  
• Pentostatin – IV every other week for several months.  

These medicines (called purine-analogues) put 80–90 % of patients into a complete remission that can last 10 years or longer after only one treatment course.

Other/second-line options  
• Rituximab (an antibody) – sometimes added if the first drug doesn’t bring full remission.  
• Interferon-α – older, used when purine-analogues are not possible (for example during pregnancy).  
• BRAF inhibitors (vemurafenib, dabrafenib) – useful if the leukemia comes back and carries the BRAF-V600E mutation (seen in most cases).  
• Moxetumomab pasudotox – an FDA-approved targeted drug for people who have relapsed after other treatments.  
• Splenectomy (removing the spleen) – rarely needed today but can help in selected cases.

Supportive/monitoring care  
• Prompt treatment of infections, routine vaccinations (flu, COVID-19, pneumococcal, shingles), possible growth-factor shots for very low neutrophil counts.  
• Regular blood counts and periodic bone-marrow or molecular tests to detect early relapse.

4. Outlook / life expectancy  
With modern therapy:  
• Overall 10-year survival is > 90 %.  
• Many patients live 20–30 years or more and die of causes unrelated to HCL.  
• Relapses can occur (about 30–40 % over 10–15 years), but most patients respond again to the same or a different drug.  
Important: Outlook is best when:  
– The initial white-cell and platelet counts are not extremely low.  
– The patient is treated by or in consultation with a hematologist who is familiar with HCL.

5. What you and your father can do now  
• See a hematologist/oncologist experienced in HCL (if possible at a center that treats blood cancers).  
• Bring a list of current medicines, allergies, and all recent lab or imaging reports.  
• Ask about:   – Exact results of his bone-marrow biopsy and flow-cytometry (to confirm the diagnosis).   – Which drug the doctor recommends first and why.   – Expected short-term side effects (fever, low blood counts, fatigue).   – Vaccinations before starting therapy (especially if he will be immunosuppressed).  
• Maintain a healthy lifestyle: balanced diet, exercise as tolerated, no smoking, limited alcohol, and good infection-prevention habits (hand-washing, avoiding sick contacts when blood counts are low).  
• Arrange regular follow-up visits even once he is in remission—these visits allow doctors to catch a relapse early, when it is easiest to treat.

Key take-away  
Hairy Cell Leukemia is a real cancer, but in 2024 it is highly treatable. Most patients—including 55-year-old men like your father—enter long remissions after just one short course of medicine and can live normal lives for many years. Close cooperation with a hematology team will give him the best chance for a long and healthy future.

<gold_response>
Hairy cell leukemia (Treatment): Treatment isn't always necessary for people with hairy cell leukemia. Because this cancer progresses very slowly and sometimes doesn't progress at all, some people prefer to wait to treat their cancer only if it causes signs and symptoms. The majority of people with hairy cell leukemia eventually need treatment. If your hairy cell leukemia causes signs and symptoms, you may decide to undergo treatment. There is no cure for hairy cell leukemia. But treatments are effective at putting hairy cell leukemia in remission for years. Chemotherapy Doctors consider chemotherapy drugs the first line of treatment for hairy cell leukemia. The great majority of people will experience complete or partial remission through the use of chemotherapy. Two chemotherapy drugs are used in hairy cell leukemia: - Cladribine. Treatment for hairy cell leukemia typically begins with cladribine. You receive a continuous infusion of the drug into a vein over several days. Most people who receive cladribine experience a complete remission that can last for several years. If your hairy cell leukemia returns, you can be treated with cladribine again. Side effects of cladribine may include infection and fever. - Pentostatin (Nipent). Pentostatin causes remission rates similar to cladribine, but it's given on a different schedule. People who take pentostatin receive infusions every other week for three to six months. Side effects of pentostatin may include fever, nausea and infection. Biological treatments Biological therapy attempts to make cancer cells more recognizable to your immune system. Once your immune system identifies cancer cells as intruders, it can set about destroying your cancer. Two types of biological treatments are used in hairy cell leukemia: - Interferon. Currently, the role of interferon in hairy cell leukemia treatment is limited. You might receive interferon if chemotherapy hasn't been effective or if you can't take chemotherapy. Most people experience partial remission with interferon, which is taken for a year. Side effects include flu-like symptoms, such as fever and fatigue. - Rituximab (Rituxan). Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody approved to treat non-Hodgkin lymphoma and chronic lymphocytic leukemia, though it's sometimes used in hairy cell leukemia. If chemotherapy drugs haven't worked for you or you can't take chemotherapy, your doctor might consider rituximab. Side effects of rituximab include fever and infection. Surgery Surgery to remove your spleen (splenectomy) might be an option if your spleen ruptures or if it's enlarged and causing pain. Though removing your spleen can't cure hairy cell leukemia, it can usually restore normal blood counts. Splenectomy isn't commonly used to treat hairy cell leukemia, but it may be helpful in certain situations. Any surgery carries a risk of bleeding and infection.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Short answer  
• Current expert consensus is that asthma is a chronic (long-lasting) respiratory disease that cannot be “cured” in the usual sense of the word.  
• With the right treatment plan, however, most people can keep asthma under very good control and live symptom-free for long periods.  
• A minority of children appear to “out-grow” their asthma, but long-term studies show that the underlying airway tendency (hyper-responsiveness) often remains, so flare-ups can return in adulthood.

Why doctors say asthma is not curable  
1. Chronic airway changes  
 • In asthma the bronchial tubes become inflamed and overly sensitive.  
 • Over time the airway wall can remodel (thicken, scar), a process that current medicines cannot completely reverse.

2. Persistent tendency to react to triggers  
 • Even when someone feels well, the airways of a person with asthma are generally more reactive than those of a person who has never had asthma.  

3. Lifelong data  
 • Long-term cohort studies (Melbourne Asthma Study, Tucson Children’s Respiratory Study, etc.) show that many children who seem to lose symptoms still test abnormally on lung-function or develop wheeze again later in life.  
 • Adults rarely lose the diagnosis once it is firmly established.

What “control” looks like  
With modern inhaled corticosteroids, bronchodilators, and – when needed – biologic injections or allergy shots, most patients can:  
• Have little or no daytime or nighttime symptoms  
• Need rescue inhaler ≤2 days a week  
• Maintain normal physical activity  
• Have no emergency visits or hospitalisations

So while asthma is not curable, it is highly treatable.

Suggested consumer article  
“Is Asthma Curable?” – American Lung Association (Updated 2023)  
https://www.lung.org/lung-health-diseases/lung-disease-lookup/asthma/learn-about-asthma/is-asthma-curable  
The article explains the difference between control and cure, why some children appear to out-grow symptoms, and how to achieve long-term control with medication and trigger avoidance.

Additional reliable sources  
• National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI). Asthma Care Quick Reference, 2020.  
• Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Asthma Data and Statistics.  
• Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA). Global Strategy for Asthma Management and Prevention, 2024.

If you need help finding an asthma specialist or creating an individualized action plan, ask your primary-care clinician for a referral to a board-certified allergist or pulmonologist.

predicted_text:
I’m not a medical professional, but here are some practical steps and general information that can help you understand—and hopefully improve—persistent bad breath (halitosis). If these measures don’t make a clear difference within a few weeks, or if you notice other symptoms (gum bleeding, tooth pain, sinus or stomach issues, fever, unexplained weight loss, etc.), you should book an appointment with a dentist or physician for a full evaluation.

1. Start with thorough daily oral-hygiene basics
   • Brush twice a day with fluoride toothpaste, spending at least two minutes each time.  
   • Floss (or use interdental brushes/water flossers) once daily to remove food particles and plaque between teeth.  
   • Clean the tongue: a tongue scraper or the back of your toothbrush can remove odor-causing bacteria that build up on the tongue’s surface.  
   • Rinse with an alcohol-free antibacterial or zinc-containing mouthwash. (Alcohol can dry your mouth and worsen odor.)

2. See your dentist for a full exam and professional cleaning
   • Gum (periodontal) disease, cavities, or poorly fitting dental work can trap bacteria.  
   • A dental hygienist can remove tartar you can’t reach with home cleaning.  
   • Ask whether you have “coated tongue,” dry mouth, or signs of infection that need treatment.

3. Address dry mouth (xerostomia)
   Mouth dryness lets odor-producing bacteria multiply.  
   • Sip water frequently; aim for 6–8 glasses/day.  
   • Chew sugar-free gum or suck on sugar-free mints to stimulate saliva.  
   • Limit caffeine, alcohol, and tobacco—all can dry the mouth.  
   • Some medications cause dry mouth; talk with your prescribing doctor if you think this is a factor.  

4. Review diet and habits
   • Foods like onions, garlic, certain spices, coffee, and alcohol can linger in your breath until they’re metabolized.  
   • High-protein, low-carb diets sometimes cause a “ketone” smell.  
   • Smoking and vaping directly cause bad breath and gum disease. Quitting helps almost immediately.  

5. Consider sinus, throat, or respiratory issues
   Chronic sinusitis, post-nasal drip, tonsil stones, and certain chest infections can all create odor. Signs include nasal congestion, thick mucus, or a chronic sore throat. An ENT (ear, nose, and throat) doctor can evaluate these.

6. Digestive, metabolic, or systemic conditions
   • Acid reflux (GERD) can bring stomach acids—and odor—into the throat and mouth.  
   • Uncontrolled diabetes can give breath a sweet or fruity odor.  
   • Kidney or liver disorders sometimes cause a fishy or ammonia-like smell.  
   If symptoms point in these directions (heartburn, stomach pain, frequent urination, fatigue, swelling, yellowing skin/eyes), see your primary-care provider.

7. Keep dentures or appliances spotless
   If you wear dentures, retainers, or aligners, clean them exactly as instructed and store them in antibacterial solutions when not in use.

8. Track patterns
   • Note when your breath seems worst—after certain foods, first thing in the morning, when you’re stressed, etc.  
   • A brief log can help your dentist or physician pinpoint triggers.

9. Be realistic about mouthwashes and mints
   These mask odor temporarily. If you need them constantly, it’s a sign you should find and treat the underlying cause.

When to seek professional help quickly
   • Persistent bad breath despite good home care for 2–3 weeks.  
   • Loose teeth, gum recession, or painful, swollen gums.  
   • Mouth sores that don’t heal in 1–2 weeks.  
   • Chronic dry mouth or thick stringy saliva.  
   • Other unexplained symptoms (fever, weight loss, severe heartburn, persistent cough).

Bottom line
Bad breath usually improves with diligent oral hygiene and dental care. If it doesn’t, consult a dentist first—most halitosis originates in the mouth. If dental causes are ruled out, your dentist may refer you to a medical doctor or specialist (ENT, gastroenterologist, endocrinologist) to look for non-oral sources.

Some diseases and medicines are associated with a specific breath odor. Having good dental habits, like brushing and flossing regularly, help fight bad breath. Here is an outline of what the research (through early-2024) tells us about the three treatments you mentioned and how they may—or may not—fit into a treatment plan for people who have BOTH bipolar disorder and generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
What it is  
• A non-invasive procedure in which a magnetic coil, placed over the scalp, delivers rapidly pulsed magnetic fields that induce small electrical currents in the superficial cortex.  
• Sessions last 20-40 minutes, 5 days/week for 4–6 weeks, followed by optional maintenance sessions.

Regulatory status  
• In the United States the FDA has cleared repetitive TMS (rTMS) for:  
  – Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) that has not responded to at least one antidepressant.  
  – Obsessive–Compulsive Disorder (OCD) with the “deep” TMS coil.  
• It is NOT FDA-cleared specifically for bipolar disorder or for GAD. Use for those conditions is considered “off-label.”

Evidence in bipolar disorder  
• Bipolar depression: Small randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and several open-label studies suggest response rates of 30–60 %, but the evidence base is still thin; most studies had <50 participants.  
• Bipolar mania: A few small studies have been negative or mixed.  
• Safety issue: There is a non-trivial risk (��5–10 %) of flipping a patient with bipolar disorder from depression into hypomania/mania, especially if mood stabilizers are not optimized.

Evidence in anxiety disorders  
• Primary GAD: Very small studies (n=10–30) using low-frequency right-sided or high-frequency left-sided stimulation have shown modest reductions in worry and somatic anxiety, but no large or definitive trials exist.  
• Anxiety symptoms that accompany depression often improve as the depression lifts, but direct anti-anxiety effects remain uncertain.

Bottom line on TMS  
• Reasonable to consider as an add-on if you are predominantly in a depressive phase that has not responded to medication/therapy, and if you and your psychiatrist can monitor closely for manic switch.  
• Insurance coverage is usually limited to FDA-approved uses, so off-label use for bipolar or GAD may require self-payment or an appeal.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
What it is  
• A brief, controlled electrical stimulus delivered under general anesthesia and muscle relaxation that provokes a generalized seizure lasting 20–60 seconds.  
• Typically done 2–3 times a week for 6–12 treatments; maintenance (“continuation”) ECT or medication prevents relapse.

Effectiveness  
• One of the most effective treatments in all of psychiatry. Response rates:  
  – Unipolar or bipolar major depression: 70–90 %  
  – Acute mania that is severe or medication-resistant: 70 %+  
  – Catatonia: >80 %  
• Works more quickly than medications or TMS—often within 1-2 weeks.

• Short-term confusion on the day of treatment.  
• Anterograde and retrograde memory problems; for most people this resolves over weeks to months, but a minority report longer-lasting gaps in autobiographical memory.  
• Requires anesthesia, so medical clearance is needed.  
• Modern ECT techniques (ultra-brief pulse, unilateral placement) greatly reduce cognitive side-effects compared with older methods.

• Considered when depression or mania is life-threatening (suicidality, psychosis, refusal to eat) or has not responded to adequate trials of medications and psychotherapy.  
• ECT is not generally used to treat primary anxiety; however, improvement in mood often results in parallel reduction in anxiety symptoms.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Acupuncture
--------------------------------------------------------------------

• Traditional Chinese Medicine technique in which very thin needles are inserted into specific points on the body; may be combined with electrical stimulation (electro-acupuncture) or heat (moxibustion).

Research for mood and anxiety

• Generally safe when performed with sterile technique by a licensed acupuncturist; occasional bruising, bleeding, or, rarely, infection or pneumothorax.

Bipolar and Generalized Anxiety Disorder I read about TMS Therapy. Do you know anything about it? Has it had success? Also wondering about ECT? Finally, I've been told acupuncture can help for mood disorders. Is that true for mixed bipolar and generalized anxiety disorder along with meds? Have you ever heard of this?
</question>

The response will be provided in these tags:
<response>
Here is an outline of what the research (through early-2024) tells us about the three treatments you mentioned and how they may—or may not—fit into a treatment plan for people who have BOTH bipolar disorder and generalized anxiety disorder (GAD).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
What it is  
• A non-invasive procedure in which a magnetic coil, placed over the scalp, delivers rapidly pulsed magnetic fields that induce small electrical currents in the superficial cortex.  
• Sessions last 20-40 minutes, 5 days/week for 4–6 weeks, followed by optional maintenance sessions.

Regulatory status  
• In the United States the FDA has cleared repetitive TMS (rTMS) for:  
  – Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) that has not responded to at least one antidepressant.  
  – Obsessive–Compulsive Disorder (OCD) with the “deep” TMS coil.  
• It is NOT FDA-cleared specifically for bipolar disorder or for GAD. Use for those conditions is considered “off-label.”

Evidence in bipolar disorder  
• Bipolar depression: Small randomized controlled trials (RCTs) and several open-label studies suggest response rates of 30–60 %, but the evidence base is still thin; most studies had <50 participants.  
• Bipolar mania: A few small studies have been negative or mixed.  
• Safety issue: There is a non-trivial risk (��5–10 %) of flipping a patient with bipolar disorder from depression into hypomania/mania, especially if mood stabilizers are not optimized.

Evidence in anxiety disorders  
• Primary GAD: Very small studies (n=10–30) using low-frequency right-sided or high-frequency left-sided stimulation have shown modest reductions in worry and somatic anxiety, but no large or definitive trials exist.  
• Anxiety symptoms that accompany depression often improve as the depression lifts, but direct anti-anxiety effects remain uncertain.

Bottom line on TMS  
• Reasonable to consider as an add-on if you are predominantly in a depressive phase that has not responded to medication/therapy, and if you and your psychiatrist can monitor closely for manic switch.  
• Insurance coverage is usually limited to FDA-approved uses, so off-label use for bipolar or GAD may require self-payment or an appeal.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
What it is  
• A brief, controlled electrical stimulus delivered under general anesthesia and muscle relaxation that provokes a generalized seizure lasting 20–60 seconds.  
• Typically done 2–3 times a week for 6–12 treatments; maintenance (“continuation”) ECT or medication prevents relapse.

Effectiveness  
• One of the most effective treatments in all of psychiatry. Response rates:  
  – Unipolar or bipolar major depression: 70–90 %  
  – Acute mania that is severe or medication-resistant: 70 %+  
  – Catatonia: >80 %  
• Works more quickly than medications or TMS—often within 1-2 weeks.

Safety/side-effects  
• Short-term confusion on the day of treatment.  
• Anterograde and retrograde memory problems; for most people this resolves over weeks to months, but a minority report longer-lasting gaps in autobiographical memory.  
• Requires anesthesia, so medical clearance is needed.  
• Modern ECT techniques (ultra-brief pulse, unilateral placement) greatly reduce cognitive side-effects compared with older methods.

Place in treatment for bipolar + GAD  
• Considered when depression or mania is life-threatening (suicidality, psychosis, refusal to eat) or has not responded to adequate trials of medications and psychotherapy.  
• ECT is not generally used to treat primary anxiety; however, improvement in mood often results in parallel reduction in anxiety symptoms.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3. Acupuncture
--------------------------------------------------------------------
What it is  
• Traditional Chinese Medicine technique in which very thin needles are inserted into specific points on the body; may be combined with electrical stimulation (electro-acupuncture) or heat (moxibustion).

Research for mood and anxiety  
• Major depression: Meta-analyses of RCTs show small-to-moderate benefit vs. wait-list or sham, roughly comparable to low-intensity psychotherapy, but studies are heterogeneous and operator-dependent.  
• Generalized anxiety disorder: A 2018 Cochrane review found low-quality evidence of benefit over control conditions; effect sizes were modest.  
• Bipolar disorder: Very little high-quality data; a handful of small pilot studies show potential mood-stabilizing effect, but reproducibility is unclear.

Safety  
• Generally safe when performed with sterile technique by a licensed acupuncturist; occasional bruising, bleeding, or, rarely, infection or pneumothorax.

Role as an adjunct  
• Can be considered as a complementary therapy for anxiety, sleep issues, or pain, conditions that often

<gold_response>
Generalized anxiety disorder (Treatment): Treatment decisions are based on how significantly generalized anxiety disorder is affecting your ability to function in your daily life. The two main treatments for generalized anxiety disorder are psychotherapy and medications. You may benefit most from a combination of the two. It may take some trial and error to discover which treatments work best for you. Psychotherapy Also known as talk therapy or psychological counseling, psychotherapy involves working with a therapist to reduce your anxiety symptoms. Cognitive behavioral therapy is the most effective form of psychotherapy for generalized anxiety disorder. Generally a short-term treatment, cognitive behavioral therapy focuses on teaching you specific skills to directly manage your worries and help you gradually return to the activities you've avoided because of anxiety. Through this process, your symptoms improve as you build on your initial success. Medications Several types of medications are used to treat generalized anxiety disorder, including those below. Talk with your doctor about benefits, risks and possible side effects. - Antidepressants. Antidepressants, including medications in the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) and serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) classes, are the first line medication treatments. Examples of antidepressants used to treat generalized anxiety disorder include escitalopram (Lexapro), duloxetine (Cymbalta), venlafaxine (Effexor XR) and paroxetine (Paxil, Pexeva). Your doctor also may recommend other antidepressants. - Buspirone. An anti-anxiety medication called buspirone may be used on an ongoing basis. As with most antidepressants, it typically takes up to several weeks to become fully effective. - Benzodiazepines. In limited circumstances, your doctor may prescribe a benzodiazepine for relief of anxiety symptoms. These sedatives are generally used only for relieving acute anxiety on a short-term basis. Because they can be habit-forming, these medications aren't a good choice if you have or had problems with alcohol or drug abuse.
</gold_response>

I’m sorry your family is facing this. The good news is that small, “duct-origin” (ductal) cancers found at an early stage are usually very treatable. After the surgeon removes the lump(s), the next step is to decide how much—if any—additional treatment is worthwhile for an 84-year-old woman. In most centers that decision is made by a multidisciplinary team (surgeon, medical oncologist, radiation oncologist, possibly a geriatrician). Below are the factors they will look at and the options typically discussed.

1. Information still needed from the surgery
   • Pathology report: exact tumor size, grade, margins (how close the cancer is to the edge of the specimen).  
   • Hormone-receptor status (ER and PR).  
   • HER2 status.  
   • Sentinel lymph-node biopsy results (if it is done).  
   • Your mother’s overall health, medications and life-expectancy estimate (not just age).

2. Radiation therapy (RT)
   • Standard care after a lumpectomy is whole-breast radiation for 3–5 weeks, because it cuts the risk of the cancer coming back in that breast by ~60–70 %.  
   • Studies show that women over 70 with:  
        – a tumor ≤2 cm,  
        – clear margins,  
        – ER-positive disease,  
        – and who will take hormone pills  
     can safely skip radiation with only a small increase in local-recurrence risk (about 3–4 % vs. 1 %). For many 80-plus patients this is an attractive option.  
   • If RT is chosen, shorter courses (hypofractionation, 3 weeks) or partial-breast techniques (5–10 treatments or even a single intra-operative dose) reduce inconvenience.

3. Endocrine (hormone-blocking) therapy
   • If the tumor is ER- or PR-positive (most ductal cancers in older women are), pills such as:  
        – Aromatase inhibitors: letrozole (Femara), anastrozole (Arimidex), exemestane (Aromasin)  
        – or Tamoxifen  
     decrease the chance of the cancer returning anywhere in the body.  
   • Benefit: about a 30–40 % drop in recurrence and a smaller but real survival benefit.  
   • Risk/side effects: hot flashes, bone thinning, joint stiffness (AIs) or blood-clot risk (tamoxifen). Bone-density monitoring and fall-prevention are important.  
   • Duration: standard is 5 years, but some frail patients or those bothered by side effects may aim for 2–3 years.

4. Chemotherapy
   • Reserved for higher-risk disease (node-positive, ER-negative, HER2-positive, high-grade, larger tumors).  
   • At 84, many women do not receive chemo because potential benefits are modest and side effects (infection risk, fatigue, neuropathy, heart effects) can be hard to tolerate.  
   • A “geriatric assessment” can predict who might do well. If chemo is needed, lighter regimens or single drugs may be used.

5. HER2-targeted therapy (trastuzumab, etc.)
   • Only considered if the tumor over-expresses HER2.  
   • Given with chemotherapy for a year. Heart function must be good; otherwise it is usually avoided in the very elderly.

6. Other considerations
   • Osteoporosis prevention: calcium, vitamin D, weight-bearing exercise, DEXA scans.  
   • Heart health: manage blood pressure, cholesterol, diabetes.  
   • Vaccinations: flu, COVID, pneumonia, shingles.  
   • Emotional and practical support: social worker, support groups, “Reach to Recovery,” transport services.

7. Questions to ask the oncology team
   • Do the margins look clear—was everything removed?  
   • What are the exact stage, ER/PR, HER2 results?  
   • Will a sentinel-node biopsy be done?  
   • How much will skipping radiation raise my mother’s personal risk of the cancer coming back?  
   • Is an aromatase inhibitor or tamoxifen recommended, and for how long?  
   • Do her other medical problems or medicines affect the choices?  
   • What is the expected benefit (in numbers) vs. side-effects for each treatment you’re suggesting?  
   • Is a shorter radiation course or partial-breast radiation available?  
   • Would a geriatric-oncology consultation help?

Key take-away
For many healthy 80-plus women with a small, ER-positive ductal cancer, the most common plan after a lumpectomy is:
   • OPTIONAL radiation (according to preference and risk tolerance)  
   • 5 years of an aromatase inhibitor or tamoxifen, with bone protection measures  
   • No chemotherapy unless

<gold_response>
Breast cancer (Treatment): Treatment is based on many factors, including: - Type of breast cancer - Stage of the cancer (staging is a tool your providers use to find out how advanced the cancer is) - Whether the cancer is sensitive to certain hormones - Whether the cancer overproduces (overexpresses) the HER2/neu protein Cancer treatments may include: - Hormone therapy. - Chemotherapy, which uses medicines to kill cancer cells. - Radiation therapy, which is used to destroy cancerous tissue. - Surgery to remove cancerous tissue: A lumpectomy removes the breast lump. Mastectomy removes all or part of the breast and possibly nearby structures. Nearby lymph nodes may also be removed during surgery. - Targeted therapy uses medicine to attack the gene changes in cancer cells. Hormone therapy is an example of targeted therapy. It blocks certain hormones that fuel cancer growth. Cancer treatment can be local or systemic: - Local treatments involve only the area of disease. Radiation and surgery are forms of local treatment. They are most effective when the cancer has not spread outside the breast. - Systemic treatments affect the entire body. Chemotherapy and hormonal therapy are types of systemic treatment. Most women receive a combination of treatments. For women with stage I, II, or III breast cancer, the main goal is to treat the cancer and prevent it from returning (recurring). For women with stage IV cancer, the goal is to improve symptoms and help them live longer. In most cases, stage IV breast cancer cannot be cured. - Stage 0 and ductal carcinoma: Lumpectomy plus radiation or mastectomy is the standard treatment. - Stage I and II: Lumpectomy plus radiation or mastectomy with lymph node removal is the standard treatment. Chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, and other targeted therapy may also be used after surgery. - Stage III: Treatment involves surgery, possibly followed by chemotherapy, hormone therapy, and other targeted therapy. - Stage IV: Treatment may involve surgery, radiation, chemotherapy, hormone therapy, other targeted therapy, or a combination of these treatments. After treatment, some women continue to take medicines for a time. All women continue to have blood tests, mammograms, and other tests after treatment to monitor for the return of cancer or development of another breast cancer. Women who have had a mastectomy may have reconstructive breast surgery. This will be done either at the time of mastectomy or later.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
According to the National Library of Medicine (NLM) – specifically the MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia article entitled “Peripheral neuropathy” (https://medlineplus.gov/ency/article/000593.htm) – damage to peripheral nerves can be produced by many different conditions.  MedlinePlus lists the following major causes:

• Diabetes mellitus (the most common single cause in the United States)  
• Alcohol abuse / chronic alcoholism  
• Vitamin deficiencies – especially lack of vitamins B1 (thiamine), B6, B12, niacin, folate, or vitamin E  
• Auto-immune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, vasculitis, Guillain-Barré syndrome, chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP)  
• Infections – e.g., Lyme disease, shingles (herpes zoster), HIV/AIDS, hepatitis C, leprosy, diphtheria, syphilis  
• Hereditary (genetic) disorders – e.g., Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease and other inherited neuropathies  
• Physical injury or prolonged pressure on a nerve (trauma, fractures, poorly-fitting casts or splints, using crutches, repetitive stress, carpal tunnel syndrome, “Saturday‐night palsy,” etc.)  
• Tumors – nerve-sheath tumors or cancers that press on or infiltrate nerves  
• Bone-marrow or connective-tissue disorders (amyloidosis, monoclonal gammopathy, sarcoidosis)  
• Metabolic and endocrine disorders – kidney failure (uremia), liver disease, hypothyroidism, acromegaly  
• Vascular or blood problems that decrease oxygen supply to the nerve (vasculitis, blood clots, high blood pressure)  
• Exposure to toxins and heavy metals – lead, mercury, arsenic, thallium, industrial solvents, some insecticides  
• Medications and medical treatments – certain chemotherapy drugs (e.g., vincristine, paclitaxel, cisplatin), some anti-seizure medicines, certain antibiotics (metronidazole, nitrofurantoin), antiretrovirals, statins; radiation therapy  
• Chronic inflammatory conditions and systemic diseases (for example, celiac disease, amyloidosis, sarcoidosis)  
• Idiopathic (in many people no specific cause is found even after evaluation)  

The same MedlinePlus page explains that identifying and treating the underlying cause—when one can be found—offers the best chance of stopping or slowing progression of the neuropathy.

Peripheral Neuropathy (Definition): Peripheral neuropathy describes damage to the peripheral nervous system, which transmits information from the brain and spinal cord to every other part of the body. More than 100 types of peripheral neuropathy have been identified, each with its own characteristic set of symptoms, pattern of development, and prognosis. Impaired function and symptoms depend on the type of nerves -- motor, sensory, or autonomic -- that are damaged.  Some people may experience temporary numbness, tingling, and pricking sensations, sensitivity to touch, or muscle weakness. Others may suffer more extreme symptoms, including burning pain (especially at night), muscle wasting, paralysis, or organ or gland dysfunction. Peripheral neuropathy may be either inherited or acquired. Causes of acquired peripheral neuropathy include physical injury (trauma) to a nerve, tumors, toxins, autoimmune responses, nutritional deficiencies, alcoholism, medical procedures, and vascular and metabolic disorders. Acquired peripheral neuropathies are caused by systemic disease, trauma from external agents, or infections or autoimmune disorders affecting nerve tissue. Inherited forms of peripheral neuropathy are caused by inborn mistakes in the genetic code or by new genetic mutations.
</gold_response>
