<gold_response>
Nose fracture: A nose fracture is a break in the bone or cartilage over the bridge, or in the sidewall or septum (structure that divides the nostrils) of the nose. A fractured nose is the most common fracture of the face. It most often occurs after an injury and often occurs with other fractures of the face. Nose injuries and neck injuries are often seen together. A blow that is forceful enough to injure the nose may be hard enough to injure the neck. Serious nose injuries cause problems that need a health care provider's attention right away. For example, damage to the cartilage can cause a collection of blood to form inside the nose. If this blood is not drained right away, it can cause an abscess or a permanent deformity that blocks the nose. It may lead to tissue death and cause the nose to collapse. For minor nose injuries, the provider may want to see the person within the first week after the injury to see if the nose has moved out of its normal shape. Sometimes, surgery may be needed to correct a nose or septum that has been bent out of shape by an injury. Symptoms may include: - Blood coming from the nose - Bruising around the eyes - Difficulty breathing through the nose - Misshapen appearance (may not be obvious until the swelling goes down) - Pain - Swelling The bruised appearance most often disappears after 2 weeks. If a nose injury happens: - Try to stay calm. - Breathe through your mouth and lean forward in a sitting position to keep blood from going down the back of your throat. - Squeeze the nostrils closed and hold pressure to stop the bleeding. - Apply cold compresses to your nose to reduce swelling. If possible, hold the compress so that there isn't too much pressure on the nose. - To help relieve pain, try acetaminophen (Tylenol). - DO NOT try to straighten a broken nose - DO NOT move the person if there is reason to suspect a head or neck injury Get medical help right away if: - Bleeding will not stop - Clear fluid keeps draining from the nose - You suspect a blood clot in the septum - You suspect a neck or head injury - The nose looks deformed or out of its usual shape - The person is having difficulty breathing Wear protective headgear while playing contact sports, or riding bicycles, skateboards, roller skates, or rollerblades. Use seat belts and appropriate car seats when driving. Updated by: Josef Shargorodsky, MD, MPH, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.
</gold_response>

I’m sorry you’ve been dealing with this for so long. A fissure that has lasted more than 6-8 weeks is considered “chronic,” and once it has persisted for two years it usually needs more than the usual home remedies to heal. Below are the main points most colorectal specialists work through. Use them to guide a focused discussion with your own doctor (ideally a colorectal surgeon or gastroenterologist).

1. Confirm the diagnosis  
   • Most anal fissures are straightforward, but occasionally persistent pain or bleeding is from something else (e.g., Crohn’s disease, infection, hemorrhoids, cancer). A brief in-office exam or flexible sigmoidoscopy can rule these out.

2. Address bowel habits (foundation of treatment)  
   • Stool consistency: Aim for soft, formed stools—neither hard nor loose.  
   • Fiber: 20-35 g/day from diet or supplements (psyllium, methylcellulose, wheat dextrin). Increase gradually to avoid bloating.  
   • Water: ~1.5–2 L (6-8 glasses) daily unless your doctor limits fluids.  
   • Stool softeners or osmotic laxatives: Docusate, polyethylene glycol (PEG 3350/Miralax), or magnesium hydroxide can keep stools soft.  
   • Timed toilet habits: Go as soon as you feel the urge; don’t strain or linger (>5 min). Keep feet on a small stool to relax the pelvic floor.

3. Topical medications that relax the sphincter  
   (Prescription, applied 2–3 × daily for 6–8 weeks)  
   • 0.2–0.3 % Nitroglycerin ointment (Rectiv)  
   • 2 % Diltiazem or 0.3 %–0.4 % Nifedipine compounded in petrolatum or lidocaine base  
   These reduce anal sphincter pressure and improve blood flow so the fissure can heal. Headache is the main side effect; dab on a pea-size amount. If you were already given one of these but for only a short course, it’s worth retrying for a full 6-8 weeks.

4. Warm sitz baths  
   • 10–15 minutes in plain warm water 2–3 × daily and after bowel movements. This relaxes muscle spasm, improves circulation, and eases pain.

5. Pain control  
   • Topical 5 % lidocaine before and/or after bowel movements.  
   • Oral NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) if you can take them safely.

6. Re-evaluate after 6–8 weeks  
   If the fissure is unchanged despite good adherence to steps 2-5, most guidelines move to office-based procedures:

7. Botox injection  
   • In-office or day-surgery injection of botulinum toxin into the internal anal sphincter. Healing rates run 60-80 %. Effects last ~3 months; some people need a second round.

8. Lateral internal sphincterotomy (LIS)  
   • Out-patient surgery where a small portion of the internal sphincter muscle is divided to lower pressure permanently. Healing rates exceed 90 %.  
   • Risk of minor gas seepage in the first few weeks; long-term incontinence risk is low (1-3 %) in experienced hands.  
   • Generally reserved for chronic fissures that fail medical/ Botox therapy or for fissures complicated by a skin tag (“sentinel pile”), visible internal sphincter fibers, or severe spasm.

9. Look for contributing conditions  
   • Chronic constipation or diarrhea  
   • Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn’s)  
   • Hypothyroidism, hypercalcemia, medications (e.g., opioids)  
   Treating the underlying issue improves healing and prevents recurrence.

10. Red-flag symptoms—seek prompt evaluation if you notice  
   • Rapidly increasing pain, swelling, fever (possible abscess)  
   • Heavy or persistent bleeding  
   • New change in bowel habits, unexplained weight loss, or family history of colorectal cancer

Key take-away  
After two years, a fissure rarely heals with diet and baths alone. A colorectal specialist can confirm the diagnosis and then usually progress through topical calcium-channel blockers or nitroglycerin (6–8 weeks), Botox, and, if needed, lateral internal sphincterotomy. These steps are highly effective and can put an end to the cycle of pain.

Reliable sources you can review before your visit  
• American Society of Colon & Rectal Surgeons: “Anal Fissure” fact sheet  
• Mayo Clinic: Anal fissure overview and treatment  
• Cleveland Clinic: Anal fissure patient guide

Bring this outline to your appointment, and don’t hesitate to ask about each option.

Anal fissure: An anal fissure is a small tear in the thin, moist tissue (mucosa) that lines the anus. An anal fissure may occur when you pass hard or large stools during a bowel movement. Anal fissures typically cause pain and bleeding with bowel movements. You also may experience spasms in the ring of muscle at the end of your anus (anal sphincter). Anal fissures are very common in young infants but can affect people of any age. Most anal fissures get better with simple treatments, such as increased fiber intake or sitz baths. Some people with anal fissures may need medication or, occasionally, surgery. Signs and symptoms of an anal fissure include: - Pain, sometimes severe, during bowel movements - Pain after bowel movements that can last up to several hours - Bright red blood on the stool or toilet paper after a bowel movement - Itching or irritation around the anus - A visible crack in the skin around the anus - A small lump or skin tag on the skin near the anal fissure When to see a doctor See your doctor if you have pain during bowel movements or notice blood on stools or toilet paper after a bowel movement. Common causes of anal fissure include: - Passing large or hard stools - Constipation and straining during bowel movements - Chronic diarrhea - Inflammation of the anorectal area, caused by Crohn's disease or another inflammatory bowel disease - Childbirth Less common causes of anal fissures include: - Anal cancer - HIV - Tuberculosis - Syphilis - Herpes Factors that may increase your risk of developing an anal fissure include: - Infancy. Many infants experience an anal fissure during their first year of life; experts aren't sure why. - Aging. Older adults may develop an anal fissure partly due to slowed circulation, resulting in decreased blood flow to the rectal area. - Constipation. Straining during bowel movements and passing hard stools increase the risk of tearing. - Childbirth. Anal fissures are more common in women after they give birth. - Crohn's disease. This inflammatory bowel disease causes chronic inflammation of the intestinal tract, which may make the lining of the anal canal more vulnerable to tearing. - Anal intercourse. Complications of anal fissure can include: - Failure to heal. An anal fissure that fails to heal within six weeks is considered chronic and may need further treatment. - Recurrence. Once you've experienced an anal fissure, you are prone to having another one. - A tear that extends to surrounding muscles. An anal fissure may extend into the ring of muscle that holds your anus closed (internal anal sphincter), making it more difficult for your anal fissure to heal. An unhealed fissure can trigger a cycle of discomfort that may require medications or surgery to reduce the pain and to repair or remove the fissure. If possible, your doctor will perform a digital rectal exam, which involves inserting a gloved finger into your anal canal, or use a short, lighted tube (anoscope) to inspect your anal canal. However, if this is too painful for you, your doctor may be able to diagnose an anal fissure only by observation. An acute anal fissure looks like a fresh tear, somewhat like a paper cut. A chronic anal fissure likely has the tear, as well as two separate lumps or tags of skin, one internal (sentinel pile) and one external (hypertrophied papilla). The fissure's location offers clues about its cause. A fissure that occurs on the side of the anal opening, rather than the back or front, is more likely to be a sign of another disorder, such as Crohn's disease. Your doctor may recommend further testing if he or she thinks you have an underlying condition: - Flexible sigmoidoscopy. Your doctor will insert a thin, flexible tube with a tiny video into the bottom portion of your colon. This test may be done if you're younger than 50 and have no risk factors for intestinal diseases or colon cancer. - Colonoscopy. Your doctor will insert a flexible tube into your rectum to inspect the entire colon. This test may be done if you are older than age 50 or you have risk factors for colon cancer, signs of other conditions, or other symptoms such as abdominal pain or diarrhea. Anal fissures often heal within a few weeks if you take steps to keep your stool soft, such as increasing your intake of fiber and fluids. Soaking in warm water for 10 to 20 minutes several times a day, especially after bowel movements, can help relax the sphincter and promote healing. If your symptoms persist, you'll likely need further treatment. Nonsurgical treatments Your doctor may recommend: - Externally applied nitroglycerin (Rectiv), to help increase blood flow to the fissure and promote healing and to help relax the anal sphincter. Nitroglycerin is generally considered the medical treatment of choice when other conservative measures fail. Side effects may include headache, which can be severe. - Topical anesthetic creams such as lidocaine hydrochloride (Xylocaine) may be helpful for pain relief. - Botulinum toxin type A (Botox) injection, to paralyze the anal sphincter muscle and relax spasms. - Blood pressure medications, such as oral nifedipine (Procardia) or diltiazem (Cardizem) can help relax the anal sphincter. These medications may be taken by mouth or applied externally and may be used when nitroglycerin is not effective or causes significant side effects. Surgery If you have a chronic anal fissure that is resistant to other treatments, or if your symptoms are severe, your doctor may recommend surgery. Doctors usually perform a procedure called lateral internal sphincterotomy (LIS), which involves cutting a small portion of the anal sphincter muscle to reduce spasm and pain, and promote healing. Studies have found that for chronic fissure, surgery is much more effective than any medical treatment. However, surgery has a small risk of causing incontinence. Several lifestyle changes may help relieve discomfort and promote healing of an anal fissure, as well as prevent recurrences: - Add fiber to your diet. Eating about 25 to 30 grams of fiber a day can help keep stools soft and improve fissure healing. Fiber-rich foods include fruits, vegetables, nuts and whole grains. You also can take a fiber supplement. Adding fiber may cause gas and bloating, so increase your intake gradually. - Drink adequate fluids. Fluids help prevent constipation. - Exercise regularly. Engage in 30 minutes or more of moderate physical activity, such as walking, most days of the week. Exercise promotes regular bowel movements and increases blood flow to all parts of your body, which may promote healing of an anal fissure. - Avoid straining during bowel movements. Straining creates pressure, which can open a healing tear or cause a new tear. If your infant has an anal fissure, be sure to change diapers frequently, wash the area gently and discuss the problem with your child's doctor.

Information only – not a substitute for professional medical advice.  
------------------------------------------------------------------

What’s probably happening  
• An “ingrown” toenail (onychocryptosis) develops when the edge or corner of the nail curves or is pushed into the surrounding skin.  
• The nail fold becomes irritated, swollen, painful and can easily get infected.  
• When the problem lingers for months or years, extra skin and scar tissue grow around the nail, making it even harder for the nail to grow out normally.

Why it keeps coming back  
1. The nail may be naturally wide, thick or curved.  
2. Shoes or socks that squeeze the toes keep driving the nail edge inward.  
3. Cutting the nail too short or rounding the corners lets the skin roll over the edge, trapping the nail.  
4. Re-growth after a partial “self-trim” often leaves a sharp nail spike under the skin.  
5. Medical conditions (fungal nail, injury, diabetes, poor circulation) slow healing.

Four years = time to see a foot specialist  
A problem that has persisted this long almost never clears with home care alone. A podiatrist, family physician or foot/ankle surgeon can:

• Examine the toe, rule out infection or bone involvement (rarely, X-ray).  
• Offer office-based procedures that remove just the troublesome edge or, if needed, the whole nail root on that side. Success rates are 90 %+ and the nail usually still looks normal afterward.  
• Prescribe antibiotics if there is active infection.  
• Check your circulation and sensation—critical if you have diabetes, vascular disease or neuropathy.

Self-care until you’re seen  
(The goals are to reduce pain and keep infection away, not to “cure” a 4-year ingrown toenail.)

1. Warm soaks: 10–15 min in warm water with plain Epsom salt, 2–3×/day.  
2. Keep the toe clean, dry between soaks, and loosely covered with a breathable bandage.  
3. OTC pain relievers such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen (if you have no medical reason to avoid them).  
4. Shoes: wide toe box, open-toe sandals or barefoot at home; avoid tight socks.  
5. Do NOT “dig out” the nail or cut a V-notch in the center—these methods are myths and often worsen the problem.

When to seek urgent care  
• Spreading redness, warmth, pus, or a red streak up the foot/leg.  
• Fever or feeling unwell.  
• You have diabetes, poor circulation, immune suppression, or neuropathy and notice any break in the skin.

What definitive treatment looks like  
1. Partial nail avulsion + chemical matrixectomy (phenol or sodium hydroxide): the ingrown edge is numbed, removed, and the root on that side is cauterized so it can’t regrow. Walking is usually possible the same day; healing takes 1–3 weeks.  
2. Gutter or splint technique: a thin strip of plastic is slid under the nail edge to lift it away while it grows out. Works best in early cases.  
3. Total nail removal is rarely needed unless the whole nail is diseased or severely deformed.  
4. If fungal infection is contributing, oral or topical antifungal medicine may be added.

Prevention once it’s fixed  
• Trim straight across; leave the corners visible. File sharp tips instead of cutting deep curves.  
• Don’t tear or pick at nails.  
• Keep nails moderately long—about even with the end of the toe.  
• Wear shoes with at least a thumb’s width of space beyond the longest toe; avoid high heels and narrow toe boxes for long periods.  
• Manage sweating; keep feet clean and dry.  
• Control contributing conditions: treat fungal nail, manage blood sugar, stop smoking to improve circulation.

Take-home message  
An ingrown toenail that has lasted four years almost always needs professional attention. Office procedures are quick, done under local anesthetic, and provide permanent relief for most people. Make an appointment with a podiatrist or your primary care clinician as soon as you can, and use the comfort measures above in the meantime.

Reliable resources  
• American College of Foot and Ankle Surgeons – Ingrown Toenail Patient Guide  
• Mayo Clinic – Ingrown Toenails  
• UK National Health Service (NHS) – Ingrown Toenail Treatment

If you cannot get an appointment soon and notice any signs of infection, go to an urgent care or emergency department.

Ingrown toenail (Treatment): If you have diabetes, nerve problem in the leg or foot, poor blood circulation to your foot, or an infection around the nail, see a provider right away. Don't try to treat an ingrown nail at home. Otherwise, to treat an ingrown nail at home: - Soak the foot in warm water 3 to 4 times a day if possible. After soaking, keep the toe dry. - Gently massage over the inflamed skin. - Place a small piece of cotton or dental floss under the nail. Wet the cotton or floss with water or antiseptic. When trimming your toenails: - Briefly soak your foot in warm water to soften the nails. - Use a clean, sharp trimmer. - Trim toenails straight across the top. Do not taper or round the corners or trim too short.  - Do not try to cut out the ingrown portion of the nail yourself. This will only make the problem worse. Consider wearing sandals until the problem goes away. Over-the-counter medicine that is applied to the ingrown toenail may help with the pain, but it does not treat the problem. If this doesn't work and the ingrown nail gets worse, see your family doctor, a foot specialist (podiatrist), or a skin specialist (dermatologist). If the ingrown nail doesn't heal or keeps coming back, your provider may remove part of the nail: - Numbing medicine is first injected into the toe. - The ingrown part of the nail is removed. This procedure is called a partial nail avulsion. - It takes 2 to 4 months for the nail to regrow. If the toe is infected, your doctor may prescribe antibiotics. After the procedure, follow any instructions for helping your nail heal.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Kartagener’s syndrome (often grouped under the broader term “Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia” or PCD) is a rare, inherited condition in which the microscopic, hair-like structures (cilia) that line the airways, sinuses, middle ears and reproductive tract do not beat normally.  Because cilia move mucus, bacteria and, in the reproductive organs, sperm or eggs, their poor function produces two major sets of problems:

1.  Respiratory/ENT symptoms (from impaired mucus clearance)  
2.  Fertility and certain pregnancy-related issues (from impaired movement of sperm or eggs)

Below is a practical overview with an emphasis on fertility.

------------------------------------------------------
1.  Main features and symptoms
------------------------------------------------------
•  Classic triad:  
   – Chronic sinusitis and nasal congestion, often beginning in infancy  
   – Chronic bronchitis/bronchiectasis (persistent wet cough, recurrent chest infections)  
   – Situs inversus totalis (the heart and abdominal organs are “mirror-image” in about 50 % of patients).  

•  Ears: recurrent middle-ear infections, fluid build-up, possible hearing loss.  

•  Lungs: neonatal respiratory distress, chronic wet cough, wheeze, repeated pneumonia; some patients need long-term antibiotics or airway-clearance therapy.  

•  Nose/sinuses: nasal polyps, loss of smell.  

•  Fertility (see next section).  

•  Other: recurrent headaches from sinus pressure, fatigue from chronic infection; very rarely hydrocephalus in infancy.

------------------------------------------------------
2.  Fertility in Kartagener’s syndrome
------------------------------------------------------
MEN  
•  Sperm are usually produced in normal numbers, but the flagella (tails) have the same structural defects as respiratory cilia, so they do not swim well.  
•  Result: markedly reduced sperm motility (asthenozoospermia) → natural conception is uncommon.  
•  Options:  
   – Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI), a form of in-vitro fertilization (IVF) in which a single sperm is injected directly into an egg, bypasses the motility problem and has good success rates.  
   – Prior semen analysis and discussion with a reproductive urologist are recommended.

WOMEN  
•  The cilia lining the fallopian tubes help move the egg toward the uterus.  Their impaired beating can:  
   – Delay or prevent the egg and sperm from meeting, reducing fertility.  
   – Increase the risk of an ectopic (tubal) pregnancy because the embryo may not reach the uterus promptly.  
•  Natural pregnancies do occur, but time-to-pregnancy is often longer.  
•  Options:  
   – Timed intercourse or intrauterine insemination (IUI) sometimes help.  
   – IVF can bypass the tubes entirely; success is generally similar to that of couples without PCD when maternal age and other factors are matched.  
•  All women with PCD should have early ultrasound when pregnant to confirm the embryo is in the uterus and not in the tube.

PREGNANCY AND DELIVERY CONSIDERATIONS  
•  Situs inversus alone does not usually complicate pregnancy, but obstetricians should be aware (heart sounds, organ position, etc.).  
•  Good control of respiratory infections and regular airway-clearance therapy remain important during pregnancy.

------------------------------------------------------
3.  Genetics and inheritance
------------------------------------------------------
•  Autosomal-recessive: both parents are usually healthy carriers; each child has a 25 % chance of having the condition.  
•  More than 50 genes are known so far; genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis and clarify recurrence risks.  
•  Couples may benefit from meeting with a genetic counselor before family planning.

------------------------------------------------------
4.  Diagnosis
------------------------------------------------------
•  Clinical history + imaging (CT of sinuses/lungs, chest X-ray showing dextrocardia or situs inversus).  
•  Low nasal nitric oxide test (screening).  
•  Ciliary biopsy with high-speed video microscopy and/or electron microscopy to look for structural defects.  
•  Genetic panel testing.

------------------------------------------------------
5.  Day-to-day management
------------------------------------------------------
•  Airway-clearance physiotherapy (vest therapy, percussion/postural drainage).  
•  Prompt, culture-guided antibiotics for chest or sinus infections.  
•  Routine vaccinations, annual flu shot, COVID-19 boosters, and pneumococcal vaccine.  
•  Regular ENT and audiology checks, especially in childhood.  
•  Bronchodilators or inhaled antibiotics in some cases; occasional sinus surgery or ear tubes.  
•  Lung-function monitoring; referral to a specialized PCD or cystic-fibrosis clinic when available.  
•  In advanced lung disease, lung transplantation is an option.

------------------------------------------------------
6.  Outlook
------------------------------------------------------
With modern airway

•  Fertility (see next section).  

•  Other: recurrent headaches from sinus pressure, fatigue from chronic infection; very rarely hydrocephalus in infancy.

------------------------------------------------------
2.  Fertility in Kartagener’s syndrome
------------------------------------------------------
MEN  
•  Sperm are usually produced in normal numbers, but the flagella (tails) have the same structural defects as respiratory cilia, so they do not swim well.  
•  Result: markedly reduced sperm motility (asthenozoospermia) → natural conception is uncommon.  
•  Options:  
   – Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI), a form of in-vitro fertilization (IVF) in which a single sperm is injected directly into an egg, bypasses the motility problem and has good success rates.  
   – Prior semen analysis and discussion with a reproductive urologist are recommended.

WOMEN  
•  The cilia lining the fallopian tubes help move the egg toward the uterus.  Their impaired beating can:  
   – Delay or prevent the egg and sperm from meeting, reducing fertility.  
   – Increase the risk of an ectopic (tubal) pregnancy because the embryo may not reach the uterus promptly.  
•  Natural pregnancies do occur, but time-to-pregnancy is often longer.  
•  Options:  
   – Timed intercourse or intrauterine insemination (IUI) sometimes help.  
   – IVF can bypass the tubes entirely; success is generally similar to that of couples without PCD when maternal age and other factors are matched.  
•  All women with PCD should have early ultrasound when pregnant to confirm the embryo is in the uterus and not in the tube.

PREGNANCY AND DELIVERY CONSIDERATIONS  
•  Situs inversus alone does not usually complicate pregnancy, but obstetricians should be aware (heart sounds, organ position, etc.).  
•  Good control of respiratory infections and regular airway-clearance therapy remain important during pregnancy.

------------------------------------------------------
3.  Genetics and inheritance
------------------------------------------------------
•  Autosomal-recessive: both parents are usually healthy carriers; each child has a 25 % chance of having the condition.  
•  More than 50 genes are known so far; genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis and clarify recurrence risks.  
•  Couples may benefit from meeting with a genetic counselor before family planning.

------------------------------------------------------
4.  Diagnosis
------------------------------------------------------
•  Clinical history + imaging (CT of sinuses/lungs, chest X-ray showing dextrocardia or situs inversus).  
•  Low nasal nitric oxide test (screening).  
•  Ciliary biopsy with high-speed video microscopy and/or electron microscopy to look for structural defects.  
•  Genetic panel testing.

------------------------------------------------------
5.  Day-to-day management
------------------------------------------------------
•  Airway-clearance physiotherapy (vest therapy, percussion/postural drainage).  
•  Prompt, culture-guided antibiotics for chest or sinus infections.  
•  Routine vaccinations, annual flu shot, COVID-19 boosters, and pneumococcal vaccine.  
•  Regular ENT and audiology checks, especially in childhood.  
•  Bronchodilators or inhaled antibiotics in some cases; occasional sinus surgery or ear tubes.  
•  Lung-function monitoring; referral to a specialized PCD or cystic-fibrosis clinic when available.  
•  In advanced lung disease, lung transplantation is an option.

------------------------------------------------------
6.  Outlook
------------------------------------------------------
With modern airway

Below is general, consumer–friendly information about distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA) and a list of reliable places—many of them Spanish-language or based in Mexico—where you can obtain additional details, medical guidance and family support.  
(Use it as background only; your daughter’s own doctors remain the best source of advice.)

1. What is distal renal tubular acidosis?  
• The kidneys normally keep body fluids “in balance” by getting rid of acids that are produced every day.  
• In dRTA (also called Type 1 RTA or acidosis tubular renal distal) the last part of the kidney tubule cannot remove hydrogen ions (acid) properly. Acid builds up in the blood (metabolic acidosis) while the urine stays too alkaline.  
• Over time this can lead to poor growth, vomiting, dehydration, low potassium, rickets/osteopenia, kidney stones or nephrocalcinosis (calcium deposits in the kidneys).  
• The condition can be inherited (autosomal dominant or recessive) or acquired after certain autoimmune, kidney or drug-related conditions. Some hereditary forms are linked with sensorineural hearing loss.

2. How is it diagnosed?  
• Blood tests: low bicarbonate, normal anion-gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis; low/normal potassium; high chloride.  
• Urine pH usually stays > 5.5 even during acidosis; urine may contain large amounts of calcium.  
• Kidney ultrasound may show stones or calcium deposits; bone X-rays may show rickets in children.  
• Genetic testing is sometimes done to confirm the exact mutation and to guide family counseling.

3. Treatment (your daughter’s nephrologist will individualize):  
• Lifelong oral alkali therapy (sodium bicarbonate or potassium citrate) to correct the acid and keep serum bicarbonate normal.  
• Extra potassium if needed.  
• Lots of fluids; sometimes thiazide diuretics to lower urinary calcium loss.  
• Vitamin D and calcium monitoring for bone health.  
• Hearing checks in the recessive forms linked to deafness.  
With good control, growth usually normalizes, urine calcium falls, stones stop forming and long-term kidney function is preserved.

4. Prognosis  
• When treatment is started early and taken consistently, children generally catch up in growth and avoid chronic kidney disease.  
• Without therapy, chronic acidosis can lead to poor growth, bone disease, repeated stones and eventual kidney failure.

5. Where can I learn more or find help?  
Mexican organizations / Spanish-language resources  
• Fundación Mexicana del Riñón, A.C.  
  www.fundaciondelrinon.org.mx | Tel. (55) 5658-1199  
  Provides patient education, screening campaigns and can direct you to pediatric nephrologists in Mexico.  

• Asociación ALE, I.A.P.  
  www.asociacionale.org.mx | contacto@asociacionale.org.mx  
  NGO dedicated to kidney disease patients, transplants and family support; has regional chapters.  

• Sociedad Latinoamericana de Nefrología y Hipertensión (SLANH) – sección Pediatría  
  www.slanh.net | Lists certified pediatric nephrology centers throughout Mexico and Latin America.  

• Centro Nacional de Trasplantes (CENATRA) – though focused on transplantation, their staff often have kidney patient support contacts.  
  www.gob.mx/cenatra  

• MedlinePlus en español: “Acidosis tubular renal”  
  https://medlineplus.gov/spanish/ency/article/000497.htm  
  Consumer-level overview reviewed by the U.S. National Library of Medicine.

International / Rare-disease groups (some pages available in Spanish)

  https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov | Search “distal renal tubular acidosis” (includes Spanish PDF). Free phone/email service answers family questions.  

• National Organization for Rare Disorders (NORD)  
  rarediseases.org | Has a fact sheet on dRTA.  

• Orphanet (EU rare-disease portal)  
  www.orpha.net | Información en español, list of expert centers, ongoing studies.  

• National Kidney Foundation (USA) – many handouts in Spanish (“La acidosis tubular renal” PDF)  
  www.kidney.org  

• International Pediatric Nephrology Association (IPNA) – global map of pediatric nephrologists and patient groups.  
  ipna-online.org  

Online peer support  
• “Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA) – Support Group” (Facebook, English & Spanish posts)  
• Inspire.com kidney communities (English, but Mexican parents participate).  
Always verify any medical

<gold_response>
SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis (Description): SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis is a kidney (renal) disorder that sometimes includes blood cell abnormalities. The kidneys normally filter fluid and waste products from the body and remove them in urine; however, in people with distal renal tubular acidosis, the kidneys are unable to remove enough acid from the body, and the blood becomes too acidic. This chemical imbalance is called metabolic acidosis. The inability to remove acids from the body often results in slowed growth and may also lead to softening and weakening of the bones, called rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. This bone disorder is characterized by bone pain, bowed legs, and difficulty walking. In addition, most children and adults with SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis have excess calcium in the urine (hypercalciuria), calcium deposits in the kidneys (nephrocalcinosis), and kidney stones (nephrolithiasis). In rare cases, these kidney abnormalities lead to life-threatening kidney failure. Affected individuals may also have low levels of potassium in the blood (hypokalemia). Individuals with the features described above have complete distal renal tubular acidosis, which usually becomes apparent in childhood. Some people do not develop metabolic acidosis even though their kidneys have trouble removing acids; these individuals are said to have incomplete distal renal tubular acidosis. Additionally, these individuals may have other features of distal renal tubular acidosis, such as bone problems and kidney stones. Often, people who initially have incomplete distal renal tubular acidosis develop metabolic acidosis later in life. Some people with SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis also have blood cell abnormalities. These can vary in severity from no symptoms to a condition called hemolytic anemia, in which red blood cells prematurely break down (undergo hemolysis), causing a shortage of red blood cells (anemia). Hemolytic anemia can lead to unusually pale skin (pallor), extreme tiredness (fatigue), shortness of breath (dyspnea), and an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly). There are two forms of SLC4A1-associated distal renal tubular acidosis; they are distinguished by their inheritance pattern. The autosomal dominant form is more common and is usually less severe than the autosomal recessive form. The autosomal dominant form can be associated with incomplete or complete distal renal tubular acidosis and is rarely associated with blood cell abnormalities. The autosomal recessive form is always associated with complete distal renal tubular acidosis and is more commonly associated with blood cell abnormalities, although not everyone with this form has abnormal blood cells.
</gold_response>

Lewy body disease (most often called Lewy body dementia, or LBD) is a progressive brain-degenerating illness related to both Alzheimer’s disease and Parkinson’s disease.  Below are answers to the three points you asked about, written for a general (non-medical) audience.  Please remember that no written reply can replace advice from your own health-care provider.  

────────────────────────
1)  Is Lewy body disease hereditary?
────────────────────────
• Most people who develop LBD do NOT have a clear-cut hereditary or “familial” form.  
• Age (usually over 60), male sex, and having Parkinson’s disease are the strongest known risk factors.  
• Researchers have found a handful of gene changes (mutations in or near the SNCA, GBA, LRRK2 and APOE genes) that can raise risk.  These mutations are uncommon, and even when they occur they do not guarantee that a person will get LBD.  
• In practical terms: if one parent has Lewy body dementia, the chance that a child will also develop it later in life is thought to be only slightly higher than the risk in the general population.  That is very different from strongly hereditary disorders such as Huntington’s disease.  
• Gene testing is therefore not routinely recommended unless the family is part of a research study or multiple relatives have Parkinson’s-type disorders at unusually young ages.  

────────────────────────
2)  Does alcoholism play a role in starting the disease?
────────────────────────
• Current medical evidence does not show heavy alcohol use as a cause or trigger of Lewy body dementia.  
• Long-term, heavy drinking can itself lead to other types of cognitive decline (alcohol-related dementia, Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome) that may look similar, but the underlying brain changes are different from the Lewy bodies seen under a microscope in LBD.  
• That said, alcohol can worsen attention, balance, sleep, and mood in anyone, and can make the symptoms of an existing Lewy body disorder worse or harder to manage.  
• Moderate alcohol intake (e.g., a daily drink or less) has not been shown to increase or decrease LBD risk.  

────────────────────────
3)  What are the initial/early symptoms?
────────────────────────
Early presentation varies from person to person, but the most common “red-flag” features are:  

Cognitive & psychiatric
• Fluctuating attention and alertness — periods of seeming “spacy,” drowsy, or confused that can come and go from hour to hour or day to day.  
• Visual hallucinations — repeatedly seeing people, animals, or objects that are not there; typically well-formed and detailed.  
• Mild memory problems, difficulty finding words, trouble with planning or multitasking.  
• Mood or behavior changes (depression, anxiety, apathy, irritability).  

Motor (movement-related)
• Parkinsonian signs: slowness (bradykinesia), muscle rigidity/stiffness, shuffling walk, stooped posture, reduced facial expression, sometimes a resting tremor.  
• Frequent falls or imbalance.  

Sleep & autonomic
• REM sleep behavior disorder (acting out vivid dreams, punching, kicking, yelling while asleep) years before other symptoms.  
• Excessive daytime sleepiness or insomnia.  
• Autonomic changes: dizziness on standing (low blood pressure), constipation, urinary urgency, erectile dysfunction.  

Other pointers
• People with early LBD often have a striking sensitivity to certain antipsychotic (neuroleptic) drugs, developing severe stiffness, confusion, or a sudden drop in blood pressure if these medicines are given.  
• Symptoms usually progress slowly over years, but the day-to-day fluctuations can be dramatic, sometimes leading families to suspect “mini-strokes” even though that is not the cause.  

────────────────────────
Where to learn more / get support
────────────────────────
• Lewy Body Dementia Association (LBDA): https://www.lbda.org  
• National Institute on Aging (NIH): “Lewy Body Dementia” factsheet – https://www.nia.nih.gov/health/lewy-body-dementia  
• Mayo Clinic Patient Guide: https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/lewy-body-dementia  
• For caregivers: local chapters of the Alzheimer’s Association often have support groups that welcome LBD families.  

────────────────────────
Bottom line
────────────────────────
Lewy body dementia is usually not hereditary, and alcohol use has not been shown to initiate it (though heavy drinking can cause other dementias and may complicate LBD care).  Early warning signs include fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, Parkinson-like movement problems, REM sleep behavior disorder, and pronounced sensitivity to certain medications. • REM sleep behavior disorder (acting out vivid dreams, punching, kicking, yelling while asleep) years before other symptoms.  
• Excessive daytime sleepiness or insomnia.  
• Autonomic changes: dizziness on standing (low blood pressure), constipation, urinary urgency, erectile dysfunction.

• People with early LBD often have a striking sensitivity to certain antipsychotic (neuroleptic) drugs, developing severe stiffness, confusion, or a sudden drop in blood pressure if these medicines are given.

• For caregivers: local chapters of the Alzheimer’s Association often have support groups that welcome LBD families.

────────────────────────

Lewy body dementia: Lewy body dementia is one of the most common forms of progressive dementia. People affected by this condition may experience a variety of symptoms such as changes in alertness and attention; hallucinations; problems with movement and posture; muscle stiffness; confusion; and/or memory loss. Although the exact cause of Lewy body dementia is poorly understood, symptoms are thought to result when clumps of a protein called alpha-synuclein ("Lewy bodies") accumulate in the brain. Lewy body dementia usually occurs sporadically in people with no family history of the condition. Rarely, more than one family member may be affected. There is currently no cure for Lewy body dementia; however, medications may be available to help manage the associated symptoms. [1] [2] [3] The Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) provides the following list of features that have been reported in people with this condition. Much of the information in the HPO comes from Orphanet, a European rare disease database. If available, the list includes a rough estimate of how common a feature is (its frequency). Frequencies are based on a specific study and may not be representative of all studies. You can use the MedlinePlus Medical Dictionary for definitions of the terms below. Signs and Symptoms Approximate number of patients (when available) Autosomal dominant inheritance - Delusions - Dementia - Fluctuations in consciousness - Parkinsonism - Visual hallucinations - The exact underlying cause of Lewy body dementia is poorly understood. The symptoms of the condition are thought to occur when clumps of a protein called alpha-synuclein accumulate in the regions of the brain involved in thinking, memory and movement. The build-up of these clumps (which are called "Lewy bodies") appears to be associated with a loss of certain neurons (nerve cells ) in the brain that produce two important neurotransmitters (chemicals that act as messengers between brain cells). The neurotransmitter, acetylcholine, is important for memory and learning. The other, dopamine, plays an important role in behavior, cognition, movement, motivation, sleep, and mood. [4] Although Lewy body dementia usually occurs sporadically, more than one family member can rarely be affected. Studies of these families suggest that there may be a genetic component to the condition in some cases. For example, copy number variants or changes ( mutations ) in the SNCA gene have been reported in a few affected families. [5] [6] The APOE ε4 allele and mutations in the GBA gene have been associated with an increased risk of Lewy body dementia and the APOE ε2 allele with a decreased risk. [5] [7] [2] Most cases of Lewy body dementia are not thought to be inherited . The condition generally occurs sporadically in people with no family history of the condition. [4] Rarely, the condition can affect more than one family member. Some of these cases appear to be due to single gene changes ( mutations ) that follow an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Other familial cases do not follow a specific pattern of inheritance and likely have a multifactorial cause (associated with the effects of multiple genes in combination with lifestyle and environmental factors ). [6] [5] Making a diagnosis for a genetic or rare disease can often be challenging. Healthcare professionals typically look at a person’s medical history, symptoms, physical exam, and laboratory test results in order to make a diagnosis. The following resources provide information relating to diagnosis and testing for this condition. If you have questions about getting a diagnosis, you should contact a healthcare professional. Testing Resources The Genetic Testing Registry (GTR) provides information about the genetic tests for this condition. The intended audience for the GTR is health care providers and researchers. Patients and consumers with specific questions about a genetic test should contact a health care provider or a genetics professional. The Lewy Body Dementia Association offers detailed and up-to-date information regarding the treatment and management of Lewy body dementia . Please click on the link to access this resource.

Below is a side-by-side summary for each condition, followed by a note on how a typical public-health or non-profit “agency” (for example a state Birth Defects Program, the March of Dimes, National Tay-Sachs & Allied Diseases Association, Shriners Children’s Hospitals, etc.) can help parents who are worried about either disorder.  
(Information is for general education only and is not a substitute for personal medical advice.)

────────────────────────────────────────
1.  WHAT IS IT AND HOW DOES IT AFFECT A BABY?
────────────────────────────────────────
Tay-Sachs disease (TSD)
•  Rare, inherited, progressive neurologic disease.  
•  Babies appear normal at birth, but between 3–6 months they begin to lose motor skills (rolling, sitting). Gradually develop muscle weakness, loss of vision/hearing, seizures, swallowing problems and paralysis.  
•  Classic infantile form is usually fatal in early childhood (often by age 4–5). Juvenile and adult-onset variants are less common and progress more slowly.

Clubfoot (congenital talipes equino-varus)
•  A structural birth defect of the foot/ankle in which the foot points downward and inward; calf muscles are often smaller.  
•  The baby generally feels no pain, but if it is not corrected walking can become difficult and painful, and abnormal shoe wear, calluses or arthritis can occur later.  
•  With early treatment most children grow up to walk, run and play normally.

────────────────────────────────────────
2.  CAUSE – CAN IT BE PREVENTED, TREATED OR CURED?
────────────────────────────────────────
Tay-Sachs disease
•  Cause: A mutation in the HEXA gene → deficiency of the enzyme β-hexosaminidase A → toxic build-up of GM2 ganglioside in brain cells.  
•  Inheritance: Autosomal recessive (both parents must be silent “carriers”).  
•  Prevention: Carrier screening before pregnancy or in early pregnancy; options include:
    – Partner carrier testing  
    – Prenatal diagnostic testing (CVS/amniocentesis)  
    – Pre-implantation genetic testing with IVF  
•  Treatment/Cure: No cure at present. Care is supportive (seizure control, nutrition, respiratory care, physical therapy, palliative/hospice services). Research trials (e.g., gene therapy) are under way, but still experimental.

Clubfoot
•  Cause: Multifactorial. A combination of genes and environmental factors that disturb normal foot/leg development early in pregnancy. Sometimes isolated; sometimes part of a syndrome or related to conditions like spina bifida.  
•  Prevention: No proven way to prevent the isolated form. General pregnancy health measures (avoid smoking, adequate folic acid, avoid early amniocentesis) may reduce risk slightly.  
•  Treatment/Cure: Highly effective, especially when begun soon after birth:
    – Ponseti method (weekly gentle manipulation & casting for 4-8 weeks, then a small outpatient heel-cord release in many cases, followed by a nighttime brace for several years).  
    – French/physiotherapy method (daily stretching/taping).  
    – Less commonly, extensive surgery for resistant cases.  
    – Long-term outcome is excellent for > 90 % of children treated early; they lead active, unrestricted lives.

────────────────────────────────────────
3.  HOW COMMON IS IT?
────────────────────────────────────────
Tay-Sachs disease  
•  General U.S./world birth prevalence: �� 1 in 320,000 live births.  
•  Higher-risk groups: Ashkenazi Jewish, French-Canadian, Cajun and certain Pennsylvania Dutch populations (carrier frequency in Ashkenazi Jews about 1 in 27).

Clubfoot  
•  Worldwide average: 1–2 per 1,000 live births (about 1 baby every 15-20 minutes worldwide).  
•  More common in males (�� 2:1) and in some geographic/ethnic groups (e.g., Hawaiians, Maoris).

────────────────────────────────────────
4.  HOW CAN AN “AGENCY” HELP PARENTS, AND WHAT DOES IT COST?
────────────────────────────────────────
What most maternal-child-health or birth-defects agencies can offer  
•  Accurate, plain-language information on both conditions.  
•  Referral to:
    – Genetic counselors (carrier testing, interpretation of results, discussion of reproductive choices).  
    – Pediatric orthopaedic specialists or multidisciplinary clinics (for clubfoot).  
    – Pediatric neurologists/metabolic clinics and palliative-care teams (for TSD).  
•  Support services:
    – Parent-to-parent mentoring or local support groups.  
    – Help arranging second opinions, early-intervention services, physical/occupational therapy.  
    – Lists

<gold_response>
Tay-Sachs Disease: Tay-Sachs disease is a inherited metabolic disease caused by the harmful buildup of lipids (fatty materials such as oils and acids) in various cells and tissues in the body.  It is part of a group of genetic disorders called the GM2 gangliosidoses.  Tay-Sachs and its variant form are caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A.  Affected children appear to develop normally until about age 6 months.  Then, symptoms begin and include progressive loss of mental ability, dementia, blindness, increased startle reflex to noise, progressive loss of hearing leading to deafness, and difficulty with swallowing.  Seizures may begin in the child's second year. Persons with Tay-Sachs also have "cherry-red" spots in their eyes.  A much rarer form of the disorder, called late-onset Tay-Sachs disease, occurs in individuals in their twenties and early thirties and is characterized by an unsteady gait and progressive neurological deterioration. The incidence of Tay-Sachs has been particularly high among people of Eastern European and Askhenazi Jewish descent., as well as in certain French Canadians and Louisiana Cajuns. Affected individuals and carriers of Tay-Sachs disease can be identified by a blood test that measures hexosaminidase A activity. Both parents must carry the mutated gene in order to have an affected child. In these instances, there is a 25 percent chance with each pregnancy that the child will be affected with Tay-Sachs disease. Prenatal diagnosis is available if desired.  A very severe form of Tay-Sachs disease is know as Sandhoff disease, which is not limited to any ethnic group. Presently there is no specific treatment for Tay-Sachs disease. Anticonvulsant medicine may initially control seizures. Other supportive treatment includes proper nutrition and hydration and techniques to keep the airway open. Children may eventually need a feeding tube. Even with the best of care, children with Tay-Sachs disease usually die by age 4, from recurring infection.
</gold_response>

I’m very sorry to hear that your daughter is facing Menkes syndrome. Because it is a rare and complex condition, most families feel overwhelmed at first. The information below will give you a practical overview of what Menkes syndrome is, what treatments and supports are available, and where you can turn for additional help. Use it as a starting point for discussions with your daughter’s medical team. It does not replace advice from your own physicians.

1. What Menkes syndrome is  
• Cause: A pathogenic change (mutation) in the ATP7A gene on the X-chromosome prevents the body from transporting and absorbing copper properly. Copper is needed for many enzymes involved in brain development, connective-tissue strength, hair and skin pigmentation, and energy production.  
• Inheritance: X-linked recessive—typically affects boys more severely, but girls can be symptomatic if they have certain X-chromosome arrangements or skewed X-inactivation. A woman who carries an ATP7A mutation has a 50 % chance of passing it to each son (who would be affected) and a 50 % chance of passing it to each daughter (who would be a carrier and occasionally mildly affected).  
• Types:  
  – Classic Menkes disease (onset 2–3 months of age, most severe)  
  – Occipital horn syndrome (milder)  
  – Atypical or “intermediate” variants

2. Early signs you may already have encountered  
• Poor weight gain, irritability, low body temperature  
• Seizures, low muscle tone, developmental delay  
• “Kinky,” sparse, light-colored or steely hair; loose skin or joints  
• Recurrent respiratory infections, weak bones, bladder or vascular problems

3. Confirming or revisiting the diagnosis  
• DNA testing of ATP7A is the gold standard.  
• Low serum copper and ceruloplasmin (the main copper-carrying protein) support the diagnosis but are not enough on their own.  
• Brain MRI often shows characteristic changes, but findings vary.  
If your daughter was diagnosed some time ago, you may still wish to speak with a medical geneticist or metabolic specialist about whether additional molecular confirmation or new testing techniques could help guide care or family planning.

4. Treatment and day-to-day management  
There is no cure yet, but some interventions can modify the course and improve comfort and quality of life.

a. Copper histidinate (Cu-His) injections  
• Giving copper within the first 10–28 days of life offers the greatest chance of improving neurodevelopmental outcome and survival. If your daughter is older, benefit is less certain, but some children still gain seizure control, muscle tone improvement, or slower neurodegeneration.  
• Administration is usually subcutaneous 1 mg/kg/day at first, then individualized.  
• An experienced metabolic or neurometabolic center should supervise therapy; monitoring includes copper and ceruloplasmin levels, blood counts, liver function, and neurodevelopmental progress.

b. Seizure control  
• Standard anticonvulsant medicines are used; dose may be adjusted frequently because of feeding difficulties or malabsorption.  
• Vagus nerve stimulation and ketogenic diet have been tried in selected cases.

c. Nutritional and GI support  
• Feeding therapy, high-calorie formulas, or gastrostomy (feeding tube) may be required if swallowing becomes unsafe.  
• Adequate hydration and management of gastroesophageal reflux help reduce respiratory infections.

d. Physical, occupational, speech, and vision therapies  
• Regular therapy sessions can maximize mobility, reduce contractures, and improve communication.

e. Infection prevention  
• Vaccinations (including flu and RSV if eligible) and prompt treatment of chest infections are essential because weakened connective tissue can impair airway clearance.

f. Orthopedic and connective-tissue care  
• Loose joints can be supported with braces.  
• Fractures or vascular complications (aneurysms) need orthopedic or vascular surgical input.

g. Developmental and psychosocial support  
• Early-intervention programs; individualized education plans (IEPs) once school-aged.  
• Counseling or support groups for the family.

5. Specialists you will typically need on your daughter’s team  
• Pediatrician or internist experienced with complex care  
• Pediatric neurologist / epileptologist  
• Medical geneticist or metabolic disease specialist  
• Gastroenterologist / nutritionist  
• Pulmonologist or ENT for airway issues  
• Orthopedist and physiotherapist  
• Social worker and psychologist  
A single “medical home” or care-coordinator can keep visits organized and paperwork—especially for insurance—manageable.

6. Prognosis  
Classic Menkes disease remains life-limiting; many children survive 3–10 years, but there have been survivors into the teens and beyond, especially with early copper therapy and attentive supportive care. Milder forms (occipital horn syndrome,

3. Confirming or revisiting the diagnosis  
• DNA testing of ATP7A is the gold standard.  
• Low serum copper and ceruloplasmin (the main copper-carrying protein) support the diagnosis but are not enough on their own.  
• Brain MRI often shows characteristic changes, but findings vary.  
If your daughter was diagnosed some time ago, you may still wish to speak with a medical geneticist or metabolic specialist about whether additional molecular confirmation or new testing techniques could help guide care or family planning.

4. Treatment and day-to-day management  
There is no cure yet, but some interventions can modify the course and improve comfort and quality of life.

a. Copper histidinate (Cu-His) injections  
• Giving copper within the first 10–28 days of life offers the greatest chance of improving neurodevelopmental outcome and survival. If your daughter is older, benefit is less certain, but some children still gain seizure control, muscle tone improvement, or slower neurodegeneration.  
• Administration is usually subcutaneous 1 mg/kg/day at first, then individualized.  
• An experienced metabolic or neurometabolic center should supervise therapy; monitoring includes copper and ceruloplasmin levels, blood counts, liver function, and neurodevelopmental progress.

b. Seizure control  
• Standard anticonvulsant medicines are used; dose may be adjusted frequently because of feeding difficulties or malabsorption.  
• Vagus nerve stimulation and ketogenic diet have been tried in selected cases.

c. Nutritional and GI support  
• Feeding therapy, high-calorie formulas, or gastrostomy (feeding tube) may be required if swallowing becomes unsafe.  
• Adequate hydration and management of gastroesophageal reflux help reduce respiratory infections.

d. Physical, occupational, speech, and vision therapies  
• Regular therapy sessions can maximize mobility, reduce contractures, and improve communication.

e. Infection prevention  
• Vaccinations (including flu and RSV if eligible) and prompt treatment of chest infections are essential because weakened connective tissue can impair airway clearance.

f. Orthopedic and connective-tissue care  
• Loose joints can be supported with braces.  
• Fractures or vascular complications (aneurysms) need orthopedic or vascular surgical input.

g. Developmental and psychosocial support  
• Early-intervention programs; individualized education plans (IEPs) once school-aged.  
• Counseling or support groups for the family.

• Pediatric neurologist / epileptologist  
• Medical geneticist or metabolic disease specialist  
• Gastroenterologist / nutritionist  
• Pulmonologist or ENT for airway issues  
• Orthopedist and physiotherapist  
• Social worker and psychologist  
A single “medical home” or care-coordinator can keep visits organized and paperwork—especially for insurance—manageable.

Classic Menkes disease remains life-limiting; many children survive 3–10 years, but there have been survivors into the teens and beyond, especially with early copper therapy and attentive supportive care. Milder forms (occipital horn syndrome,

What is Menkes syndrome?: Menkes syndrome is a disorder that affects copper levels in the body. It is characterized by sparse, kinky hair; failure to gain weight and grow at the expected rate (failure to thrive); and deterioration of the nervous system. Additional signs and symptoms include weak muscle tone (hypotonia), sagging facial features, seizures, developmental delay, and intellectual disability. Children with Menkes syndrome typically begin to develop symptoms during infancy and often do not live past age 3. Early treatment with copper may improve the prognosis in some affected individuals. In rare cases, symptoms begin later in childhood. Occipital horn syndrome (sometimes called X-linked cutis laxa) is a less severe form of Menkes syndrome that begins in early to middle childhood. It is characterized by wedge-shaped calcium deposits in a bone at the base of the skull (the occipital bone), coarse hair, and loose skin and joints.
</gold_response>

   • https://rarediseases.org/rare-diseases/amyloidosis-primary-al/

   • 2-page PDF overview, includes cardiac form  
   • https://amyloidosis.org/resources/

   • 12-page booklet, free PDF or free hard copies by mail (U.S. only)  
   • https://arci.org/patient-resources/

––––––––––––––––––––––
Booklets / in-depth guides (longer)

  https://www.heart.org/attrcm

• “ATTR-CM Patient & Caregiver Handbook” – Alnylam Act™ (pharmaceutical-sponsored but medically reviewed)  
  https://www.alnylamact.com/resources/

Web pages with videos / illustrations

• Cleveland Clinic: Cardiac Amyloidosis Overview  
  https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/22924-cardiac-amyloidosis

Places that will mail brochures for free

• Amyloidosis Foundation  (info@amyloidosis.org, 1-877-AMYLOID)

Finding medical journal articles
––––––––––––––––––––––

Local help
––––––––––––––––––––––

• Public or hospital medical libraries can often print articles or booklets for you at no cost.  
• Many funeral homes will reproduce short handouts if you provide a PDF or website link.

––––––––––––––––––––––

I’m very sorry your little girl is going through this.  Below is general information on Milroy disease (congenital primary lymphedema) and the treatments that are usually recommended.  Please remember that only your child’s own doctors can make a diagnosis and design a treatment plan for her; use this information to have an informed discussion with them.

--------------------------------------------------
1.  What Milroy disease is
--------------------------------------------------
•  It is a genetic form of primary lymphedema.  
•  Babies are born with lymph-vessels that are too few, too narrow or don’t work well, so lymph fluid builds up, most often in the feet and legs but sometimes in the hands, arms or genitals.  
•  A change (mutation) in the FLT4 / VEGFR-3 gene is found in many, but not all, children with Milroy disease.  

--------------------------------------------------
2.  Why early treatment matters
--------------------------------------------------
•  Long-standing swelling can stretch the skin, harden the tissues, slow wound-healing and make infections such as cellulitis more likely.  
•  Controlling swelling early can keep the leg or arm soft, maintain function, and prevent complications later in life.  

--------------------------------------------------
3.  Doctors and clinics that usually look after these children
--------------------------------------------------
•  Pediatrician (to coordinate care)  
•  Pediatric dermatologist or vascular/lymphatic anomalies clinic  
•  Certified lymphedema therapist or physiotherapist  
•  Geneticist (for genetic testing/counseling)  
If you are not already linked with a specialty lymphedema center, ask your pediatrician for a referral.  Many children’s hospitals have a “vascular anomalies” or “lymphedema” program.

--------------------------------------------------
4.  How lymphedema is treated
--------------------------------------------------
There is, at present, no medicine that cures Milroy disease, but the swelling can almost always be reduced and kept under control with “complete decongestive therapy” (CDT).  In infants and toddlers the steps are adapted to their size and activity level:

A.  Compression  
   •  Short-stretch multilayer bandaging done by a trained therapist to bring the swelling down (decongestion phase).  
   •  Once the limb size is improved, custom-made compression garments (stockings, tights, sleeves, or special leggings) worn during the day help keep it down.  
   •  Many parents use soft night-time quilted garments or a light wrap at night.  
   •  Garments need to be resized every few months as she grows.

B.  Manual Lymph Drainage (MLD)  
   •  A gentle, specialized massage that moves fluid toward lymph-rich areas.  
   •  Parents can be taught a simplified version to use at home once a day or a few times a week.

C.  Exercise and movement  
   •  Normal crawling, walking and play are excellent; moving the muscles works like a pump under the compression.  
   •  When she is older: swimming, cycling and gentle gymnastics are good options.

D.  Skin care  
   •  Wash, rinse and dry skin folds daily; moisturize with plain, scent-free cream.  
   •  Treat cuts, insect bites or rashes promptly to prevent infection.  
   •  Watch for signs of cellulitis (redness, heat, pain, sudden swelling, fever) and seek urgent medical care—antibiotics may be needed.

E.  Weight management & nutrition  
   •  Keeping weight in a healthy range lessens the load on the lymph system.  
   •  No special diet is required, just balanced age-appropriate nutrition.

F.  Infections and vaccines  
   •  Routine childhood vaccinations can be given—usually in an unaffected limb if possible.  
   •  If cellulitis occurs repeatedly, some specialists prescribe low-dose preventive antibiotics.

G.  Surgery (only in selected cases, in expert centers)  
   •  Microsurgical options such as lymphatic-venous anastomosis (LVA) or vascularized lymph-node transfer (VLNT) are sometimes offered to older children or adults when conservative care fails.  
   •  Debulking (removal of excess tissue) is rarely done today in young children and only by experienced teams.

--------------------------------------------------
5.  Tests your doctors may suggest
--------------------------------------------------
•  Ultrasound or lymphoscintigraphy to see lymph flow.  
•  Genetic testing for FLT4/VEGFR-3 or other genes (helps with counseling but is not required to start treatment).  
•  Doppler ultrasound to be sure there is no vein clot.  
These tests guide long-term planning but do not change the day-to-day therapy described above.

--------------------------------------------------
6.  Practical tips for parents
--------------------------------------------------
•  Keep a notebook: dates of measurements, garment orders, infections, therapy sessions.  
•  Buy two sets of garments so one can be

<gold_response>
Milroy disease (Treatment): There is currently no cure for Milroy disease. Management is typically conservative and usually successful in most people. [3] Management of lymphedema should be guided by a lymphedema therapist. Some improvement is usually possible with the use of properly fitted compression hosiery or bandaging and well fitting, supportive shoes. Good skin care is essential. These measures may improve the cosmetic appearance of the affected areas, decrease their size, and reduce the risk of complications. [2] Decongestive physiotherapy , which combines compression bandaging, manual lymphatic drainage (a specialized massage technique), exercise, breathing exercises, dietary measures and skin care, has become the standard of care for primary lymphedema. [3] People with recurrent cellulitis may benefit from prophylactic antibiotics . [2] [3] Surgical intervention is considered a last option when other medical management fails. [3] When possible, people with Milroy disease should avoid: wounds to swollen areas (because of their reduced resistance to infection) long periods of immobility prolonged standing elevation of the affected limb certain medications (particularly calcium channel-blocking drugs that can cause increased leg swelling in some people)[2] Management Guidelines GeneReviews provides current, expert-authored, peer-reviewed, full-text articles describing the application of genetic testing to the diagnosis, management, and genetic counseling of patients with specific inherited conditions.

predicted_text:
Ellis-van Creveld (EVC) syndrome – sometimes called chondro-ectodermal dysplasia – is a rare, inherited condition that mainly affects the skeleton, nails, teeth, hair and, in roughly half of patients, the heart.  Fewer than 1,000 living people are documented in the medical literature, so information is scattered, but enough adults have now been followed to give a reasonable picture of life-long issues, including child-bearing.

1. Why it happens  
• Inheritance: autosomal-recessive.  A person must receive a non-working copy of either the EVC or EVC2 gene from each parent to be affected.  
• If you have EVC: every child you conceive will receive one non-working copy from you.  Unless your partner is also a carrier, none of your children will have the syndrome itself, although they will all be carriers.  If your partner is a carrier, each pregnancy faces the typical recessive ratios (25 % affected, 50 % carrier, 25 % unaffected/non-carrier).  
• Carrier frequency is very low in the general population but can be high in certain isolated communities (for example, Old-Order Amish, certain Arab and Ashkenazi villages).

2. Typical features through life  
• At birth/childhood: short limbs and stature (adult height ��100–140 cm), narrow chest, extra fingers or toes (post-axial polydactyly), small or absent nails, multiple oral frenula and tooth abnormalities.  
• Heart: 50–60 % have a congenital heart defect, most often a common atrio-ventricular canal; survival is good when the defect is mild or surgically repaired.  
• Lungs: the short, narrow rib cage can predispose to respiratory infections, particularly in early life.  
• Adulthood: persistent short stature, possible joint pain/early osteoarthritis, dental work, occasional restrictive-lung symptoms, psychosocial and employment issues typical of other short-stature conditions.

3. Sexual development, fertility and having children  
• Puberty: normal timing and hormonal profiles are the rule.  Male and female secondary sexual characteristics develop normally.  
• Fertility: there is no evidence of impaired fertility in either sex due to EVC itself.  Sperm counts, ovulation and endocrine function have been normal in the few adults analysed.  
• Published adult cases:   
  – Multiple Amish adults (men and women) with genetically confirmed EVC have fathered or given birth to several children.  
  – Bodur et al., 2015, reported a Turkish woman with EVC who carried two pregnancies to term; both infants were carriers only.  
  – Al-Kindi et al., 2020, reviewed 27 adult patients (14 female) worldwide; 8 women had been pregnant, most delivered by Caesarean section because of small pelvic capacity.  
• Obstetric considerations for women  
  – Short stature and a relatively narrow pelvis raise the risk of cephalo-pelvic disproportion; most obstetric teams plan an elective C-section.  
  – Cardiac status must be assessed pre-pregnancy; significant residual heart disease may require specialist maternal-fetal care or surgery before conception.  
  – Respiratory reserve: because the thorax is small, the normal late-pregnancy drop in lung capacity can cause breathlessness; pulmonary follow-up is recommended.  
  – Epidural/spinal anaesthesia is feasible but the anaesthetist should be aware of potential spine anomalies.  
• Men’s health issues  
  – No consistent urogenital or erectile problems are linked to EVC.  
  – Stature or limb differences can complicate usual positioning during fertility evaluation, but actual sperm function is normal in reported cases.

4. Living with EVC as an adult  
• Orthopaedics: monitoring for hip dysplasia, knee valgus and early osteoarthritis; corrective surgery may be helpful.  
• Dentistry: lifelong dental follow-up for enamel defects and missing teeth.  
• Cardiology: periodic echo if a congenital defect is present or was repaired.  
• Psychosocial: access to peer groups (see resources below) and occupational therapy for workplace adaptations.

5. Current research and registries  
• Gene discovery: 2000 (EVC and EVC2 genes, chromosome 4p16).  
• Ciliary biology: EVC/EVC2 proteins sit in the basal body of the primary cilium; the syndrome is classed as a “ciliopathy.”  Work in zebrafish and mouse models is clarifying how the defect leads to short bones and heart malformations.  
• Natural-history studies: NIH-funded skeletal-dysplasia registries (USA), the European Skeletal Dysplasia Network, and individual country registries (e.g., Germany’s).  These collect data on adults, pregnancies, surgery outcomes and quality

<gold_response>
Ellis-van Creveld syndrome (Description): Ellis-van Creveld syndrome is an inherited disorder of bone growth that results in very short stature (dwarfism). People with this condition have particularly short forearms and lower legs and a narrow chest with short ribs. Ellis-van Creveld syndrome is also characterized by the presence of extra fingers and toes (polydactyly), malformed fingernails and toenails, and dental abnormalities. More than half of affected individuals are born with a heart defect, which can cause serious or life-threatening health problems. The features of Ellis-van Creveld syndrome overlap with those of another, milder condition called Weyers acrofacial dysostosis. Like Ellis-van Creveld syndrome, Weyers acrofacial dysostosis involves tooth and nail abnormalities, although affected individuals have less pronounced short stature and typically do not have heart defects. The two conditions are caused by mutations in the same genes.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Nephrotic syndrome is not a single disease—it is a cluster of findings that appear when the tiny blood-filtering units in the kidneys (glomeruli) become abnormally “leaky.”  When this happens, large amounts of protein that should stay in the bloodstream spill into the urine.  The loss of protein creates a chain of problems that doctors group together under the name “nephrotic syndrome.”

WHAT HAPPENS IN NEPHROTIC SYNDROME  
• Heavy protein in the urine (proteinuria – usually ≥ 3–3.5 g per day)  
• Low level of albumin (protein) in the blood  
• Swelling or puffiness (edema), often first seen around the eyes, in the feet/ankles, or abdomen  
• High cholesterol and other blood-fat abnormalities  
• A tendency toward blood clots and infections

MAIN CAUSES  

A. Primary (the kidney itself is the main target)  
1. Minimal-change disease – most common in children; often responds well to steroids  
2. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)  
3. Membranous nephropathy  
4. Less common primary glomerulonephritides

B. Secondary (part of another condition)  
1. Diabetes mellitus (diabetic kidney disease)  
2. Systemic lupus erythematosus and other autoimmune diseases  
3. Infections – hepatitis B or C, HIV, malaria, syphilis, COVID-19, etc.  
4. Certain drugs – NSAIDs, lithium, some antibiotics, interferon, bisphosphonates, heroin  
5. Allergic reactions, bee stings, vaccinations (rare)  
6. Cancers – lymphomas, solid tumors  
7. Genetic / congenital defects in the filtration barrier (seen in some infants)

IS IT CURABLE?  

Whether nephrotic syndrome can be “cured” depends on the cause:

• Minimal-change disease: often goes into complete remission with corticosteroids or other immune-modulating drugs.  
• Membranous nephropathy and FSGS: may respond partially or completely to steroids, calcineurin inhibitors (cyclosporine, tacrolimus), rituximab, or other immunosuppressants. Some cases progress despite therapy.  
• Diabetic kidney disease: controlling blood sugar, blood pressure, and using certain medications (ACE inhibitors or ARBs, SGLT2 inhibitors) can slow or halt progression, but the underlying diabetes remains.  
• Lupus nephritis: immunosuppressive therapy (mycophenolate, cyclophosphamide, rituximab, belimumab) can bring prolonged remission.  
• Infection-related or drug-induced cases: treating the infection or stopping the offending drug may completely resolve the syndrome.  
• Genetic / congenital forms: no definitive cure; supportive treatment and, if kidney failure develops, dialysis or transplant.

GENERAL TREATMENT MEASURES  (usually coordinated by a nephrologist)

1. Control protein leakage and blood pressure  
   • ACE inhibitors (lisinopril, enalapril) or ARBs (losartan, valsartan)  
   • SGLT2 inhibitors in diabetic or nondiabetic patients (dapagliflozin, empagliflozin)  

2. Reduce swelling (edema)  
   • Low-salt diet, sometimes fluid restriction  
   • Diuretics (furosemide, torsemide; add metolazone or spironolactone if needed)  
   • Careful daily weight and leg elevation  

3. Lower cholesterol and triglycerides  
   • Statins, fibrates, lifestyle changes  

4. Prevent blood clots  
   • Walking/movement, support stockings; some high-risk patients receive a blood thinner (warfarin, apixaban)  

5. Prevent and treat infections  
   • Vaccinations (pneumococcal, flu, hepatitis B)  
   • Prompt antibiotics if an infection starts  

6. Adequate—but not excessive—protein intake  
   • A dietitian can individualize protein and calorie needs  

7. Monitor kidney function  
   • Regular urine protein checks, blood tests (creatinine, eGFR), and blood pressure readings  

WHEN KIDNEY FUNCTION DECLINES  
If scarring progresses to end-stage kidney disease, options are dialysis or kidney transplantation.  Transplanted kidneys can also develop recurrence of some primary diseases, but many patients do well long-term.

TAKE-HOME POINTS  
• Nephrotic syndrome is a sign that the kidney’s filters are damaged.  
• Pinpointing the underlying cause (often by blood tests, urine tests, imaging, and kidney biopsy) guides treatment.  
• Many children and a fair number of adults go into full remission; others can have their disease controlled or

<gold_response>
What causes Nephrotic syndrome?: Nephrotic syndrome is caused by different disorders that damage the kidneys. This damage leads to the release of too much protein in the urine. The most common cause in children is minimal change disease. Membranous glomerulonephritis is the most common cause in adults.In both diseases, the glomeruli in the kidneys are damaged. Glomeruli are the structures that help filter wastes and fluids. This condition can also occur from: - Cancer - Diseases such as diabetes, systemic lupus erythematosus, multiple myeloma, and amyloidosis - Genetic disorders - Immune disorders - Infections (such as strep throat, hepatitis, or mononucleosis) - Use of certain drugs It can occur with kidney disorders such as: - Focal and segmental glomerulosclerosis - Glomerulonephritis - Mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis Nephrotic syndrome can affect all age groups. In children, it is most common between ages 2 and 6. This disorder occurs slightly more often in males than females.
</gold_response>
