predicted_text:
How would a person—or the parent of a child—realize that night-blindness is present from birth rather than caused later by injury, nutritional problems, or another eye disease?  The key points are:

1. Typical timing  
• “Congenital” means the problem is present at birth, although it may not be recognized until the first situations that require vision in dim light (evening play, camping, school sleep-overs, etc.).  
• Most families notice something is wrong in early childhood (ages 2-6). A child with congenital night blindness usually shows no difficulty in normal daylight; the first signs appear only when the lights are low.

2. Day-to-day clues  
• The child (or adult) cannot see, or sees very poorly, at dusk, in movie theaters, during power outages, or in poorly lit classrooms.  
• Hesitation, clinging to a parent, or bumping into furniture when lights are turned off.  
• Reluctance to play hide-and-seek in dim rooms, or fear of going outside at night when siblings and friends have no problem.  
• Needing a flashlight or phone light to move around even when others don’t.  
• In adults, lifelong statements such as “I’ve never been able to see in the dark,” predating any other eye trouble.

3. What is (and is not) seen on routine eye exams  
• Daylight (photopic) visual acuity is usually normal or near-normal.  
• The front of the eye and the retina often look normal with a basic exam, so standard school vision screenings may miss the condition.  
• Myopia (nearsightedness), nystagmus (eye wobble), or strabismus (eye turn) may coexist in some inherited forms but are not always present.

4. Confirming the diagnosis  
Only an eye-care professional can tell you for sure. Diagnosis may include:  
• Dark-adaptation testing: measures how quickly and how well the eye adjusts to the dark.  
• Electroretinography (ERG): records the electrical response of the retina to light and can pinpoint rod-cell malfunction typical of congenital stationary night blindness (CSNB).  
• Genetic testing: many cases are linked to mutations in genes such as NYX, CACNA1F, GRM6, etc.  
• Full retinal examination to rule out progressive disorders (e.g., retinitis pigmentosa) that can also start with night-vision problems but worsen over time.

5. Why the timing matters  
• “Congenital stationary night blindness” is usually non-progressive—once diagnosed, the dim-light problem remains but daytime vision stays stable.  
• Progressive conditions that also start with night-blindness (e.g., retinitis pigmentosa or vitamin A deficiency) get worse over years. An eye-care professional distinguishes between the two.

6. What to do if you suspect it  
• Keep a log of situations where you or your child cannot see in low light.  
• Schedule a comprehensive dilated eye exam with an ophthalmologist (ideally one who specializes in retinal or inherited eye diseases).  
• Mention any family history of similar problems or of consanguinity (parents related by blood), as this can guide testing.  
• Ask whether an ERG or genetic panel is appropriate.  
• Discuss practical steps: carrying a small flashlight, installing night-lights, higher contrast markings on stairs, and education accommodations if needed.

Bottom line  
You “know” you have congenital night blindness when difficulty seeing in low-light settings has been present since the earliest occasions it could be tested, other parts of vision are relatively normal, and an eye-care professional confirms non-progressive rod dysfunction (often via ERG or genetic testing). If you see these signs, book an ophthalmology appointment; only formal testing can separate congenital stationary night blindness from progressive or treatable causes of poor night vision.

<gold_response>
autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness: Autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness is a disorder of the retina, which is the specialized tissue at the back of the eye that detects light and color. People with this condition typically have difficulty seeing and distinguishing objects in low light (night blindness). For example, they may not be able to identify road signs at night or see stars in the night sky. They also often have other vision problems, including loss of sharpness (reduced acuity), nearsightedness (myopia), involuntary movements of the eyes (nystagmus), and eyes that do not look in the same direction (strabismus). The vision problems associated with this condition are congenital, which means they are present from birth. They tend to remain stable (stationary) over time. Autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness is likely a rare disease; however, its prevalence is unknown. Mutations in several genes can cause autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness. Each of these genes provide instructions for making proteins that are found in the retina. These proteins are involved in sending (transmitting) visual signals from cells called rods, which are specialized for vision in low light, to cells called bipolar cells, which relay the signals to other retinal cells. This signaling is an essential step in the transmission of visual information from the eyes to the brain. Mutations in two genes, GRM6 and TRPM1, cause most cases of this condition. These genes provide instructions for making proteins that are necessary for bipolar cells to receive and relay signals. Mutations in other genes involved in the same bipolar cell signaling pathway are likely responsible for a small percentage of cases of autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness. Gene mutations that cause autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness disrupt the transmission of visual signals between rod cells and bipolar cells or interfere with the bipolar cells' ability to pass on these signals. As a result, visual information received by rod cells cannot be effectively transmitted to the brain, leading to difficulty seeing in low light. The cause of the other vision problems associated with this condition is unclear. It has been suggested that the mechanisms that underlie night blindness can interfere with other visual systems, causing myopia, reduced visual acuity, and other impairments. Some people with autosomal recessive congenital stationary night blindness have no identified mutation in any of the known genes. The cause of the disorder in these individuals is unknown. This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations. The parents of an individual with an autosomal recessive condition each carry one copy of the mutated gene, but they typically do not show signs and symptoms of the condition. predicted_text:
Oleander (Nerium oleander) contains potent “cardiac-glycoside” poisons (oleandrin, neriine, etc.).  Illness develops only if enough of those chemicals actually get into the mouth and are swallowed.  What matters, therefore, is the dose:

1. Touching the inside of a freshly-broken stem can leave a tiny film of sap on the fingers (usually a few milligrams or less).  
2. If you immediately pick up food and eat without washing, some of that sap may be transferred to the food and swallowed, but the amount is generally far smaller than if you had chewed part of a leaf, flower or stem.  

HOW FAST COULD SYMPTOMS START?  
• Small-dose (trace) exposures – the kind most likely from fingertip transfer – typically cause no symptoms at all. If they do, the first signs are gastrointestinal and usually appear within 30 minutes to about 4 hours (nausea, metallic taste, stomach cramps, vomiting or diarrhea).  
• Larger, clearly toxic oral doses (a piece of leaf, tea made from the plant, etc.) can cause GI symptoms in the same 30 min–4 h window, followed by dangerous heart-rhythm changes, dizziness, fainting, or seizures 4–24 hours after ingestion.  

HOW BAD COULD IT GET?  
• With only trace contamination from sap on the hands, severe poisoning is very unlikely; most people either remain completely well or experience only mild, brief stomach upset or mouth irritation.  
• Serious toxicity—slow or irregular heartbeat, severe vomiting, confusion, high potassium, possible death—requires a much larger dose (roughly ≥½–1 leaf for a child or ≥2–3 leaves for an adult, though even less can be dangerous).  

WHAT TO WATCH FOR DURING THE FIRST 24 HOURS  
• Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, excessive salivation  
• Visual disturbances, dizziness, marked fatigue  
• Slow pulse (<60/min) or rapid irregular pulse, palpitations, fainting  
• Severe diarrhea or persistent vomiting  

WHAT TO DO NOW  
1. If the exposure was only through casual finger contact and you feel well, wash hands thoroughly with soap and water and observe for at least 6–8 hours.  
2. If any of the warning symptoms above occur—even mild gastrointestinal upset—call your local Poison Control center (U.S. 1-800-222-1222) or seek medical attention immediately; tell them it may be oleander.  
3. Do not induce vomiting or take “home remedies” unless advised by poison-control or a clinician.  
4. In the future, always wash hands after handling oleander and keep the plant (fresh or dried) away from children, pets, and food preparation areas.  

BOTTOM LINE  
After mere fingertip transfer, most people remain symptom-free; if anything develops it usually does so within the first few hours and is mild. Nevertheless, oleander is one of the more dangerous garden plants, so any suspected ingestion warrants caution and a phone call to Poison Control or a healthcare provider.

<gold_response>
Oleander poisoning: Oleander poisoning occurs when someone eats the flowers or chews the leaves or stems of the oleander plant (Nerium oleander), or its relative, the yellow oleander (Cascabela thevetia). This article is for information only. DO NOT use it to treat or manage an actual poison exposure. If you or someone you are with has an exposure, call your local emergency number (such as 911), or your local poison center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States. Poisonous ingredients include: - Digitoxigenin - Neriin - Oleandrin - Oleondroside Note: This list may not include all poisonous ingredients. The poisonous substances are found in all parts of the oleander plant: - Flowers - Leaves - Stems - Twigs Oleander poisoning can affect many parts of the body. HEART AND BLOOD - Irregular or slow heartbeat - Low blood pressure - Weakness EYES, EARS, NOSE, MOUTH, AND THROAT - Blurred vision - Vision disturbances, including halos STOMACH AND INTESTINES - Diarrhea - Loss of appetite - Nausea and vomiting - Stomach pain NERVOUS SYSTEM - Confusion - Death - Depression - Disorientation - Dizziness - Drowsiness - Fainting - Headache - Lethargy SKIN - Hives - Rash Note: Depression, loss of appetite, and halos are most often seen in chronic overdose cases. Seek immediate medical help. DO NOT make a person throw up unless told to do so by poison control or a health care provider. Get the following information: - Person's age, weight, and condition - Name and part of the plant swallowed, if known - Time it was swallowed - Amount swallowed Your local poison center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States. This hotline number will let you talk to experts in poisoning. They will give you further instructions. This is a free and confidential service. All local poison control centers in the United States use this national number. You should call if you have any questions about poisoning or poison prevention. It does not need to be an emergency. You can call for any reason, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. The provider will measure and monitor the person's vital signs, including temperature, pulse, breathing rate, and blood pressure. Symptoms will be treated as appropriate. The person may receive: - Activated charcoal - Blood and urine tests - Breathing support - Chest x-ray - EKG (electrocardiogram, or heart tracing) - Fluids through a vein (IV) - Medicines to treat symptoms including an antidote to reverse the effects of the poison - Tube through the mouth into the stomach to wash out the stomach (gastric lavage) How well you do depends on the amount of poison swallowed and how quickly treatment is received. The faster you get medical help, the better the chance for recovery. Symptoms last for 1 to 3 days and may require a hospital stay. Death is unlikely. DO NOT touch or eat any plant with which you are not familiar. Wash your hands after working in the garden or walking in the woods. Updated by: Jesse Borke, MD, FACEP, FAAEM, Attending Physician at FDR Medical Services/Millard Fillmore Suburban Hospital, Buffalo, NY. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team. Editorial update 10/26/2016.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
“Optic atrophy” (sometimes called optic neuropathy) means that the optic nerve, the cable that carries visual information from the eye to the brain, has been damaged and its fibres have wasted away (“atrophied”).  The condition can be caused by many different problems—some inherited and some acquired—so it is not automatically “genetic,” although several well-known hereditary forms do exist.

1. Hereditary (genetic) forms  
   • Dominant optic atrophy (Kjer type) – usually shows up in childhood; caused most often by mutations in the OPA1 gene.  
   • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) – sudden, painless loss of central vision in young adults; due to mutations in mitochondrial DNA.  
   • Recessive optic atrophy, optic atrophy associated with Wolfram syndrome (WFS1 gene), OPA3-related disease, and other rare syndromes.  
   • In these hereditary types, the pattern of inheritance (autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, or mitochondrial) determines the chance that other family members might be affected.

2. Non-genetic (acquired) causes  
   • Poor blood supply to the optic nerve (ischemic optic neuropathy, severe anemia, stroke to the nerve’s blood supply).  
   • Inflammation/infection: optic neuritis (often linked to multiple sclerosis), syphilis, Lyme disease, tuberculosis, viral infections, etc.  
   • Pressure or compression: brain or orbital tumors, aneurysms, enlarged blood vessels, hydrocephalus, thyroid eye disease.  
   • Trauma: head or eye injuries.  
   • Toxic / nutritional: methanol (wood alcohol) poisoning, certain medications (e.g., ethambutol, amiodarone, chloramphenicol, linezolid), vitamin B-12 deficiency, severe malnutrition.  
   • Elevated eye pressure (advanced glaucoma).  
   • Other neurological or systemic disorders (sarcoidosis, neuromyelitis optica, mitochondrial or metabolic diseases).

Key points to remember  
• Optic atrophy is a sign, not a single disease. Pinpointing the underlying cause is crucial for prognosis, treatment, and family counseling.  
• An eye-care professional (ophthalmologist or neuro-ophthalmologist) usually orders blood tests, imaging (MRI/CT), visual-field testing, and sometimes genetic testing to sort out the cause.  
• In many inherited forms, no cure exists yet, but low-vision aids, protection of remaining vision, and genetic counseling can help.  
• Some acquired causes (inflammation, infection, nutritional deficiency, compression, toxin exposure, glaucoma) can be treated or halted if detected early.

If you or a family member has been told you have optic atrophy, ask your eye specialist whether a genetic work-up or referral to a neuro-ophthalmologist or genetic counselor is appropriate, and whether any treatable underlying conditions have been ruled out.

“Optic atrophy” (sometimes called optic neuropathy) means that the optic nerve, the cable that carries visual information from the eye to the brain, has been damaged and its fibres have wasted away (“atrophied”).  The condition can be caused by many different problems—some inherited and some acquired—so it is not automatically “genetic,” although several well-known hereditary forms do exist.

1. Hereditary (genetic) forms  
   • Dominant optic atrophy (Kjer type) – usually shows up in childhood; caused most often by mutations in the OPA1 gene.  
   • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) – sudden, painless loss of central vision in young adults; due to mutations in mitochondrial DNA.  
   • Recessive optic atrophy, optic atrophy associated with Wolfram syndrome (WFS1 gene), OPA3-related disease, and other rare syndromes.  
   • In these hereditary types, the pattern of inheritance (autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, or mitochondrial) determines the chance that other family members might be affected.

2. Non-genetic (acquired) causes  
   • Poor blood supply to the optic nerve (ischemic optic neuropathy, severe anemia, stroke to the nerve’s blood supply).  
   • Inflammation/infection: optic neuritis (often linked to multiple sclerosis), syphilis, Lyme disease, tuberculosis, viral infections, etc.  
   • Pressure or compression: brain or orbital tumors, aneurysms, enlarged blood vessels, hydrocephalus, thyroid eye disease.  
   • Trauma: head or eye injuries.  
   • Toxic / nutritional: methanol (wood alcohol) poisoning, certain medications (e.g., ethambutol, amiodarone, chloramphenicol, linezolid), vitamin B-12 deficiency, severe malnutrition.  
   • Elevated eye pressure (advanced glaucoma).  
   • Other neurological or systemic disorders (sarcoidosis, neuromyelitis optica, mitochondrial or metabolic diseases).

Key points to remember  
• Optic atrophy is a sign, not a single disease. Pinpointing the underlying cause is crucial for prognosis, treatment, and family counseling.

• Some acquired causes (inflammation, infection, nutritional deficiency, compression, toxin exposure, glaucoma) can be treated or halted if detected early.

If you or a family member has been told you have optic atrophy, ask your eye specialist whether a genetic work-up or referral to a neuro-ophthalmologist or genetic counselor is appropriate, and whether any treatable underlying conditions have been ruled out.
</response>

Optic nerve atrophy: Optic nerve atrophy is damage to the optic nerve. The optic nerve carries images of what the eye sees to the brain. There are many causes of optic atrophy. The most common is poor blood flow. This is called ischemic optic neuropathy. The problem most often affects older adults. The optic nerve can also be damaged by shock, toxins, radiation, and trauma. Eye diseases, such as glaucoma, can also cause a form of optic nerve atrophy. The condition can also be caused by diseases of the brain and central nervous system. These may include: - Brain tumor - Cranial arteritis (sometimes called temporal arteritis) - Multiple sclerosis - Stroke There are also rare forms of hereditary optic nerve atrophy that affect children and young adults. Optic nerve atrophy causes vision to dim and reduces the field of vision. The ability to see fine detail will also be lost. Colors will seem faded. Over time, the pupil will be less able to react to light, and eventually, its ability to react to light may be lost. The health care provider will do a complete eye exam to look for the condition. The exam will include tests of: - Color vision - Pupil light reflex - Tonometry - Visual acuity You may also need a complete physical exam and other tests. Damage from optic nerve atrophy cannot be reversed. The underlying disease must be found and treated. Otherwise, vision loss will continue. Rarely, conditions that lead to optic atrophy may be treatable. Vision lost to optic nerve atrophy cannot be recovered. It is very important to protect the other eye. People with this condition need to be checked regularly by an eye doctor with experience in nerve-related conditions. Tell your doctor right away about any change in vision. Many causes of optic nerve atrophy cannot be prevented. Prevention steps include: - Older adults should have their provider carefully manage their blood pressure. - Use standard safety precautions to prevent injuries to the face. Most facial injuries are the result of car accidents. Wearing seat belts may help prevent these injuries. - Schedule a routine annual eye exam to check for glaucoma. - Never drink home-brewed alcohol and forms of alcohol that are not intended for drinking. Methanol, which is found in home-brewed alcohol, can cause optic nerve atrophy in both eyes. Updated by: Franklin W. Lusby, MD, ophthalmologist, Lusby Vision Institute, La Jolla, CA. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.
</gold_response>

Yes.  Over the last 20 years several large studies have followed healthy people who later developed rheumatoid arthritis (RA).  From these studies we have learned that

1. Blood-test changes often precede any obvious joint disease  
   • Swedish blood-bank study (Rantapää-Dahlqvist et al., Arthritis & Rheumatism 2003): rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-cyclic-citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP/ACPA) antibodies were found up to 9 years (average 4–5 years) before the first swollen joint.  
   • Dutch cohort (van de Stadt et al., 2011): anti-CCP present a median of 4 years before symptoms; antibody levels rose as the first symptoms approached.  
   • U.S. military serum repository (Deane et al., 2010): ACPA and certain cytokines were detectable 3–10 years before arthritis began.

2. Very early “general” symptoms can appear months to a few years before true arthritis  
   • Prospective “clinically suspect arthralgia” cohorts (Burgers et al., 2017; van Steenbergen et al., 2018) showed that people who eventually developed RA often reported fatigue, vague hand or foot pain, and morning stiffness lasting ≥60 minutes a median of 3 years before any doctor could see swollen joints.

3. The first definite joint signs usually evolve quickly  
   • In most modern “early RA” clinics the time from the first objectively swollen joint to a firm diagnosis is only a few weeks to months, but by then the person may describe subtle stiffness or fatigue that started 6–12 months earlier.

4. Age of onset  
   • Classic RA most often begins between ages 30 and 60, but adult-onset disease can begin in the 20s and late 70s, and a separate condition—juvenile idiopathic (formerly “juvenile RA”)—can start in childhood.

What this means for you
• A completely healthy-feeling person can already have RA-related antibodies in the blood many years before joints are affected.  
• The very earliest bodily clues are usually nonspecific—tiredness, low-grade fever, vague achiness, or short-lived stiffness in the hands or feet on waking.  
• Once the immune reaction reaches the joints, persistent morning stiffness (≥30 min), swelling, warmth and symmetrical pain in the small joints of the hands, wrists or feet are typical first “visible” signs.  
• Because early treatment can stop or slow joint damage, anyone who notices these early joint symptoms for more than 3–4 weeks should be evaluated promptly by a physician (preferably a rheumatologist).

Key references you can look up or show your doctor
• Rantapää-Dahlqvist S, et al. Antibodies against cyclic citrullinated peptide and IgA RF predict the development of RA up to 9 years before symptom onset. Arthritis Rheum. 2003.  
• van de Stadt LA, et al. The serological and clinical onset of RA: a 4-year prospective study. Ann Rheum Dis. 2011.  
• Deane KD, et al. The number of elevated cytokines and chemokines in pre-clinical RA predicts time to diagnosis. Ann Rheum Dis. 2010.  
• Burgers LE, et al. Identifying clinically suspect arthralgia in the general population: characteristics and risk of progression to RA. Arthritis Res Ther. 2017.

In short, research shows that immunologic changes can be detected up to a decade before the first swollen joint, while vague symptoms such as fatigue or morning stiffness often surface months to a few years before definite rheumatoid arthritis appears.

The reference answer will be provided in these tags:
<gold_response>
Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder that can affect more than just your joints. In some people, the condition also can damage a wide variety of body systems, including the skin, eyes, lungs, heart and blood vessels. An autoimmune disorder, rheumatoid arthritis occurs when your immune system mistakenly attacks your own body's tissues. Unlike the wear-and-tear damage of osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis affects the lining of your joints, causing a painful swelling that can eventually result in bone erosion and joint deformity. The inflammation associated with rheumatoid arthritis is what can damage other parts of the body as well. While new types of medications have improved treatment options dramatically, severe rheumatoid arthritis can still cause physical disabilities. Signs and symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis may include: - Tender, warm, swollen joints - Joint stiffness that is usually worse in the mornings and after inactivity - Fatigue, fever and weight loss Early rheumatoid arthritis tends to affect your smaller joints first - particularly the joints that attach your fingers to your hands and your toes to your feet. As the disease progresses, symptoms often spread to the wrists, knees, ankles, elbows, hips and shoulders. In most cases, symptoms occur in the same joints on both sides of your body. About 40 percent of the people who have rheumatoid arthritis also experience signs and symptoms that don't involve the joints. Rheumatoid arthritis can affect many nonjoint structures, including: - Skin - Eyes - Lungs - Heart - Kidneys - Salivary glands - Nerve tissue - Bone marrow - Blood vessels Rheumatoid arthritis signs and symptoms may vary in severity and may even come and go. Periods of increased disease activity, called flares, alternate with periods of relative remission - when the swelling and pain fade or disappear. Over time, rheumatoid arthritis can cause joints to deform and shift out of place. Make an appointment with your doctor if you have persistent discomfort and swelling in your joints. Rheumatoid arthritis occurs when your immune system attacks the synovium - the lining of the membranes that surround your joints. The resulting inflammation thickens the synovium, which can eventually destroy the cartilage and bone within the joint. The tendons and ligaments that hold the joint together weaken and stretch. Gradually, the joint loses its shape and alignment. Doctors don't know what starts this process, although a genetic component appears likely. While your genes don't actually cause rheumatoid arthritis, they can make you more susceptible to environmental factors - such as infection with certain viruses and bacteria - that may trigger the disease. Factors that may increase your risk of rheumatoid arthritis include: - Your sex. Women are more likely than men to develop rheumatoid arthritis. - Age. Rheumatoid arthritis can occur at any age, but it most commonly begins between the ages of 40 and 60. - Family history. If a member of your family has rheumatoid arthritis, you may have an increased risk of the disease. - Smoking. Cigarette smoking increases your risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis, particularly if you have a genetic predisposition for developing the disease. Smoking also appears to be associated with greater disease severity. - Environmental exposures. Although uncertain and poorly understood, some exposures such as asbestos or silica may increase the risk for developing rheumatoid arthritis. Emergency workers exposed to dust from the collapse of the World Trade Center are at higher risk of autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis. - Obesity. People who are overweight or obese appear to be at somewhat higher risk of developing rheumatoid arthritis, especially in women diagnosed with the disease when they were 55 or younger. Rheumatoid arthritis can be difficult to diagnose in its early stages because the early signs and symptoms mimic those of many other diseases. There is no one blood test or physical finding to confirm the diagnosis. During the physical exam, your doctor will check your joints for swelling, redness and warmth. He or she may also check your reflexes and muscle strength. Blood tests People with rheumatoid arthritis often have an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR, or sed rate) or C-reactive protein (CRP), which may indicate the presence of an inflammatory process in the body. Other common blood tests look for rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies. Imaging tests Your doctor may recommend X-rays to help track the progression of rheumatoid arthritis in your joints over time. MRI and ultrasound tests can help your doctor judge the severity of the disease in your body. There is no cure for rheumatoid arthritis. But recent discoveries indicate that remission of symptoms is more likely when treatment begins early with strong medications known as disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). Medications The types of medications recommended by your doctor will depend on the severity of your symptoms and how long you've had rheumatoid arthritis. - NSAIDs. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can relieve pain and reduce inflammation. Over-the-counter NSAIDs include ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB) and naproxen sodium (Aleve). Stronger NSAIDs are available by prescription. Side effects may include ringing in your ears, stomach irritation, heart problems, and liver and kidney damage. - Steroids. Corticosteroid medications, such as prednisone, reduce inflammation and pain and slow joint damage. Side effects may include thinning of bones, weight gain and diabetes. Doctors often prescribe a corticosteroid to relieve acute symptoms, with the goal of gradually tapering off the medication. - Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). These drugs can slow the progression of rheumatoid arthritis and save the joints and other tissues from permanent damage. Common DMARDs include methotrexate (Trexall, Otrexup, Rasuvo), leflunomide (Arava), hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil) and sulfasalazine (Azulfidine). Side effects vary but may include liver damage, bone marrow suppression and severe lung infections. - Biologic agents. Also known as biologic response modifiers, this newer class of DMARDs includes abatacept (Orencia), adalimumab (Humira), anakinra (Kineret), certolizumab (Cimzia), etanercept (Enbrel), golimumab (Simponi), infliximab (Remicade), rituximab (Rituxan), tocilizumab (Actemra) and tofacitinib (Xeljanz). These drugs can target parts of the immune system that trigger inflammation that causes joint and tissue damage. These types of drugs also increase the risk of infections. Biologic DMARDs are usually most effective when paired with a nonbiologic DMARD, such as methotrexate. Therapy Your doctor may send you to a physical or occupational therapist who can teach you exercises to help keep your joints flexible. The therapist may also suggest new ways to do daily tasks, which will be easier on your joints. For example, if your fingers are sore, you may want to pick up an object using your forearms. Assistive devices can make it easier to avoid stressing your painful joints. For instance, a kitchen knife equipped with a saw handle helps protect your finger and wrist joints. Certain tools, such as buttonhooks, can make it easier to get dressed. Catalogs and medical supply stores are good places to look for ideas. Surgery If medications fail to prevent or slow joint damage, you and your doctor may consider surgery to repair damaged joints. Surgery may help restore your ability to use your joint. It can also reduce pain and correct deformities. Rheumatoid arthritis surgery may involve one or more of the following procedures: - Synovectomy. Surgery to remove the inflamed synovium (lining of the joint). Synovectomy can be performed on knees, elbows, wrists, fingers and hips. - Tendon repair. Inflammation and joint damage may cause tendons around your joint to loosen or rupture. Your surgeon may be able to repair the tendons around your joint. - Joint fusion. Surgically fusing a joint may be recommended to stabilize or realign a joint and for pain relief when a joint replacement isn't an option. - Total joint replacement. During joint replacement surgery, your surgeon removes the damaged parts of your joint and inserts a prosthesis made of metal and plastic. Surgery carries a risk of bleeding, infection and pain. Discuss the benefits and risks with your doctor. You can take steps to care for your body if you have rheumatoid arthritis. These self-care measures, when used along with your rheumatoid arthritis medications, can help you manage your signs and symptoms: - Exercise regularly. Gentle exercise can help strengthen the muscles around your joints, and it can help fight fatigue you might feel. Check with your doctor before you start exercising. If you're just getting started, begin by taking a walk. Try swimming or gentle water aerobics. Avoid exercising tender, injured or severely inflamed joints. - Apply heat or cold. Heat can help ease your pain and relax tense, painful muscles. Cold may dull the sensation of pain. Cold also has a numbing effect and decreases muscle spasms. - Relax. Find ways to cope with pain by reducing stress in your life. Techniques such as guided imagery, distraction and muscle relaxation can all be used to control pain. Some common complementary and alternative treatments that have shown promise for rheumatoid arthritis include: - Fish oil. Some preliminary studies have found that fish oil supplements may reduce rheumatoid arthritis pain and stiffness. Side effects can include nausea, belching and a fishy taste in the mouth. Fish oil can interfere with medications, so check with your doctor first. - Plant oils. The seeds of evening primrose, borage and black currant contain a type of fatty acid that may help with rheumatoid arthritis pain and morning stiffness. Side effects may include nausea, diarrhea and gas. Some plant oils can cause liver damage or interfere with medications, so check with your doctor first. - Tai chi. This movement therapy involves gentle exercises and stretches combined with deep breathing. Many people use tai chi to relieve stress in their lives. Small studies have found that tai chi may reduce rheumatoid arthritis pain. When led by a knowledgeable instructor, tai chi is safe. But don't do any moves that cause pain.
</gold_response>

Even without a known family history, a woman can still develop PCOS. Factors that can “unmask” or worsen the hormonal imbalance include:  
•  Insulin resistance and weight gain/obesity  
•  Inactivity and high-calorie/high-sugar diets  
•  Certain prenatal or early-life exposures that affect hormone signaling  
•  Possibly some environmental/endocrine-disrupting chemicals (research is ongoing)

•  It is not contagious—you cannot “catch” it from someone.  
•  It is not caused by one behavior or by using birth-control pills.

The condition usually results from an underlying genetic susceptibility combined with lifestyle and metabolic factors such as insulin resistance and excess weight. If you have PCOS or a strong family history, maintaining a healthy weight, regular physical activity and periodic medical check-ups can help lower the risk of complications. Always discuss personal concerns and screening with your health-care provider.

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (Summary): Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) is a health problem that can affect a woman's menstrual cycle, ability to have children, hormones , heart, blood vessels, and appearance. Women with this condition typically have high levels of  hormones called androgens, missed or irregular periods, and many small cysts in their ovaries. The cause of PCOS is unknown, but probably involves a combination of genetic and environmental factors . Treatment for PCOS may involve birth control pills and medications for diabetes and infertility. Medicines called anti-androgens are also used to speed the growth of hair and clear acne. [1] [2]

I’m sorry you’re having to worry about this.  Below is a plain-language overview of what polymicrogyria (PMG) means, what it usually does — and, just as important, what it does NOT do.

1.  What polymicrogyria is  
   • During pregnancy the cerebral cortex folds abnormally, creating many small, shallow gyri (“polymicro-gyria”).  
   • That “mis-folding” is a structural change; it is present at birth and does not progress or reverse.  
   • Think of it like the wiring in a house that was installed differently while the house was being built; once the walls go up, the wiring layout stays the same.

2.  Does the brain ever “grow out of it”?  
   • The abnormal folds themselves do not straighten out or turn into a typical pattern later on.  
   • HOWEVER, the brain is remarkably plastic, especially in the first few years of life.  Even though the physical structure won’t change, other parts of the brain can learn to take over or support functions.  
   • So children with milder or localized PMG can continue to gain new skills.  Improvement is expected, but it happens through compensation and therapy, not by the cortex “becoming normal.”

3.  Why some children are far more affected than others  
   • The outcome depends on:  
     – How much cortex is involved (focal vs. widespread).  
     – Which areas are involved (motor strip, language areas, etc.).  
     – Whether other brain problems or genetic syndromes are present.  
   • Because of that, severity ranges from minimal motor delay all the way to severe physical and intellectual disability plus epilepsy.

4.  Typical developmental picture  
   • Motor: low muscle tone (hypotonia), late sitting/crawling/walking, sometimes spasticity.  
   • Speech/language: may be delayed, but many children eventually speak.  
   • Seizures: 50–90 % develop some form of epilepsy, often controllable with medication.  
   • Learning/intellect: from normal to moderate impairment; again it depends on extent/location.

5.  What helps  
   • Early-intervention physical, occupational and speech therapy are the best-proven ways to maximize skills.  
   • Regular neurologic follow-up to watch for seizures or tight/stiff muscles.  
   • If epilepsy appears, aggressive seizure control helps brain development.  
   • Vision and hearing testing, because subtle deficits worsen motor and language delays if missed.

6.  Practical outlook for your son (based on what you’ve shared)  
   • Not sitting at 16 months is a delay, but gaining hand use and interest in moving are good signs.  
   • Many children with similar starts do learn to sit, crawl and even walk, usually on a later timetable.  
   • Language may follow the same “delayed but progressing” pattern.  
   • Expect gradual progress rather than suddenly “catching up overnight.”

7.  Questions to ask your child’s care team  
   • Exactly which brain regions show PMG on his MRI?  
   • Any sign of other malformations (corpus callosum, brainstem, etc.)?  
   • Has a genetic test or infection screen been done to look for an underlying cause?  
   • What early-intervention services can start now (PT, OT, speech)?  
   • How will you monitor for seizures, and what should I watch for at home?

8.  Red-flag symptoms that need urgent review  
   • Any staring spells, sudden stiffening, twitching or loss of awareness.  
   • Regression (loss of skills he already had).  
   • Feeding trouble or breathing changes.  
   • Rapid increase in head size or sudden change in muscle tone.

9.  Where to find support  
   • PMG Family Support/PMG Awareness Organization (online community, parent guides).  
   • Child Neurology Foundation, United Cerebral Palsy, local Early Intervention program.  
   • Meeting other families often helps set realistic but hopeful expectations.

Key point in one sentence: The abnormal folds won’t “grow back to normal,” but the condition is not degenerative, and with therapy and good medical care many children gain new motor, language and learning skills over time.

<gold_response>
Polymicrogyria: Polymicrogyria is a condition characterized by abnormal development of the brain before birth. Specifically, the surface of the brain develops too many folds which are unusually small. The signs and symptoms associated with the condition vary based on how much of the brain and which areas of the brain are affected; however, affected people may experience recurrent seizures ( epilepsy ); delayed development; crossed eyes ; problems with speech and swallowing; and muscle weakness or paralysis. Bilateral forms (affecting both sides of the brain) tend to cause more severe neurological problems. Polymicrogyria can result from both genetic and environmental causes. It may occur as an isolated finding or as part of a syndrome . Treatment is based on the signs and symptoms present in each person. [1] [2] A wide variety of symptoms may be observed in people with polymicrogyria, depending on the areas of the brain implicated and whether or not it is part of a larger syndrome . Signs and symptoms may include: [3] [4] Developmental delay Crossed eyes Epilepsy Paralysis of the face, throat, and tongue Difficulty with speech and swallowing Drooling The diagnosis of polymicrogyria is made by imaging brain structures using  MRI . Typical findings include areas of the  cerebral cortex with a complex set of small gyri that appear fused to each other and separated by shallow sulci. These findings may be isolated to one side of the brain (unilateral) or may involve both sides of the brain (bilateral). [3] [4] The resources below provide information about treatment options for this condition. If you have questions about which treatment is right for you, talk to your healthcare professional. Management Guidelines GeneReviews provides current, expert-authored, peer-reviewed, full-text articles describing the application of genetic testing to the diagnosis, management, and genetic counseling of patients with specific inherited conditions. The following diseases are related to Polymicrogyria. If you have a question about any of these diseases, you can contact GARD. Bilateral frontal polymicrogyria Bilateral frontoparietal polymicrogyria Bilateral generalized polymicrogyria Bilateral parasagittal parieto-occipital polymicrogyria Bilateral perisylvian polymicrogyria
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Because the exact mechanism of pre-eclampsia is still uncertain, no strategy can guarantee that it will be prevented; however, research and clinical guidelines do point to several actions that clearly lower risk, are considered safe in pregnancy, or help detect the problem very early so it can be managed before it becomes dangerous.

1. Start pregnancy in the best possible health
   • Achieve a healthy body-mass index (BMI) before conception; obesity roughly doubles the risk.
   • Bring chronic illnesses—especially high blood pressure, diabetes, kidney disease and autoimmune disorders—under the best possible control prior to conception.
   • Stop smoking and limit alcohol; both independently raise the risk of placental problems.

2. Begin prenatal care early and keep every appointment
   • Regular blood-pressure checks and urine protein screening are still the single most important tools for catching pre-eclampsia early.
   • Report new headaches, visual changes, right-upper-quadrant/epigastric pain or sudden swelling promptly.

3. Low-dose aspirin, when recommended
   • Multiple randomized trials and meta-analyses show that 81 mg (sometimes 75–150 mg) aspirin taken once daily, started between 12–16 weeks and continued to 36 weeks, reduces the risk of pre-eclampsia by 10–25 % and the risk of severe/early-onset disease even more.
   • It is now recommended for women at high risk (previous pre-eclampsia, multifetal gestation, chronic hypertension, type 1 or 2 diabetes, kidney disease, autoimmune disease) or with more than one “moderate” risk factor (first pregnancy, obesity, age ≥35, family history, Black race).

4. Adequate calcium intake
   • In populations where baseline calcium intake is low (<600 mg/day), calcium supplementation (1–1.5 g/day, divided doses) beginning before 20 weeks lowers the risk of pre-eclampsia by about one-third.
   • If you already get 1,000 mg/day of calcium through food, extra supplementation has little added value—but making sure you reach that level is reasonable and safe.

5. Manage weight gain and stay active
   • Excessive gestational weight gain, especially early in pregnancy, increases risk. Follow the weight-gain targets set for your prepregnancy BMI.
   • Moderate exercise (e.g., 30 min brisk walking most days) is associated with a modest reduction in pre-eclampsia and generally improves blood-pressure control and glucose levels.

6. Control blood pressure throughout pregnancy
   • If you have chronic hypertension, use pregnancy-safe antihypertensives (labetalol, nifedipine, methyldopa) to keep BP <135/85 mm Hg (individual targets vary).
   • Home BP monitoring between office visits can pick up early rises.

7. Treat or screen for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) if suspected
   • OSA has been linked to higher pre-eclampsia rates. If you snore heavily, have witnessed apneas, excessive daytime sleepiness, or obesity, talk with your provider about evaluation.

8. Consider additional measures only under medical supervision
   • Heparin + low-dose aspirin for women with antiphospholipid syndrome or certain thrombophilias.
   • Vitamin D deficiency correction: evidence is mixed; supplementation to recommended dietary allowance (600 IU/day) is reasonable, megadoses are unproven.
   • Antioxidant vitamins C and E, folic-acid “megadoses,” garlic, fish oil, or rest-in-bed strategies have not convincingly prevented pre-eclampsia in trials and are not recommended solely for this purpose.

9. Plan spacing between pregnancies
   • Inter-pregnancy intervals <12 months or >5 years carry slightly higher risk; spacing pregnancies 18-48 months apart may lower risk.

10. Know your personal and family history
    • If you had pre-eclampsia before, risk is 15–20 % in future pregnancies (up to 30–40 % if it occurred early or was severe). Intensive monitoring, aspirin, and sometimes referral to a maternal–fetal medicine specialist are warranted.

Bottom line
You cannot remove every bit of risk, but you can tilt the odds in your favor by entering pregnancy healthy, keeping chronic conditions controlled, obtaining enough calcium, using low-dose aspirin if you qualify, staying active with appropriate weight gain, and attending all prenatal visits so any rise in blood pressure or other warning sign is caught and treated early. Always discuss individual recommendations with your obstetric provider before starting medications or supplements.

predicted_text:
Below is a short, plain-language guide that should cover the main facts your project asks about. Keep in mind that “leukemia” is really a family of different blood cancers, so every answer is a generalization; the exact details depend on the specific type (ALL, AML, CLL, CML, etc.) and on the individual patient.

1. What causes leukemia?
   • Leukemia starts when a single blood-forming cell in the bone marrow acquires a DNA change (mutation) that lets it grow out of control.  
   • Most of the time we do not know why that mutation happened.  
   • Known risk factors include: high-dose radiation, certain industrial chemicals (e.g., benzene), previous chemotherapy or radiation for another cancer, smoking, and some rare genetic conditions such as Down syndrome, Li-Fraumeni, and Fanconi anemia.  
   • For the great majority of patients it is NOT the result of something they did, and most cases are not inherited.

2. Can you survive leukemia?
   Yes. Cure or long-term control is now common for many forms:
   • Childhood ALL (acute lymphoblastic leukemia): cure rates > 90 %.  
   • CML (chronic myeloid leukemia) treated with daily pills called TKIs: most patients have a near-normal life span.  
   • AML (acute myeloid leukemia): cure rates are ~30–40 % in adults and > 60 % in children, with higher numbers if a stem-cell transplant is possible.  
   Outcome depends on leukemia type, age, overall health, and response to therapy.

3. How does leukemia affect your body?
   • The abnormal white blood cells (“blasts”) multiply in the bone marrow and crowd out normal cells.  
   • With fewer red cells → anemia → fatigue, shortness of breath.  
   • With fewer platelets → easy bruising or bleeding.  
   • With abnormal or too few functioning white cells → frequent or severe infections.  
   • The leukemic cells can accumulate in lymph nodes, spleen, liver, gums, skin, or brain, causing swelling or pain.

4. Is leukemia inherited?
   • The disease itself is almost never directly inherited.  
   • However, certain inherited syndromes (e.g., Down syndrome, Noonan syndrome, Li-Fraumeni) raise the risk.  
   • Very rarely more than one person in a family gets leukemia, but that is unusual.

5. What is “advanced” leukemia?
   • In the acute leukemias (ALL, AML): disease that has returned after treatment (relapsed) or that did not respond in the first place (refractory).  
   • In chronic leukemias (CLL, CML): a late “blast” phase when the disease begins to behave like an acute leukemia, or any stage where the leukemic burden is very high and organs are failing.

6. How long can someone with leukemia expect to live?
   This ranges from weeks (if an aggressive leukemia is untreated) to decades (for CML on modern drugs or cured ALL). Median survival figures:
   • Untreated acute leukemia: weeks–months.  
   • AML after modern therapy: 3–5 year survival about 30–40 % in adults.  
   • Childhood ALL: > 90 % 5-year survival, many cured for life.  
   • CML on TKIs: > 90 % 10-year survival; many live normal lifespans.  
   Remember: statistics describe groups, not individuals.

7. Can you tell if you have leukemia?
   • Early symptoms are vague—fatigue, fevers, night sweats, bruising, weight loss.  
   • The only way to know for sure is a blood count (CBC) and often a bone-marrow test ordered by a doctor.  
   • Because early changes can be subtle, most people are diagnosed only after a routine blood test or when symptoms push them to seek care.

8. What treatments are used?
   • Chemotherapy (given IV or pills) remains the backbone for most acute leukemias.  
   • Targeted therapy: tyrosine-kinase inhibitors such as imatinib, dasatinib, etc., for CML; FLT3, IDH, or BCL-2 inhibitors for some AMLs.  
   • Immunotherapy/biologics: monoclonal antibodies (e.g., blinatumomab), CAR-T cell therapy (esp. in relapsed ALL), checkpoint inhibitors in certain cases.  
   • Stem-cell (bone-marrow) transplant: used when risk of relapse is high or when first-line treatment fails.  
   • Radiation therapy is occasionally used for specific sites (e.g., brain or spleen) or before transplant.  
   • Supportive care: antibiotics, blood transfusions, growth factors, antivirals, antif

<gold_response>
Leukemia (Treatment): Treatment for your leukemia depends on many factors. Your doctor determines your leukemia treatment options based on your age and overall health, the type of leukemia you have, and whether it has spread to other parts of your body, including the central nervous system. Common treatments used to fight leukemia include: - Chemotherapy. Chemotherapy is the major form of treatment for leukemia. This drug treatment uses chemicals to kill leukemia cells. Depending on the type of leukemia you have, you may receive a single drug or a combination of drugs. These drugs may come in a pill form, or they may be injected directly into a vein. - Biological therapy. Biological therapy works by using treatments that help your immune system recognize and attack leukemia cells. - Targeted therapy. Targeted therapy uses drugs that attack specific vulnerabilities within your cancer cells. For example, the drug imatinib (Gleevec) stops the action of a protein within the leukemia cells of people with chronic myelogenous leukemia. This can help control the disease. - Radiation therapy. Radiation therapy uses X-rays or other high-energy beams to damage leukemia cells and stop their growth. During radiation therapy, you lie on a table while a large machine moves around you, directing the radiation to precise points on your body. You may receive radiation in one specific area of your body where there is a collection of leukemia cells, or you may receive radiation over your whole body. Radiation therapy may be used to prepare for a stem cell transplant. - Stem cell transplant. A stem cell transplant is a procedure to replace your diseased bone marrow with healthy bone marrow. Before a stem cell transplant, you receive high doses of chemotherapy or radiation therapy to destroy your diseased bone marrow. Then you receive an infusion of blood-forming stem cells that help to rebuild your bone marrow. You may receive stem cells from a donor, or in some cases you may be able to use your own stem cells. A stem cell transplant is very similar to a bone marrow transplant.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
I’m not able to diagnose or prescribe for you, but the following information will help you discuss a focused plan with your dermatologist or primary-care doctor.  

WHAT SCALP PSORIASIS IS  
• A chronic, immune-mediated skin condition that causes thick, red, scaly plaques.  
• The scalp is one of the most common sites; it may extend to the hairline, behind the ears, or down the neck.  
• Psoriasis is NOT contagious; flares usually come and go in response to triggers (stress, infection, weather, certain drugs, alcohol, smoking, obesity).

GENERAL PRINCIPLES OF CARE  
1. Reduce scale so medicine can penetrate (keratolysis).  
2. Apply anti-inflammatory or immune-modulating medication.  
3. Maintain remission with gentler, long-term agents and good scalp care.  
4. Treat the whole person: control triggers, manage stress, screen for joint pain (psoriatic arthritis), cardiovascular risk, depression.

TREATMENT OPTIONS TO DISCUSS WITH YOUR DOCTOR  

A. Over-the-Counter (OTC) Measures  
• Medicated shampoos 2–3×/week  
  – Coal tar 0.5–5 %  
  – Salicylic acid 2–6 % (helps lift scale)  
  – Ketoconazole 1 % (helps if there is overlapping seborrheic dermatitis)  
• Mineral or baby oil, coconut oil, or petroleum jelly massaged into plaques at night and covered with a shower cap to soften scale; shampoo out in the morning.  
• Thick emollients (petroleum jelly, CeraVe, Vanicream) on hairline and behind ears daily.

B. Prescription Topicals  
(Usually the first-line therapy for scalp disease)  
1. Potent to super-potent corticosteroids (e.g., clobetasol 0.05 % solution, foam, spray; betamethasone valerate 0.1 %) – used once or twice daily for up to 2–4 weeks, then tapered or pulsed to avoid thinning of skin or tachyphylaxis.  
2. Vitamin D analogues (calcipotriene/calcipotriol 0.005 % solution or foam; calcitriol 0.0003 %) – good for long-term maintenance; can be combined with steroids.  
3. Combination steroid + vitamin D (e.g., betamethasone-calcipotriene foam, gel, or ointment) – often more effective than either alone.  
4. Topical retinoid (tazarotene 0.05–0.1 %) – useful for plaque thinning; start gradually to minimize irritation.  
5. Calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus, pimecrolimus) – off-label for scalp but helpful around ears/hairline where skin is thin.

C. Phototherapy (for widespread or resistant scalp disease)  
• Excimer laser/lamps (308 nm) or narrow-band UV-B delivered via handheld comb-devices.  
• Some patients buy home NB-UVB combs after training.

D. Systemic Therapy (for extensive scalp involvement, failure of topicals, or additional body/joint disease)  
1. Traditional oral agents: Methotrexate, cyclosporine, acitretin – require blood-test monitoring.  
2. Oral small molecules: Apremilast (PDE-4 inhibitor).  
3. Biologic injections/infusions: TNF-α blockers (etanercept, adalimumab, infliximab); IL-12/23 blocker (ustekinumab); IL-17 blockers (secukinumab, ixekizumab, brodalumab); IL-23 blockers (guselkumab, risankizumab, tildrakizumab). Many achieve >75-90 % clearance including the scalp.  
4. New oral TYK2 inhibitor (deucravacitinib) recently approved for plaque psoriasis.

E. Adjunctive / Lifestyle  
• Stress-management (exercise, yoga, mindfulness, therapy).  
• Adequate sleep; limit alcohol; stop smoking.  
• Balanced diet; maintain healthy weight – obesity worsens psoriasis and reduces treatment response.  
• Treat scalp gently: lukewarm water, non-fragrance shampoos on non-treatment days, wide-tooth comb, avoid scratching; pat dry.  
• Sunlight in moderation helps many; use sunscreen on exposed areas.  
• Keep track of triggers (upper-respiratory infections, certain meds like β-blockers, lithium, antimalarials, withdrawal of oral steroids).  
• Screen for psoriatic arthritis: morning stiffness, swollen joints, heel pain. Early treatment prevents joint damage

<gold_response>
Psoriasis (Treatment): The goal of treatment is to control your symptoms and prevent infection. Three treatment options are available: - Skin lotions, ointments, creams, and shampoos. These are called topical treatments. - Pills or injections that affect the body's immune response, not just the skin. These are called systemic, or body-wide, treatments. - Phototherapy, which uses ultraviolet light to treat psoriasis. TREATMENTS USED ON THE SKIN (TOPICAL) Most of the time, psoriasis is treated with medicines that are placed directly on the skin or scalp. These may include: - Cortisone creams and ointments - Creams or ointments that contain coal tar or anthralin - Creams to remove the scaling (usually salicylic acid or lactic acid) - Dandruff shampoos (over-the-counter or prescription) - Moisturizers - Prescription medicines containing vitamin D or vitamin A (retinoids) SYSTEMIC (BODY-WIDE) TREATMENTS If you have very severe psoriasis, your provider will likely recommend medicines that suppress the immune system's faulty response. These medicines include methotrexate or cyclosporine. Retinoids can also be used. Newer drugs called biologics are used when other treatments do not work. Biologics approved for the treatment of psoriasis include: - Adalimumab (Humira) - Etanercept (Enbrel) - Infliximab (Remicade) - Ustekinumab (Stelara) - Secukinumab (Cosentyx) - Apremilast (Otezla) - Ixekizumab (Taltz) PHOTOTHERAPY Some people may choose to have phototherapy: - This is treatment in which your skin is carefully exposed to ultraviolet light. - It may be given alone or after you take a drug that makes the skin sensitive to light. - Phototherapy for psoriasis can be given as ultraviolet A (UVA) or ultraviolet B (UVB) light. OTHER TREATMENTS If you have an infection, your provider will prescribe antibiotics. HOME CARE Following these tips at home may help: - Taking a daily bath or shower. Try not to scrub too hard because this can irritate the skin and trigger an attack. - Oatmeal baths may be soothing and may help to loosen scales. You can use over-the-counter oatmeal bath products. Or, you can mix 1 cup (240 mL) of oatmeal into a tub (bath) of warm water. - Keeping your skin clean and moist, and avoiding your specific psoriasis triggers may help reduce the number of flare-ups. - Sunlight may help your symptoms go away. Be careful not to get sunburned. - Relaxation and anti-stress techniques. The link between stress and flares of psoriasis is not well understood. - Limiting the alcoholic beverages you drink may help keep psoriasis from getting worse.
</gold_response>

No one can give a calendar date, but it is possible to give a realistic picture of what “a cure” for Multiple Sclerosis (MS) would have to look like, what is happening in laboratories and clinical trials right now, and why experts are guardedly optimistic yet unwilling to promise a quick breakthrough.

1. What a true cure would mean  
   • Halting the immune attack so that no new injury occurs (immunological “switch-off”).  
   • Repairing or replacing the myelin and nerve fibers that have already been damaged (“remyelination” or regeneration).  
   • Preventing or reversing disability—restoring function in people who already have symptoms.  
   Because MS is an autoimmune, inflammatory, and neuro-degenerative disease all at once, a cure will probably take a combination of approaches rather than a single pill or injection.

2. Where we are now  
   • Twenty-five years ago there were no disease-modifying therapies (DMTs). Today there are 20+ FDA-approved drugs that can cut relapse rates by 30-70 % and, in many cases, slow the buildup of new MRI lesions and disability.  
   • High-efficacy drugs (e.g., ocrelizumab, ofatumumab, alemtuzumab) and autologous hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation (AHSCT) can put many people with the relapsing form of MS into long periods of “no evidence of disease activity” (NEDA). That is not a cure, but it shows that aggressive immune resetting is biologically possible.  
   • The first therapy for the primary-progressive form (ocrelizumab) was approved in 2017; several others (BTK inhibitors, masitinib, high-dose biotin, alpha-lipoic acid) are in late-stage trials.

3. Key lines of research that could close the gap to a cure  
   a. Immune re-education/tolerance therapy  
      • Peptide vaccines, DNA vaccines, and nanoparticle “tolerizers” aim to teach the immune system to ignore myelin rather than merely suppress it.  
   b. B-cell & plasma-cell targeting  
      • Ocrelizumab, ofatumumab, rituximab have proven how central B cells are; next-generation agents (e.g., BTK inhibitors) try to fine-tune that effect with fewer side effects.  
   c. Remyelination and neuroprotection  
      • Anti-LINGO-1, clemastine, opicinumab, high-dose biotin, thyroid-hormone analogs, and several small molecules are being tested to see if they can coax oligodendrocyte precursor cells to rebuild myelin.  
      • Lab work using monoclonal antibodies, micro-RNAs, and CRISPR gene editing is showing how to switch on myelin genes that turned off after childhood.  
   d. Regenerative cell therapies  
      • Mesenchymal stem-cell trials and induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSC) aim not only to calm the immune system but to replace lost supporting cells in the brain.  
   e. Genetics and big-data biology  
      • More than 200 gene variants that raise MS risk have been identified.  Machine-learning models are being used to stratify patients and personalize therapy—critical to stopping disease earlier, when repair is easier.  

4. How long could it take?  
   • Most scientists phrase it as “years to decades.” A single discovery could speed things up, but MS is multifactorial and differs from person to person, so a staged path is more likely:  
     – 0–5 years: Safer high-efficacy DMTs and possibly the first remyelination drug approved.  
     – 5–15 years: Combination therapies that give durable, drug-free remission in a majority of relapsing-remitting patients; better options for progressive MS.  
     – 10–30 years: Demonstrated, clinically useful restoration of function (true regeneration).  
   • Remember, many “overnight” medical advances actually rest on 20–30 years of groundwork.  Even once a therapy proves itself in the lab, it typically takes 7–10 years to move through Phase I, II, and III trials and regulatory review—longer if unexpected safety issues appear.

5. Why experts are cautiously optimistic  
   • Proof-of-concept already exists: some patients who undergo AHSCT remain relapse-free and MRI-stable for a decade without further treatment.  
   • Basic science has mapped the immune pathways and myelin biology in unprecedented detail over the last ten years, generating multiple druggable targets.  
   • Modern trial designs (platform trials, adaptive trials) can test several agents at once, short

what research (or clinical trials) is being done for Multiple Sclerosis?: The National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS) and other institutes of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) conduct research in laboratories at the NIH and also support additional research through grants to major medical institutions across the country. Scientists continue their extensive efforts to create new and better therapies for MS. One of the most promising MS research areas involves naturally occurring antiviral proteins known as interferons. Beta interferon has been shown to reduce the number of exacerbations and may slow the progression of physical disability. When attacks do occur, they tend to be shorter and less severe. In addition, there are a number of treatments under investigation that may curtail attacks or improve function. Over a dozen clinical trials testing potential therapies are underway, and additional new treatments are being devised and tested in animal models. In 2001, the National Academies/Institute of Medicine, a Federal technical and scientific advisory agency, prepared a strategic review of MS research. To read or download the National Academies/Institute of Medicine report, go to: "Multiple Sclerosis: Current Status and Strategies for the Future."
</gold_response>

Short answer  
For the right patient, permanent-seed prostate brachytherapy is an established, generally safe and very effective treatment for localized prostate cancer.  Like any cancer therapy it also carries risks and isn’t the best choice for everyone, so the decision should be made after a thorough discussion with both a urologist and a radiation oncologist.

What “seed” treatment is  
•  Tiny radioactive pellets (most often iodine-125 or palladium-103) are inserted through thin needles directly into the prostate gland during an outpatient or overnight procedure.  
•  The seeds give off radiation for weeks to months, destroying cancer cells while minimizing exposure to tissues farther away.  
•  After the radiation has decayed the seeds remain in place but are inert.

How well it works  
•  Cure / control rates for low-risk and many intermediate-risk cancers are 85-95 % at 10 years—comparable to surgery or external-beam radiation.  
•  For higher-risk disease, seeds are often combined with external-beam radiation and/or short-term hormone therapy.  
•  Several large studies show overall survival equal to that of surgery for properly selected patients.

Possible side-effects and safety concerns  
Most problems are urinary and usually peak in the first 3-6 months.

Short-term (days to months)  
•  Burning or frequent urination, weak stream, urinary urgency (30-60 % of men)  
•  Temporary blood in urine or semen  
•  Mild rectal irritation, diarrhea, or rectal bleeding (5-15 %)  
•  Fatigue for a few weeks

Long-term (months to years)  
•  Persistent urinary frequency or need for medications (10-20 %)  
•  Urinary incontinence—permanent severe leakage is uncommon (<2-3 %)  
•  Urethral stricture or chronic retention (about 2-5 %)  
•  Erectile dysfunction develops gradually in up to 25-40 % of men over several years (similar to external radiation, usually less than with surgery)  
•  Rectal ulcer/bleeding is rare (<1-2 %)  
•  Very small lifetime risk of a secondary pelvic cancer from radiation (<1 %)

Radiation to family members  
The dose that escapes the body is very low.  Precautions are simple: avoid holding young children or pregnant women on your lap for the first 2 months and use a condom the first few ejaculations.  Airport scanners and household electronics are not affected.

Who is (and isn’t) a good candidate  
LIKELY GOOD FIT  
•  Localized, low- or selected intermediate-risk cancer  
•  Prostate gland ≤60–70 cc (or willing to shrink it with hormone shots)  
•  Mild baseline urinary symptoms (IPSS/AUA score usually <15)  
•  No major hip- or pelvic-bone abnormalities that block needle placement

MAY NOT BE IDEAL  
•  Very large prostate or prior extensive TURP (may raise incontinence risk)  
•  Severe urinary obstruction or chronic prostatitis  
•  Inflammatory bowel disease or prior difficult pelvic radiation  
•  Very high-risk or metastatic prostate cancer (need multimodality therapy)

Advantages compared with other options  
•  One-time procedure; hospital stay usually 0–1 night  
•  Lower risk of major surgery complications (bleeding, anesthesia issues)  
•  Faster return to normal activities (days vs. weeks)  
•  Shorter overall treatment time than external-beam radiation (which is 4-7 weeks)

Alternatives to discuss  
•  Active surveillance (for very low-risk disease)  
•  Radical prostatectomy (open, laparoscopic, or robotic)  
•  External-beam radiation (IMRT, VMAT, proton) ± hormone therapy  
•  Combination seed + external-beam radiation  
•  Newer focal therapies (cryotherapy, HIFU) in selected cases/clinical trials

Questions to ask your specialists  
1. What is my exact stage, PSA, Gleason score, and risk group?  
2. Am I a good technical candidate for brachytherapy based on prostate size and urinary function?  
3. Would I need additional external-beam radiation or hormone therapy?  
4. What side-effects are most common in your practice and how are they managed?  
5. How many of these procedures does your center perform per year?  
6. How will you monitor my PSA after treatment and what would trigger further tests?

Bottom line  
Permanent-seed brachytherapy is a well-studied, FDA-approved option with high cure rates and a favorable safety record for many men with localized prostate cancer.  It is, however, not risk-free and may not suit every anatomy or cancer stage.  A face-to-face discussion of your personal cancer characteristics, urinary health, lifestyle priorities, and the experience of your treating team is essential before making a

<gold_response>
Prostate cancer - treatment: Treatment for your prostate cancer is chosen after a thorough evaluation. Your doctor will discuss the benefits and risks of each treatment. Sometimes your doctor may recommend 1 treatment for you because of your type of cancer and risk factors. Other times, there may be 2 or more treatments that could be good for you. Factors you and your doctor must think about include: - Your age and other medical problems you may have - Side effects that occur with each type of treatment - How much the prostate cancer has spread - Your Gleason score, which tells how likely it is that cancer has already spread - Your prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test result Ask your doctor to explain these things following about your treatment choices: - Which choices offer the best chance of curing your cancer or controlling its spread? - How likely is it that you will have different side effects, and how they will affect your life? Radical prostatectomy is a surgery to remove the prostate and some of the surrounding tissue. It is an option when the cancer has not spread beyond the prostate gland. Healthy men who will likely live 10 or more years after being diagnosed with prostate cancer often have this procedure. Be aware that it is not always possible to know for certain, before surgery, if the cancer has spread beyond the prostate gland. Possible problems after surgery include difficulty controlling urine and erection problems. Also, some men need further treatments after this surgery. Radiation therapy works best for treating prostate cancer that has not spread outside of the prostate. It may also be used after surgery if there is a risk that cancer cells are still present. Radiation is sometimes used for pain relief when cancer has spread to the bone. External beam radiation therapy uses high-powered x-rays pointed at the prostate gland: - Before treatment, the radiation therapist uses a special pen to mark the part of the body that is to be treated. - Radiation is delivered to the prostate gland using a machine similar to a regular x-ray machine. The treatment itself is usually painless. - Treatment is done in a radiation oncology center that is usually connected to a hospital. - Treatment is usually done 5 days a week for 6 to 8 weeks. Side effects may include: - Appetite loss - Diarrhea - Erection problems - Fatigue - Rectal burning or injury - Skin reactions - Urinary incontinence, the feeling of needing to urinate urgently, or blood in the urine There are reports of secondary cancers arising from the radiation as well. Proton therapy is another kind of radiation therapy used to treat prostate cancer. Proton beams target the tumor precisely, so there is less damage to the surrounding tissue. This therapy is not widely accepted or used. Brachytherapy is often used for small prostate cancers that are found early and are slow-growing. Brachytherapy may be combined with external beam radiation therapy for more advanced cancers. Brachytherapy involves placing radioactive seeds inside the prostate gland. - A surgeon inserts small needles through the skin beneath your scrotum to inject the seeds. The seeds are so small that you do not feel them. - The seeds are left in place permanently. Side effects may include: - Pain, swelling, or bruising in the penis or scrotum - Red-brown urine or semen - Impotence - Incontinence - Urinary retention - Diarrhea Testosterone is the main male hormone. Prostate tumors need testosterone to grow. Hormonal therapy is treatment that decreases the effect of testosterone on prostate cancer. Hormone therapy is mainly used for cancer that has spread beyond the prostate. The treatment can help relieve symptoms and prevent further growth and spread of cancer. But it does not cure the cancer. The main type of hormone therapy is called a luteinizing hormone-releasing hormones (LH-RH) agonist: - The medicine blocks the testicles from making testosterone. The drugs must be given by injection, usually every 3 to 6 months. - Possible side effects include nausea and vomiting, hot flashes, anemia, fatigue, thinning bones (osteoporosis), reduced sexual desire, decreased muscle mass, weight gain, and impotence. The other type of hormone medicine is called an androgen-blocking drug: - It is often given along with LH-RH drugs to block the effect of testosterone produced by the adrenal glands, which make a small amount of testosterone. - Possible side effects include erection problems, reduced sexual desire, liver problems, diarrhea, and enlarged breasts. Much of the body's testosterone is made by the testes. As a result, surgery to remove the testes (called orchiectomy) can also be used as a hormonal treatment. Chemotherapy and immunotherapy (medicine that helps the body's immune system fight the cancer) may be used to treat prostate cancer that no longer responds to hormone treatment. Usually a single drug or a combination of drugs is recommended. Updated by: Jennifer Sobol, DO, Urologist with the Michigan Institute of Urology, West Bloomfield, MI. Review provided by VeriMed Healthcare Network. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
I am not a substitute for your grandson’s physician, but here is general, evidence-based information you can use when you speak with his doctor.

1. How serious is rubella in a healthy 4-year-old?  
• In almost all children the illness is mild: low-grade fever, swollen lymph nodes, and a fine pink rash that fades within 3-5 days.  
• Complications such as arthritis, encephalitis (brain inflammation), or a low platelet count are possible but very uncommon.  
• Treatment is “supportive” only—rest, fluids, acetaminophen/ibuprofen for fever or discomfort (no aspirin).  

2. Why did he get rubella if he was vaccinated?  
• A single dose of the MMR (or MR) vaccine prevents about 95 % of cases, but that still leaves a small chance of “break-through” infection.  
• Most countries (including Mexico and the U.S.) now recommend two doses: the first at 12–15 months and the second at 4–6 years. If he has not yet had the 2nd dose, ask his doctor when it can be given after he recovers.

3. Contagious period and isolation  
• He can spread the virus from about 7 days before the rash appears until 7 days after it clears.  
• Keep him away from school, day care, crowded places, and—most importantly—pregnant women during that time.  
• Good hand-washing, covering coughs/sneezes, and cleaning shared toys help reduce spread.

4. Who should be most concerned?  
• Pregnant women who are not immune are at high risk because rubella in early pregnancy can cause miscarriage or serious birth defects (congenital rubella syndrome).  
• Make sure any pregnant relatives, neighbors, or caregivers are aware of his diagnosis so they can check their own immunity and avoid close contact.

5. What the family should do now  
• Confirm the diagnosis and get written instructions from a local physician or clinic.  
• Monitor him for fever that lasts >3 days, severe headache, drowsiness, unusual bruising, or joint swelling—call the doctor if any of these occur.  
• Make sure all household members are fully vaccinated; adults who are uncertain can receive the MMR vaccine unless they are pregnant or have other contraindications.  
• When the isolation period is over and he feels well, he can resume normal activities.

6. Prognosis  
• In children, rubella is almost always self-limited and leaves lifelong immunity.  
• Once he is past the contagious window and feeling better, there are usually no long-term effects.

Bottom line  
You do not need to panic about your grandson’s health, but you should: (1) follow his doctor’s instructions, (2) keep him away from pregnant women for at least a week after the rash disappears, and (3) make sure everyone’s vaccinations are up to date so the virus does not spread further.

predicted_text:
Yes. A suspected skull fracture is always a medical emergency—call 911 (or your local emergency number) or go to the nearest emergency department right away.

Why immediate care is critical  
• A break in the skull can injure the brain or the blood vessels around it, even if there is no visible cut or only a mild-seeming bump.  
• Serious complications such as bleeding inside the skull, swelling of the brain, infection, or leakage of cerebrospinal fluid can develop quickly and may not be obvious at first.  
• Rapid evaluation (neurologic exam, CT scan, sometimes surgery) is often needed to prevent permanent damage or death.

Red-flag symptoms after any head injury  
Seek emergency help immediately if you notice any of these in yourself or someone else:
• Loss of consciousness (even briefly)  
• Confusion, drowsiness, or difficulty staying awake  
• Persistent or worsening headache  
• Nausea or vomiting  
• Seizure  
• Clear fluid or blood coming from the nose or ears  
• Unequal pupil size or vision changes  
• Weakness, numbness, or problems with coordination  
• Slurred speech or difficulty understanding speech

While waiting for help  
• Keep the person still; do not move the neck unnecessarily.  
• If they bleed, apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth, but do not press hard on any obvious depression in the skull.  
• Do not give food, drink, or medication unless instructed by medical personnel.

Bottom line  
A skull fracture cannot be safely managed at home. Even if the injury seems minor or symptoms are mild, get professional medical evaluation immediately.
