I’m happy to outline the usual medical options, but only a team that has examined you, reviewed your scans, and knows your full medical history can decide what is right for you.  Take this information to your physicians and ask how it applies in your individual case.

1.  Assemble (or be referred to) a multidisciplinary “spina-bifida / complex-spine” team  
   •  Neurosurgeon (tethered-cord, syrinx, Chiari, shunt issues)  
   •  Orthopaedic spine surgeon (previous fusion, scoliosis/kyphosis balance)  
   •  Physiatrist (rehabilitation medicine)  
   •  Urologist / bowel-management specialist  
   •  Physical & occupational therapists, orthotist, social worker  

2.  Re-image the entire neuro-axis  
   •  MRI brain and full spine with and without contrast to document:  
        – Level and size of syrinx (fluid cavity)  
        – Whether a Chiari malformation, bony stenosis, or tethered cord is driving the syrinx  
        – Status of your existing fusion (hardware position, bone healing, adjacent levels)  
   •  Dynamic flexion/extension spine X-rays if instability is suspected.

3.  Treat the underlying driver of the syrinx / tethered cord  
   a)  Symptomatic tethered cord (worsening leg strength, pain, spasticity, new bladder/bowel problems, rapid scoliosis, foot deformity) → detethering surgery.  
   b)  Syrinx related to Chiari malformation → posterior fossa decompression ± duraplasty.  
   c)  Syrinx related to tethering, arachnoid scarring, or dura defects → detethering / lysis of adhesions; rarely a direct syrinx shunt.  
   d)  If the syrinx is small, stable, and asymptomatic, many surgeons will observe with serial MRIs rather than operate immediately.

4.  Optimise the prior vertebral fusion  
   •  Look for pseudo-arthrosis (non-union), infection, or hardware failures that might be producing pain or destabilising the cord.  
   •  If alignment is satisfactory and the fusion is solid, most patients are treated non-operatively (core-strengthening PT, low-impact fitness, weight optimisation, bone-health management).  
   •  When adjacent-segment disease or crank-shaft curve progression occurs, extension of the fusion may be recommended.

5.  Rehabilitation and symptom control  
   •  Physical therapy: gentle core strengthening, gait training, prevention of contractures; hydro-therapy is often well-tolerated.  
   •  Occupational therapy for ADLs, seating, pressure-relief cushions, bracing or custom AFOs if there is foot drop or ankle instability.  
   •  Spasticity and neuropathic pain management: gabapentin/pregabalin, amitriptyline, duloxetine, baclofen (oral or intrathecal pump), botulinum toxin injections if focal.  
   •  Bladder: intermittent catheterisation, anticholinergics, β-3 agonists, Botox, or on-abotulinum toxin injections; some ultimately need bladder augmentation or urinary diversion.  
   •  Bowel: scheduled emptying, osmotic agents, suppositories, Antegrade Continence Enema (ACE) if refractory.  
   •  Skin care, pressure-ulcer prevention, vitamin D & calcium supplementation.

6.  Monitoring schedule (varies by surgeon)  
   •  Neuro exam and bladder/bowel review every 6–12 months.  
   •  MRI every 1-2 years, or sooner if neurologic change.  
   •  Urodynamics when new urinary symptoms appear.  
   •  DEXA scan if long-term immobility or steroid use.

7.  Red-flag symptoms that should prompt urgent review  
   •  Rapid loss of leg strength, new numbness, or intractable back/leg pain.  
   •  New/worsening incontinence or inability to empty bladder.  
   •  Fever or drainage from prior fusion incision.  
   •  Severe headaches with vomiting (concern for shunt failure or syrinx expansion).

8.  Lifestyle & support resources  
   •  Stop smoking (impairs fusion and wound healing).  
   •  Maintain BMI in normal range; obesity stresses the spine and hinders mobility.  
   •  Vaccinate against pneumococcus and influenza if you use chronic catheters.  
   •  Spina Bifida Association (www.spinabifidaassociation.org) and local support groups for equipment funding, driving programs, schooling, and vocational counseling.

Key takeaway:

<gold_response>
Spina bifida (Treatment): Spina bifida treatment depends on the severity of the condition. Spina bifida occulta often doesn't require treatment at all, but other types of spina bifida do. Surgery before birth Nerve function in babies with spina bifida can worsen after birth if it's not treated. Prenatal surgery for spina bifida (fetal surgery) takes place before the 26th week of pregnancy. Surgeons expose a pregnant mother's uterus surgically, open the uterus and repair the baby's spinal cord. Research suggests that children with spina bifida who had fetal surgery may have reduced disability and be less likely to need crutches or other walking devices. In addition, fetal surgery may reduce the risk of hydrocephalus. Ask your doctor whether this procedure may be appropriate for you. Discuss the risks, such as possible premature delivery and other complications, and potential benefits for you and your baby. It's important to have a comprehensive evaluation to determine whether fetal surgery is feasible. This specialized surgery should only be done at a health care facility that has experienced fetal surgery experts, a multispecialty team approach and neonatal intensive care. Typically the team includes a fetal surgeon, pediatric neurosurgeon, maternal-fetal medicine specialist, fetal cardiologist and neonatologist. Cesarean birth Many babies with myelomeningocele tend to be in a feet-first (breech) position. If your baby is in this position or if your doctor has detected a large cyst or sac, cesarean birth may be a safer way to deliver your baby. Surgery after birth Meningocele involves surgery to put the meninges back in place and close the opening in the vertebrae. Because the spinal cord develops normally in babies with meningocele, these membranes often can be removed by surgery with little or no damage to nerve pathways. Myelomeningocele also requires surgery. Performing the surgery early can help minimize risk of infection that's associated with the exposed nerves and may also help protect the spinal cord from more trauma. During the procedure, a neurosurgeon places the spinal cord and exposed tissue inside the baby's body and covers them with muscle and skin. Sometimes a shunt to control hydrocephalus in the baby's brain is placed during the operation on the spinal cord. Treatment for complications In babies with myelomeningocele, irreparable nerve damage has likely already occurred and ongoing care from a multispecialty team of surgeons, physicians and therapists is usually needed. Babies with myelomeningocele may need more surgery for a variety of complications. Treatment for complications - such as weak legs, bladder and bowel problems or hydrocephalus - typically begins soon after birth. Depending on the severity of spina bifida and the complications, treatment may include, for example: - Walking and mobility aids. Some babies may start exercises to prepare their legs for walking with braces or crutches when they're older. Some children may need walkers or a wheelchair. Mobility aids, along with regular physical therapy, can help a child become independent. - Bowel and bladder management. Routine bowel and bladder evaluations and management plans help reduce the risk of organ damage and illness. Evaluations include X-rays, kidney scans, ultrasounds, blood tests and bladder function studies. These evaluations will be more frequent in the first few years of life, but less often as children grow. - Bowel management may include oral medications, suppositories, enemas, surgery, or a combination of these approaches. - Bladder management may include medications, using catheters to empty the bladder, surgery, or a combination. - For children, a specialist in pediatric urology with experience in evaluating and performing surgery on children with spina bifida is the best choice. - Surgery for hydrocephalus. Most babies with myelomeningocele will need a ventricular shunt - a surgically placed tube that allows fluid in the brain to drain into the abdomen. This tube might be placed just after birth, during the surgery to close the sac on the lower back or later as fluid accumulates. A less invasive procedure, called endoscopic third ventriculostomy, may be used, but candidates must be carefully chosen and meet certain criteria. The surgeon uses a small video camera to see inside the brain and makes a hole in the bottom of or between the ventricles so cerebrospinal fluid can flow out of the brain. - Treatment and management of other complications. To help with functioning, special equipment such as bath chairs, commode chairs and standing frames may be needed. Whatever the issue - orthopedic complications, tethered spinal cord, GI issues, skin problems, or others - most spina bifida complications can be treated or at least managed to improve quality of life. Ongoing care Children with spina bifida need close follow-up care and observation. Their primary care doctors follow growth, the need for immunizations and general medical issues. They coordinate your child's medical care. Children with spina bifida also often need treatment and ongoing care from: - Physical medicine and rehabilitation - Neurology - Neurosurgery - Urology - Orthopedics - Physical therapy - Occupational therapy - Special education teachers - Social workers - Dietitians Parents and other caregivers are a key part of the team, learning how to help manage their child's condition and how to encourage and support their child emotionally and socially. Keep in mind that children with spina bifida can go on to college, hold jobs and have families. Special accommodations may be necessary along the way, but encourage your child to be as independent as possible.

Below is general, non-commercial information that can help you (or your physician) locate the right experts and learn where legitimate stem-cell and other experimental treatments for limb–girdle muscular dystrophy (LGMD) are being studied.  It is not a substitute for medical advice from your own doctor.

1. Current status of “stem-cell therapy” for LGMD
•  No stem-cell product has been approved anywhere in the world for LGMD or any other muscular dystrophy.  
•  Work is under way in a few university laboratories and early-phase (Phase I/II) clinical trials, most of which involve:
  – Autologous (your own) mesoangioblasts or mesenchymal stem cells  
  – Gene-corrected induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs)  
  – Combination gene-transfer / stem-cell approaches (e.g., LGMD2C, LGMD2D)  
•  These studies are strictly experimental, enroll only small numbers of patients, and are overseen by national regulatory agencies and institutional review boards.  At present they are offered only within formal clinical-trial protocols—never as a private “treatment for sale.”  Be very cautious about clinics (often outside the U.S./Europe) that advertise stem-cell cures for a fee.

2. How to locate recognized specialists and research centers
A. Neuromuscular disease clinics
   • Ask your primary physician for referral to a neurologist who is fellowship-trained in “Neuromuscular Medicine” and who works in, or with, an academic medical center.  
   • Many such centers host multidisciplinary “MDA Clinics” (see below) in which neurologists, physiatrists, physical therapists, pulmonologists, and genetic counselors jointly see patients.

B. Muscular Dystrophy Association (MDA) – U.S.
   • Toll-free Helpline: 1-800-572-1717  
   • Clinic finder: https://www.mda.org/locate-nearby  
   • The MDA can (1) help you locate the nearest MDA-supported LGMD clinic, (2) provide names of physicians who specialize in LGMD, and (3) tell you about clinical trials for which you may be eligible.

C. Muscular Dystrophy UK / Muscular Dystrophy Canada / similar national groups
   • If you live outside the U.S., your national MD organization (search “Muscular Dystrophy” + your country) plays a role similar to the MDA and keeps a list of neuromuscular specialists.

D. National Institutes of Health (NIH) / Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center
   • Phone (U.S.): 1-888-205-2311  • Email: GARDinfo@nih.gov  
   • Provides physician-vetted information on LGMD subtypes and can tell you which U.S. investigators are running trials.

E. ClinicalTrials.gov
   • Website: https://www.clinicaltrials.gov  
   • Search term example: “limb girdle muscular dystrophy stem cell” or just “LGMD.”  
   • Each study listing shows the principal investigator, recruiting status, contact e-mail and phone number, and geographic sites.

F. European Union Clinical Trials Register
   • Website: https://www.clinicaltrialsregister.eu  
   • Same search strategy for people in Europe.

G. Centers with active LGMD / stem-cell research programs (examples, not an exhaustive list)
   • Royal Holloway–University of London / San Raffaele Telethon Institute, Milan (mesoangioblast trials)  
   • Nationwide Children’s Hospital, Columbus, Ohio, USA (gene-editing / cell therapy)  
   • University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) Broad Stem Cell Research Center  
   • Cedars-Sinai Regenerative Medicine Institute, Los Angeles  
   • Myology Institute, Sorbonne Université, Paris  
   • These centers usually require a formal physician referral or direct inquiry to the trial coordinator listed on ClinicalTrials.gov.

3. Preparing to contact a specialist
• Know your LGMD subtype if possible; genetic confirmation is increasingly required for trial eligibility.  
• Gather prior muscle biopsies, genetic reports, EMG results, and clinic notes; research coordinators will ask for them.  
• Bring a list of current medications and assistive devices.  
• Draft your questions (e.g., “Are any trials presently recruiting my subtype?” “What are the risks?” “Is travel required?”).

4. If you encounter “pay-to-participate” clinics
• Legitimate research trials do not charge for the experimental stem-cell product or its administration, though travel expenses are sometimes the patient’s responsibility.  
• Check the clinic or company against FDA or EMA warning letters and the International Society for Stem Cell Research (ISSCR) “Stem

Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy (Treatment): Unfortunately, no definitive treatments for LGMD exist. Management depends on each individual and the specific type of LGMD that the individual has. However, the American Academy of Neurology has developed guidelines for treatment of LGMD including: [5] [6] Weight control to avoid obesity Physical therapy and stretching exercises to promote mobility and prevent contractures (fixed tightening of the muscles) Use of mechanical aids such as canes, walkers, orthotics, and wheelchairs as needed to help ambulation and mobility Monitoring and surgical intervention as needed for orthopedic complications, such as foot deformity and scoliosis cardiomyopathy A team approach to treatment is recommended including a neurologist , pulmonologist , cardiologist , orthopedic surgeon, physiatrist , physical/occupational/ speech therapist , nutritionist , orthopedist , mental health counselors, and geneticist / genetic counselor . [5] [6] While not a currently available treatment option, some studies have shown  promising results with the use of gene therapy . More research is needed to prove the safety and efficacy of this treatment approach. [6] Management Guidelines The American Academy of Neurology (AAN), the medical specialty society of neurologists, offers a summary of recommended guidelines for Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy  GeneReviews provides current, expert-authored, peer-reviewed, full-text articles describing the application of genetic testing to the diagnosis, management, and genetic counseling of patients with specific inherited conditions. Project OrphanAnesthesia is a project whose aim is to create peer-reviewed, readily accessible guidelines for patients with rare diseases and for the anesthesiologists caring for them. The project is a collaborative effort of the German Society of Anesthesiology and Intensive Care, Orphanet, the European Society of Pediatric Anesthesia, anesthetists and rare disease experts with the aim to contribute to patient safety.

predicted_text:
Below is general information for educational purposes only.  It is not a substitute for an examination, diagnosis or treatment plan from your own physician or podiatrist.  Because Haglund’s deformity and retro-/sub-calcaneal bursitis can look like other heel disorders (Achilles tendinopathy, stress fracture, infection, gout, etc.), please be evaluated in person if pain, swelling or limping persist.

1. What the terms mean  
• Haglund’s deformity – an extra bony “bump” on the postero-superior part of the calcaneus (heel bone). The bump rubs on shoes or the Achilles tendon.  
• Retrocalcaneal bursitis – inflammation of the fluid-filled bursa that normally cushions the space between the Achilles tendon and the heel bone.  
• Subcutaneous calcaneal bursitis – inflammation of the more superficial bursa that sits just under the skin at the back of the heel.  
The three problems often occur together: the prominent bone irritates the bursa, the bursa swells, and the swollen bursa irritates the Achilles tendon.

2. Why it happens  
• Foot shape: high arches, tight calf/Achilles complex, or a varus (in-turned) heel put extra pressure on that area.  
• Footwear: stiff-backed shoes, high-heeled pumps (“pump bump”), running shoes with hard heel counters.  
• Activity change or overuse: sudden increase in running mileage, hill workouts, jumping sports.  
• Systemic contributors: inflammatory arthritis, gout, diabetes can aggravate bursae and tendons.

3. Typical conservative (non-surgical) management  
Most orthopaedic and sports-medicine guidelines start with 8–12 weeks of non-operative care:

A. Footwear modification  
• Wear shoes with soft or open backs, or use a heel-counter cut-out to take pressure off the bump.  
• Consider backless, runner’s “clog” style, or a shoe one half-size bigger.  
• Avoid high heels and very flat minimalist shoes until symptoms settle.

B. Heel lift / pads / orthotics  
• A 6–10 mm heel lift temporarily moves the Achilles insertion away from the bony bump.  
• Soft silicone or felt donut-shaped pads can protect the area.  
• Custom or off-the-shelf orthotic devices can correct high arches or varus heel alignment, reducing shear.

C. Activity adjustment & icing  
• Reduce or temporarily stop running, jumping, stair climbing, and uphill walking.  
• Ice the back of the heel 15–20 min, 2–4 times per day, especially after activity.

D. Stretching & physical therapy  
• Gastrocnemius/soleus stretch: Stand facing a wall, back knee straight (gastrocnemius stretch) then bent (soleus), 30 s x 3, 2–3× daily.  
• Eccentric calf strengthening (heel-lowering off a step) once acute pain settles.  
• Manual therapy, ultrasound, iontophoresis and deep-friction massage can reduce bursal/thickened tissue.  
• A night dorsiflexion splint or lightweight cast can keep the Achilles gently stretched.

E. Medication  
• Short course of an NSAID (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen) if you have no ulcers, kidney disease, bleeding disorder or other contra-indications.  
• Topical NSAID gel can be used if oral tablets are not tolerated.

F. Injections or other office procedures (by a specialist)  
• Ultrasound-guided corticosteroid injection into the bursa can calm inflammation, but must be placed carefully to avoid the Achilles tendon (risk of rupture).  
• Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) or extracorporeal shock-wave therapy are sometimes used when bursitis co-exists with chronic Achilles tendinopathy.

G. Weight optimisation & general measures  
• Reducing excess body weight lessens repetitive heel compression.  
• Warm up, progress mileage gradually, cross-train with cycling or swimming during recovery.

4. When surgery is considered  
If 3–6 months of well‐supervised conservative care fails, or bursitis recurs repeatedly, surgery may be discussed.

• Open or endoscopic calcaneoplasty (shaving/removing the Haglund bump) plus bursectomy.  
• Sometimes a small portion of the Achilles tendon needs to be detached and re-anchored with suture anchors.  
• Typical post-op pathway: 2 weeks non-weight bearing splint, 2–4 weeks walking boot with heel wedge, progressive physical therapy, return to full activity 3–6 months.  
• Success rates are 75–90 %, but risks include wound issues, numbness, persistent pain and Achilles weakness.

5. Prognosis  
• Many patients improve

F. Injections or other office procedures (by a specialist)  
• Ultrasound-guided corticosteroid injection into the bursa can calm inflammation, but must be placed carefully to avoid the Achilles tendon (risk of rupture).  
• Platelet-rich plasma (PRP) or extracorporeal shock-wave therapy are sometimes used when bursitis co-exists with chronic Achilles tendinopathy.

G. Weight optimisation & general measures  
• Reducing excess body weight lessens repetitive heel compression.  
• Warm up, progress mileage gradually, cross-train with cycling or swimming during recovery.

4. When surgery is considered  
If 3–6 months of well‐supervised conservative care fails, or bursitis recurs repeatedly, surgery may be discussed.

• Open or endoscopic calcaneoplasty (shaving/removing the Haglund bump) plus bursectomy.  
• Sometimes a small portion of the Achilles tendon needs to be detached and re-anchored with suture anchors.  
• Typical post-op pathway: 2 weeks non-weight bearing splint, 2–4 weeks walking boot with heel wedge, progressive physical therapy, return to full activity 3–6 months.  
• Success rates are 75–90 %, but risks include wound issues, numbness, persistent pain and Achilles weakness.

5. Prognosis  
• Many patients improve

Have physical therapy to improve flexibility and strength around the ankle. The focus will be on stretching your Achilles tendon. This can help the bursitis improve and prevent it from coming back. If these treatments DO NOT work, your provider may inject a small amount of steroid medicine into the bursa. After the injection, you should avoid overstretching the tendon because it can break open (rupture). If the condition is connected to Achilles tendinitis, you may need to wear a cast on the ankle for several weeks. Very rarely, surgery may be needed to remove the inflamed bursa.

predicted_text:
Not likely.

Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) damages the macula, the part of the retina that gives you sharp central vision.  It does not affect the balance organs in the inner ear, the nerves that carry balance signals to the brain, or the brain-stem centers that produce the spinning or “off-balance” feeling of vertigo.  Even when only one eye is involved, the healthy eye and the brain usually compensate so that your sense of orientation in space is preserved.

• What AMD can do:  Reduce or distort central vision in the affected eye.  That may make reading or fine detail work harder and, in advanced cases, can make you feel a little uncertain when you move around unfamiliar areas in dim light.  This is more a problem of blurred vision than true vertigo.

• What AMD does not usually do:  Produce the spinning, tilting or light-headed sensation we call dizziness or subjective vertigo.  Those symptoms more often come from inner-ear disorders (such as benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, vestibular neuritis, Ménière’s disease), migraines, medication side effects, low blood pressure, heart-rhythm problems, anxiety, dehydration, etc.

Bottom line  
Macular degeneration in one eye is very unlikely to be the primary cause of dizziness.  If you are experiencing persistent or recurrent vertigo, let your primary-care physician or an ear, nose and throat/neurology specialist evaluate you to look for other, more common causes while you continue regular follow-up with your eye-care professional for AMD.

The reference answer will be provided in these tags:
<gold_response>
Dizziness: Dizziness is a term used to describe a range of sensations, such as feeling faint, woozy, weak or unsteady. Dizziness that creates the false sense that you or your surroundings are spinning or moving is called vertigo. Dizziness is one of the more common reasons adults visit their doctors. Frequent dizzy spells or constant dizziness can significantly affect your life. But dizziness rarely signals a life-threatening condition. Treatment of dizziness depends on the cause and your symptoms. It's usually effective, but the problem may recur. People experiencing dizziness may describe it as any of a number of sensations, such as: - A false sense of motion or spinning (vertigo) - Lightheadedness or feeling faint - Unsteadiness or a loss of balance - A feeling of floating, wooziness or heavy-headedness These feelings may be triggered or worsened by walking, standing up or moving your head. Your dizziness may accompanied by nausea or be so sudden or severe that you need to sit or lie down. The episode may last seconds or days and may recur. When to see a doctor Call 911 or seek emergency medical help if you experience dizziness with: - A sudden or severe headache - Ongoing vomiting - A sudden change in speech, vision or hearing - Stumbling or difficulty walking - Fainting - Chest pain or an irregular heart rate - Numbness or weakness - Shortness of breath - A high fever - A very stiff neck - A head injury - Seizures Consult with your doctor if you experience recurrent, sudden, severe dizziness or prolonged episodes of dizziness, faintness, lightheadedness or vertigo. Dizziness has many possible causes, including inner ear disturbance, motion sickness and medication effects. Sometimes it's caused by an underlying health condition, such as poor circulation, infection or injury. The way dizziness makes you feel and your triggers provide clues for possible causes. How long the dizziness lasts and any other symptoms you have also help pinpoint the cause. Inner ear problems that cause dizziness (vertigo) Your sense of balance depends on the combined input from the various parts of your sensory system. These include your: - Eyes, which help you determine where your body is in space and how it's moving - Sensory nerves, which send messages to your brain about body movements and positions - Inner ear, which houses sensors that help detect gravity and back-and-forth motion Vertigo is the false sense that your surroundings are spinning or moving. With inner ear disorders, your brain receives signals from the inner ear that aren't consistent with what your eyes and sensory nerves are receiving. Vertigo is what results as your brain works to sort out the confusion. - Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). This condition causes an intense and brief but false sense that you're spinning or moving. These episodes are triggered by a rapid change in head movement, such as when you turn over in bed, sit up or experience a blow to the head. BPPV is the most common cause of vertigo. - Infection. A viral infection of the vestibular nerve, called vestibular neuritis, can cause intense, constant vertigo. If you also have sudden hearing loss, you may have labyrinthitis. - Meniere's disease. This disease involves the excessive buildup of fluid in your inner ear. It's characterized by sudden episodes of vertigo lasting as long as several hours. You may also experience fluctuating hearing loss, ringing in the ear and the feeling of a plugged ear. - Migraine. People who experience migraines may have episodes of vertigo or other types of dizziness even when they're not having a severe headache. Such vertigo episodes can last minutes to hours and may be associated with headache as well as light and noise sensitivity. Circulation problems that cause dizziness You may feel dizzy, faint or off balance if your heart isn't pumping enough blood to your brain. Causes include: - Drop in blood pressure. A dramatic drop in your systolic blood pressure - the higher number in your blood pressure reading - may result in brief lightheadedness or a feeling of faintness. It can occur after sitting up or standing too quickly. This condition is also called orthostatic hypotension. - Poor blood circulation. Conditions such as cardiomyopathy, heart attack, heart arrhythmia and transient ischemic attack could cause dizziness. And a decrease in blood volume may cause inadequate blood flow to your brain or inner ear. Other causes of dizziness - Neurological conditions. Some neurological disorders - such as Parkinson's disease and multiple sclerosis - can lead to progressive loss of balance. - Medications. Dizziness can be a side effect of certain medications - such as anti-seizure drugs, antidepressants, sedatives and tranquilizers. In particular, blood pressure lowering medications may cause faintness if they lower your blood pressure too much. - Anxiety disorders. Certain anxiety disorders may cause lightheadedness or a woozy feeling often referred to as dizziness. These include panic attacks and a fear of leaving home or being in large, open spaces (agoraphobia). - Low iron levels (anemia). Other signs and symptoms that may occur along with dizziness if you have anemia include fatigue, weakness and pale skin. - Low blood sugar (hypoglycemia). This condition generally occurs in people with diabetes who use insulin. Dizziness (lightheadedness) may be accompanied by sweating and anxiety. - Overheating and dehydration. If you're active in hot weather, or if you don't drink enough fluids, you may feel dizzy from overheating (hyperthermia) or from dehydration. This is especially true if you take certain heart medications. Factors that may increase your risk of getting dizzy include: - Age. Older adults are more likely to have medical conditions that cause dizziness, especially a sense of imbalance. They're also more likely to take medications that can cause dizziness. - A past episode of dizziness. If you've experienced dizziness before, you're more likely to get dizzy in the future. If your doctor suspects you're having or may have had a stroke, are older or suffered a blow to the head, he or she may immediately order an MRI or CT scan. Most people visiting their doctor because of dizziness will first be asked about their symptoms and medications and then be given a physical examination. During this exam, your doctor will check how you walk and maintain your balance and how the major nerves of your central nervous system are working. You may also need a hearing test and balance tests, including: - Eye movement testing. Your doctor may watch the path of your eyes when you track a moving object. And you may be given an eye motion test in which cold and warm water or air are placed in your ear canal. - Head movement testing. If your doctor suspects your vertigo is caused by benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, he or she may do a simple head movement test called the Dix-Hallpike maneuver to verify the diagnosis. - Posturography. This test tells your doctor which parts of the balance system you rely on the most and which parts may be giving you problems. You stand in your bare feet on a platform and try to keep your balance under various conditions. - Rotary-chair testing. During this test you sit in a computer-controlled chair that moves very slowly in a full circle. At faster speeds, it moves back and forth in a very small arc. In addition, you may be given blood tests to check for infection and other tests to check heart and blood vessel health. Dizziness often gets better without treatment. Within a couple of weeks, the body usually adapts to whatever is causing it. If you seek treatment, your doctor will base it on the cause of your condition and your symptoms. It may include medications and balance exercises. Even if no cause is found or if your dizziness persists, prescription drugs and other treatments may make your symptoms more manageable. Medications - Water pills. If you have Meniere's disease, your doctor may prescribe a water pill (diuretic). This along with a low-salt diet may help reduce how often you have dizziness episodes. - Medications that reduce the dizziness. Antihistamines such as meclizine (Antivert) may offer short-term relief from vertigo. Anticholinergics help reduce dizziness. They include scopolamine skin patches (Transderm Scop). - Anti-nausea medications. Your doctor may prescribe a drug to provide immediate relief of nausea. Some of these can cause drowsiness. - Anti-anxiety medications. Diazepam (Valium) and alprazolam (Xanax) are in a class of drugs called benzodiazepines, which may cause addiction. They may also cause drowsiness. - Preventive medicine for migraine. Certain medicines may help prevent attacks of migraine. Therapy - Head position maneuvers. A technique called canalith repositioning (or Epley maneuver) usually helps resolve benign paroxysmal positional vertigo more quickly than simply waiting for your dizziness to go away. It can be done by your doctor, an audiologist or a physical therapist and involves maneuvering the position of your head. It's usually effective after one or two treatments. Before undergoing this procedure, tell your care provider if you have a neck or back condition, a detached retina or blood vessel problems. - Balance therapy. You may learn specific exercises to help make your balance system less sensitive to motion. This physical therapy technique is called vestibular rehabilitation. It is used for people with dizziness from inner ear conditions such as vestibular neuritis. - Psychotherapy. This type of therapy may help people whose dizziness is caused by anxiety disorders. Surgical or other procedures - Injections. Your doctor may inject your inner ear with the antibiotic gentamicin to disable the balance function. The unaffected ear takes over that function. - Removal of the inner ear sense organ. A procedure that's rarely used is called labyrinthectomy. It disables the vestibular labyrinth in the affected ear. The other ear takes over the balance function. This technique may be used if you have serious hearing loss and your dizziness hasn't responded to other treatments. Dizziness usually goes away on its own. If you tend to experience repeated episodes of dizziness, consider these tips: - Be aware of the possibility of losing your balance, which can lead to falling and serious injury. - Avoid moving suddenly and walk with a cane for stability, if needed. - Fall-proof your home by removing tripping hazards such as area rugs and exposed electrical cords. Use nonslip mats on your bath and shower floors. Use good lighting. - Sit or lie down immediately when you feel dizzy. Lie still with your eyes closed in a darkened room if you're experiencing a severe episode of vertigo. - Avoid driving a car or operating heavy machinery if you experience frequent dizziness without warning. - Avoid using caffeine, alcohol, salt and tobacco. Excessive use of these substances can worsen your signs and symptoms. - Drink enough fluids, eat a healthy diet, get enough sleep and avoid stress. - If your dizziness is caused by a medication, talk with your doctor about discontinuing it or lowering the dose. - If your dizziness comes with nausea, try an over-the-counter (nonprescription) antihistamine, such as meclizine (Antivert) or one containing dimenhydrinate (Dramamine). These may cause drowsiness. Nondrowsy antihistamines aren't as effective. - If your dizziness is caused by overheating or dehydration, rest in a cool place and drink water or a sports drink (Gatorade, Powerade, others).
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Severe dehydration can certainly make a person feel dizzy, light-headed or even cause them to faint because the circulating blood volume and blood pressure fall.  Typical warning signs just before a dehydration-related faint include:

• Intense thirst, dry mouth  
• Profuse sweating that then stops (sweat dries up)  
• Rapid heartbeat or palpitations  
• Feeling very warm, nauseated, “gray” or “tunnel-vision”  
• Light-headedness, wooziness, or seeing black spots  

A sharp or tight chest pain, however, is NOT considered a classic symptom of dehydration.  While some people do notice a vague pressure or fluttering in the chest when their heart is beating fast from low blood volume, true “tight pain under the breasts” can signal many other, more serious conditions—heart-related problems, esophageal spasm/acid reflux, costochondritis, panic attack, lung issues, etc.

Bottom line  
• Dizziness and fainting can be from severe dehydration.  
• Chest pain is not typical; treat it as a red-flag symptom.  
• Anyone who develops chest pain—especially if it is new, tightening, or accompanied by fainting, shortness of breath, sweating, or nausea—should be evaluated by a clinician or go to the nearest emergency department right away.

While rehydrating (oral fluids with electrolytes or IV fluids) often relieves dehydration symptoms quickly, chest pain requires prompt medical attention to rule out other causes.

Dear ­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­

I am sorry to hear about the severe vision loss you have lived with for so many years. Below is an overview of what modern medicine can (and, just as importantly, cannot yet) do for optic-nerve atrophy, together with practical next steps if you would like to be evaluated at our center.

1. What optic-nerve atrophy means  
• The optic nerve is made up of roughly 1.2 million long nerve fibers (axons) that carry visual information from the eye to the brain.  
• “Atrophy” means those fibers have been permanently damaged. Typical causes include head trauma, glaucoma, lack of blood flow, inflammation, tumors pressing on the nerve, toxins, or severe nutritional deficiency.  
• Once an axon has died, today’s routine medical and surgical techniques cannot bring it back to life. Treatment therefore focuses on:  
  – Removing or controlling the original cause (if it is still present);  
  – Preventing additional damage; and  
  – Helping the person use the remaining vision in the most effective way (low-vision rehabilitation).

2. Evidence-based treatment options available today  
A. Identify and treat any ongoing or preventable cause  
   • Neuro-imaging (MRI) to be sure there is no compressive mass that could still be relieved.  
   • Blood tests for vitamin B12, folate, copper, thyroid, and autoimmune markers; correcting any deficiency can protect remaining fibers.  
   • Pressure-lowering therapy if glaucoma is present.  
   • Immunosuppressive or antiviral medicines if an active inflammatory or infectious optic neuritis is discovered.  
   • Stopping optic-nerve-toxic drugs (e.g., ethambutol, amiodarone) or environmental toxins.

B. Low-vision and rehabilitation services  
   • High-powered reading lenses, magnifiers, telescopic or electronic devices (CCTV, video magnifiers).  
   • Orientation & mobility training, white-cane instruction, adaptive software (screen readers, voice-assistant tech).  
   • Occupational-therapy-based daily-living skills. Studies show these steps significantly improve independence and quality of life even when visual-acuity numbers do not change.

C. Experimental or research-stage approaches (not yet proven, not standard of care)  
   • Electrical stimulation therapy (transcorneal or transorbital microcurrent): early trials show modest improvements in some patients, but results are inconsistent and long-term benefit is unproven.  
   • Stem-cell–derived retinal ganglion or optic-nerve cell implants: in animal models there is partial regeneration; human clinical trials are just beginning and are tightly regulated.  
   • Gene-therapy approaches and neuro-protective biologics (e.g., CNTF, BDNF): still pre-clinical or phase-I.  
   • “Reactive optic-nerve” or “neuro-reactivation” procedures sometimes advertised in various countries have not been confirmed by peer-reviewed research to restore function after long-standing atrophy.

Because you have had no perception of vision for approximately 16 years, the chance of recovering sight with currently validated treatments is unfortunately extremely low. Any clinic promising a full cure should be approached with caution and a request for peer-reviewed data.

3. What our hospital can offer  
1) Comprehensive neuro-ophthalmology evaluation: review of records, detailed eye exam, visual-field testing, optical-coherence tomography (OCT) of the optic nerve, visual-evoked potentials (VEP), and high-resolution MRI if needed.  
2) Low-vision rehabilitation program.  
3) Screening for eligibility in ongoing clinical trials (electrical stimulation, neuro-protective medications, or future stem-cell/gene-therapy studies once they are approved). Trial enrollment is free, but only a small proportion of patients meet the inclusion criteria.  
4) Psychological and social-work support services.

4. Estimated costs (self-pay, before any insurance or charity adjustment)  
• Initial out-patient neuro-ophthalmology consultation: USD 250–400.  
• Diagnostic imaging/tests (OCT, visual fields, VEP, MRI if ordered): USD 600–1

Short answer  
Yes – over the last 15 years a fair amount of research has shown that certain treatments work best (or only) for specific “sub-types” of migraine, while other treatments seem to help across the board.  Unfortunately, we still do not have a simple test that tells a doctor “use drug X for patient Y,” so much of care is still empirical.  The table below summarizes what is known today.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
HOW MIGRAINE IS SUB-TYPED and WHAT HAS EVIDENCE
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Attack frequency  
   • Episodic (< 15 headache days / mo)  
     – First-line prevention: β-blockers, topiramate, valproate, CGRP mAbs, neuromodulation (Cefaly®, REN).  
   • Chronic (�� 15 days / mo, ≥ 8 migraine days)  
     – Only two treatments have class-I evidence: onabotulinumtoxin A and the four CGRP monoclonal antibodies.  
     – Oral preventives work, but effect size is smaller.

2.  With aura vs. without aura  
   • Single-pulse transcranial magnetic stimulation (sTMS) – FDA-cleared for acute treatment of migraine WITH aura; not helpful when no aura.  
   • Some preventive data suggest lamotrigine or acetazolamide is more effective when aura is prominent.  
   • Nothing else consistently separates by aura status.

3.  Menstrual / hormonally-related migraine  
   • Mini-prophylaxis: frovatriptan, naratriptan, or zolmitriptan twice daily starting 2 days before bleeding – level-A evidence.  
   • Perimenstrual estradiol, combined hormonal contraceptives, or continuous progestin for women who can use estrogen.  
   • Usual daily preventives often under-perform unless these measures are added.

4.  Hemiplegic or brain-stem migraine  
   • TRIPTANS, DITANS, ERGOTS are usually avoided because of theoretic stroke risk.  
   • Prevention relies on flunarizine, verapamil, acetazolamide, or lamotrigine.  
   • Evidence base small (open series and case reports).

5.  Vestibular migraine  
   • Best-documented preventives: verapamil, propranolol, topiramate, venlafaxine; vestibular rehabilitation for persistent dizziness.  
   • Acute: triptans appear helpful; data for gepants emerging.

6.  Cluster-like daily migraine (chronic paroxysmal hemicrania, SUNCT)  
   • Respond dramatically to indomethacin.  An indomethacin trial is mandatory for any strictly unilateral daily headache.

7.  Neuralgiform or occipital components  
   • Occipital or supra-orbital nerve blocks, pulsed radio-frequency, or implanted stimulators can be useful when scalp pain dominates.

8.  Refractory / medication-over-use migraine  
   • In-hospital “bridge”: dihydro-ergotamine infusion, ketamine, IV valproate, nerve blocks, or occipital nerve stimulation.  
   • After detoxification, CGRP mAbs reduce relapse rate.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
NEUROMODULATION DEVICES AND WHAT THEY’RE APPROVED FOR
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• sTMS (eNeura®): Acute and preventive migraine WITH aura.  
• External trigeminal nerve stimulation (Cefaly®): Preventive and acute episodic migraine.  
• Non-invasive vagus nerve stimulator (gammaCore®): Acute treatment of episodic migraine and cluster headache; preventive in chronic cluster.  
• Remote electrical neuromodulation (Nerivio®): Acute treatment of episodic or chronic migraine in people aged ≥12 y.  

Evidence quality varies (randomized trials for devices above, pilot studies for most QEEG/HEG protocols).  Quantitative EEG-guided neurofeedback (QEEG) and hemo-encephalography (HEG) still lack high-quality trials, which is why many insurers call them investigational.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
WHY THE MATCHING IS STILL IMPERFECT
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Migraine biology is complex – at least four major pathways (serotonin, CGRP, PACAP, nitric oxide) and dozens of genetic polymorphisms are involved.  
2.  Nothing in routine blood work or brain imaging yet predicts which pathway is dominant in an individual patient.  Research using functional MRI, proteomics, and pharmacogenomics is under way but not ready for clinic use.  
3.  Regulatory trials are usually done in “all comers with migraine,” so subgroup analysis is often under-powered.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
PRACTICAL STEPS WHEN STANDARD OPTIONS HAVE FAILED
--------------------------------------------------------------------

The reference answer will be provided in these tags:
<gold_response>
Migraine (Treatment): There is no specific cure for migraine headaches. The goal is to treat your migraine symptoms right away, and to prevent symptoms by avoiding or changing your triggers. A key step is learning how to manage your migraines at home. A headache diary can help you identify your headache triggers. Then you and your doctor can plan how to avoid these triggers. If you have frequent migraines, your doctor may prescribe medicine to reduce the number of attacks. You need to take the medicine every day for it to be effective. Medicines may include: - Antidepressants - Blood pressure medicines - Seizure medicines Botulinum toxin type A (Botox) injections may also help reduce migraine attacks if they occur more than 15 days a month. Some people find relief with minerals and vitamins. Check with your doctor to see if riboflavin or magnesium is right for you. TREATING AN ATTACK Other medicines are taken at the first sign of a migraine attack. Over-the-counter (OTC) pain medicines, such as acetaminophen, ibuprofen, or aspirin are often helpful when your migraine is mild. Be aware that: - Taking medicines more than 3 days a week may lead to rebound headaches. These are headaches that keep coming back due to overuse of pain medicine. - Taking too much acetaminophen can damage your liver. - Too much ibuprofen or aspirin can irritate your stomach or kidneys. If these treatments do not help, ask your doctor about prescription medicines. These include nasal sprays, suppositories, or injections. The group of medicines most often used is called triptans. Some migraine medicines narrow the blood vessels. If you are at risk for having a heart attack or have heart disease, talk with your doctor before using these medicines. Some migraine medicines should not be used by pregnant women. Talk with your doctor about which medicine is right for you if you are pregnant or planning to become pregnant. Other medicines treat symptoms of migraine, such as nausea and vomiting. They may be used alone or along with the other drugs that treat the migraine itself. Feverfew is an herb for migraines. It can be effective for some people. Before using feverfew, make sure your provider approves. Herbal remedies sold in drugstores and health food stores are not regulated. Work with a trained herbalist when selecting herbs.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
I’m sorry you are still feeling ill.  Typhoid fever can usually be cured, but sometimes people continue to feel unwell because of one (or a combination) of the following:

1. The original germ (Salmonella Typhi / Paratyphi) was never completely cleared – perhaps the antibiotic course was too short, not taken correctly, or the bacteria are resistant to that drug.  
2. You became re-infected from unsafe food or water after finishing treatment.  
3. You have become a “chronic carrier.”  In some people the bacteria hide in the gall-bladder and keep shedding into the intestine, producing relapses or vague, long-lasting symptoms.  
4. The illness was misdiagnosed; another infection or condition may be responsible for your ongoing symptoms (malaria, tuberculosis, viral hepatitis, brucellosis, inflammatory bowel disease, etc.).  
5. A complication of typhoid (for example, intestinal inflammation, anemia, or liver involvement) is making recovery slow.

WHAT TO DO NOW

1. See an experienced doctor (internal-medicine or infectious-disease specialist).  Explain that symptoms have persisted for a year despite treatment.  
2. Ask for proper confirmatory tests, not just a Widal test (which is unreliable).  Typical tests include:  
   • Blood culture (preferably before starting any new antibiotic)  
   • Stool and/or urine culture  
   • Typhi-dot IgM/IgG if cultures are not available  
   • Complete blood count, liver function tests  
   • Abdominal ultrasound to look at the gall-bladder (for carrier state)  
3. If Salmonella Typhi is confirmed, the laboratory should do an “antibiotic sensitivity” test to find out which medicines still work against the germ in your area.  
4. Recommended modern treatments (chosen according to sensitivity) are usually:  
   • Ceftriaxone IV 10–14 days, or  
   • Cefixime tablets 10–14 days, or  
   • Azithromycin tablets 7–10 days, or  
   • A fluoroquinolone (ciprofloxacin/ofloxacin) only if the strain is still sensitive (resistance is now common).  
   NEVER stop early; take the full course exactly as prescribed.  
5. For proven chronic carriers doctors may:  
   • Give a longer antibiotic course (e.g., a fluoroquinolone for 28 days, or amoxicillin/ampicillin 4–6 weeks if the strain is sensitive).  
   • Consider removal of the gall-bladder (cholecystectomy) if antibiotics alone do not clear carriage and the person keeps relapsing.  
6. If cultures are negative, the doctor will look for other diseases that mimic typhoid and treat accordingly.

SELF-CARE WHILE RECOVERING

• Drink plenty of safe fluids (boiled or bottled water, oral rehydration solution if you have diarrhea).  
• Eat light, well-cooked food; small frequent meals are easier to manage.  
• Rest, but start gentle activity as strength returns.  
• Paracetamol/acetaminophen can be used for fever or aches unless your doctor advises otherwise.  
• Do NOT take any additional antibiotics, steroids, or “over-the-counter” fever mixtures without medical advice—these can mask symptoms or worsen resistance.

PREVENTION (to avoid relapse or re-infection)

• Always drink water that is boiled, chlorinated, or sealed-bottle; avoid ice of uncertain origin.  
• Wash hands with soap and clean water before eating and after using the toilet.  
• Eat food that is freshly cooked and served hot; avoid raw salads or unpeeled fruits outside the home.  
• Get typhoid vaccination if you live in or travel to areas where the disease is common (injectable Vi-polysaccharide every 2–3 years or oral Ty21a capsules).  
• Ensure safe disposal of human waste in your home and community.

RED-FLAG SIGNS—GO TO A HOSPITAL IMMEDIATELY IF YOU DEVELOP

• Persistent high fever with confusion or delirium  
• Severe abdominal pain, bloating, or vomiting blood  
• Bloody or black stools  
• Shortness of breath or jaundice (yellow eyes/skin)  
• Marked weakness, fainting, or inability to drink fluids

BOTTOM LINE  
Typhoid that lingers for months is not “normal.”  You need a repeat, culture-based evaluation, targeted antibiotics according to sensitivity, and a check for carrier state or another underlying illness.  Only an in-person medical assessment can provide the exact treatment plan, so please arrange to see a qualified doctor as soon as possible.  In the meantime, follow the hygiene and dietary measures above to protect yourself and others.

predicted_text:
HOW TO FIND OUT WHETHER YOU’VE HAD CHICKENPOX (VARICELLA)

1. The blood test  
   • Name: Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) IgG antibody titer (usually an ELISA test).  
   • What it looks for: IgG antibodies that remain in your blood for life after natural chickenpox or after varicella vaccine.  
   • How it is done: A routine blood draw sent to any standard laboratory.

2. Interpreting the result  
   • “Positive,” “reactive,” or a numerical value above the laboratory’s cut-off → You are immune; that virtually always means you have had chickenpox (or were vaccinated).  
   • “Negative,” “non-reactive,” or below the cut-off → No evidence of immunity; you are assumed never to have had chickenpox (and you are at risk if exposed).  
   • “Equivocal” → Borderline; the test is repeated or you are treated as non-immune.

3. What the test does NOT tell you  
   • It cannot distinguish whether the antibodies came from natural disease or from the 2-dose varicella vaccine you might have received in childhood.  
   • An IgM test would look for a very recent or current infection; it is not useful for the question you are asking.

WHY THE TEST MATTERS

If you truly never had chickenpox (and have not been vaccinated), you are susceptible to the primary infection and need the varicella vaccine series (two doses 4–8 weeks apart) before you ever worry about shingles vaccine.

IF THE TEST IS POSITIVE (IMMUNE)

• You do not need the varicella vaccine.  
• You are eligible for shingles (zoster) vaccination when you reach the recommended age (see below).

IF THE TEST IS NEGATIVE (NOT IMMUNE)

• First get immunized with the two-dose varicella vaccine.  
• After you are protected against chickenpox, you would still be a candidate for shingles vaccine when you are older, because shingles results from reactivation of the virus that will then be latent in your nerves.

DO YOU EVEN NEED THE TEST?

• Public-health guidelines consider almost every adult born in the United States before 1980 to be immune to chickenpox, because >90 % of them had the disease as children (even if they do not remember it).  
• For that reason, the CDC does NOT recommend routine serologic testing before giving shingles vaccine, unless you have a specific reason to doubt past infection (e.g., born and raised in a tropical country where adult susceptibility is higher, never vaccinated, or certain you never had the illness).

WHICH SHINGLES VACCINE?

• Zostavax (live, single dose) was licensed for adults ≥60 y but is no longer sold in the U.S. as of 2020.  
• Shingrix (recombinant, non-live, two doses 2–6 months apart) is now the preferred vaccine for adults 50 y and older, regardless of whether they recall chickenpox or have had a prior zoster episode.  
• You cannot receive Shingrix until age 50; if you are younger your immediate concern would be varicella vaccination if you are not immune.

SUMMARY

Ask your clinician for a VZV IgG antibody test if you truly are unsure of past chickenpox and need documented proof.  
• Positive IgG → you’ve had it (or were vaccinated) → no need for varicella vaccine; plan on Shingrix at 50+.  
• Negative IgG → you’ve never had it → get the 2-dose varicella vaccine now; plan on Shingrix at 50+.  

Discuss the timing and vaccine choice with your healthcare provider, especially if you have immune-compromising conditions, allergies, or are pregnant.

predicted_text:
Vitelliform macular dystrophy (VMD), sometimes called Best disease or Best‐like dystrophy, is an inherited condition that affects the macula – the small, central area of the retina responsible for sharp, detailed vision.  In most people the disorder progresses slowly and central vision is preserved for many years, but some individuals eventually develop legally-blind central acuity.  

Key points about treatment
─────────────────────────
1.  There is, at present, no cure that stops or reverses the underlying genetic defect.  
2.  Most people with VMD do **not** lose all their vision; side (peripheral) vision remains intact.  
3.  Available treatments are aimed at
    • managing complications that can threaten central vision;  
    • maximizing the vision you have; and  
    • monitoring for future therapies (especially gene-based treatments).  

Current management options
──────────────────────────
1.  Regular ophthalmic follow-up  
    • Dilated retinal exams and imaging (OCT, fundus photography, autofluorescence) are used to track the “egg-yolk” lesion and detect complications early.  
    • Adults are usually seen every 6–12 months; children and people with rapid changes may need more frequent visits.  

2.  Treating choroidal neovascularization (CNV)  
    • A small percentage of patients develop abnormal leaky blood vessels under the macula.  
    • If CNV appears, ophthalmologists often use the same **anti-VEGF injections** (e.g., ranibizumab, aflibercept, bevacizumab) that are standard for age-related macular degeneration. In many cases these injections stabilize or even improve vision.  
    • Photodynamic therapy (verteporfin) is rarely used today but is an alternative when anti-VEGF is contraindicated.  

3.  Treating cystoid macular edema or subretinal fluid  
    • Topical or oral carbonic-anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., dorzolamide eye drops, acetazolamide pills) have been helpful in some reports.  
    • Corticosteroid eye drops or injections are occasionally considered when inflammation is present, but evidence is limited.  

4.  Low-vision rehabilitation  
    • High-powered reading glasses, hand-held or stand magnifiers, telescopic devices, electronic video magnifiers, large-print materials, and adaptive computer software can make a dramatic difference in day-to-day life.  
    • Referral to a low-vision specialist is often covered by insurance and can be arranged by your eye doctor.  

5.  Lifestyle and nutritional measures  
    • No specific diet or supplement has been proven to alter the course of VMD, but a heart-healthy diet rich in leafy greens, fish, and colorful fruits/vegetables supports overall retinal health.  
    • Smoking is associated with worse retinal disease in general; quitting is strongly advised.  

6.  Genetic counseling and testing  
    • VMD is usually caused by pathogenic variants in the BEST1 gene (classic Best disease) or sometimes by other genes (e.g., PRPH2, IMPG1/2).  
    • Knowing the exact gene change can clarify the prognosis, aid family planning, and determine eligibility for clinical trials.  
    • A certified genetic counselor can help interpret results and discuss inheritance risks (autosomal dominant in most families; each child has a 50 % chance of inheriting the variant if one parent is affected).  

What’s on the research horizon?
──────────────────────────────
1.  Gene replacement/gene editing:  Several labs and companies are developing AAV (adeno-associated virus) vectors to deliver a working BEST1 copy directly to the retinal pigment epithelium.  Small, early-phase human trials are expected in the next few years.  

2.  Stem-cell or RPE cell transplantation:  Pilot studies are exploring whether transplanted retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells can restore function in diseases that damage the RPE, including Best disease.  

3.  Pharmacologic “bestrophin modulators”:  Molecules designed to enhance or correct the chloride-channel function of the bestrophin-1 protein are in the discovery stage.  

4.  Improved imaging and natural-history studies:  Large observational studies are under way to understand how VMD progresses so that future clinical trials can be designed efficiently.  

Finding clinical trials
───────────────────────
• ClinicalTrials.gov (search terms “Best disease,” “vitelliform,” “BEST1”)  
• Foundation Fighting Blindness Trial Finder (www.fightingblindness.org)  
• Contacting major eye research centers (e.g., National Eye Institute, Bascom Palmer Eye Institute, Moorfields Eye Hospital, Casey Eye Institute)  

Questions to ask your eye-care team
──────────────────────────────────
1. Have we confirmed the diagnosis genetically

3.  Pharmacologic “bestrophin modulators”:  Molecules designed to enhance or correct the chloride-channel function of the bestrophin-1 protein are in the discovery stage.  

4.  Improved imaging and natural-history studies:  Large observational studies are under way to understand how VMD progresses so that future clinical trials can be designed efficiently.

Adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy (Treatment): There is no cure or known treatment to stop the progression of adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy. [2] Management usually includes a comprehensive eye examination once or twice a year to monitor progression of the disease and for complications such as choroidal neovascularization ( CNV ). [4]  CNV is sometimes associated with adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy because macular degeneration can damage the retinal layers. When this happens, the vascular layer of the eye between the sclera and the retina known as the choroid may produce new blood vessels (neovascularization) which grow up through the damaged layers and leak or bleed into the retina. This can cause vision loss on its own. If CNV does develop, anti-VEGF therapy such as Ranibizumab or Bevacizumab can control and even reverse the CNV. However anti-VEGF therapy does not stop or reverse the vision loss caused by adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy, only the extra vision loss that is due to also developing CNV. [2]  Although vision loss is usually slow, when vision is impaired significantly, people with adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy may be referred for low vision testing and rehabilitation. Low vision rehabilitation can help maintain and optimize reading ability and improve overall quality of life. [4] [5]

Below is a non-technical overview of Williams Syndrome (WS) followed by practical ideas for teaching and supporting children, teenagers, or adults who have the condition.  Use this only as general information—always check details with the person’s physicians, therapists, and teachers.

--------------------------------------------------
1. What is Williams Syndrome?
--------------------------------------------------
• Cause  
  – A tiny deletion of 26-28 genes on chromosome 7 (7q11.23) that happens at conception.  
  – It is usually spontaneous (not inherited) but can be passed to children if an affected adult has a baby.

• Prevalence  
  – About 1 in 7,500–10,000 births worldwide; boys and girls equally.

• Key Medical & Physical Features (individuals have their own mix)  
  – Heart and blood-vessel problems, most often supravalvular aortic stenosis (SVAS) or pulmonary stenosis.  
  – High blood calcium in infancy, sensitive stomach, feeding difficulties.  
  – Short stature, distinctive facial appearance (“elfin” features), hernias, joint laxity or tightness.  
  – Kidney or bladder differences, early-onset puberty in some, dental crowding, hoarse voice.  
  – Mild to moderate hearing loss, sensitive ears to loud/metallic sounds.  
  – Higher risk for anxiety disorders and ADHD-like symptoms.

• Cognitive/Behavioral Profile  
  Strengths:  
  – Remarkable verbal memory, rich vocabulary for age, good long-term memory, strong listening skills, strong desire for social interaction, musicality and rhythm.  

  Challenges:  
  – Mild to moderate intellectual disability (average IQ 50-70 but wide range).  
  – Significant visual-spatial and math difficulty, poor depth perception.  
  – Fine-motor and graphomotor weakness (writing, cutting, tying).  
  – Limited concept of personal space, possible anxiety, phobias, distractibility.

• Diagnosis  
  – Confirmed by a blood test (FISH, microarray, or MLPA) looking for the 7q11.23 deletion.  
  – Screening echocardiogram, renal ultrasound, calcium levels, eye and hearing exams at diagnosis.

• Medical Follow-Up  
  – Regular cardiology visits (yearly or more).  
  – Annual blood pressure, calcium, thyroid, diabetes checks.  
  – Hearing, vision, dental visits every 6–12 months.  
  – Early intervention: physical, occupational, speech therapies.

--------------------------------------------------
2. Everyday Teaching & Support Tips
--------------------------------------------------
A. General Approach
1. Build on strengths  
   • Use music, rhythm, storytelling, and conversation as entry points for any topic.  
   • Allow the student to teach or present to peers—this boosts confidence and practices language.

2. Anticipate and scaffold weaknesses  
   • Provide explicit visual & step-by-step directions for tasks that rely on spatial, math, or motor skills.  
   • Use concrete manipulatives (blocks, counters, number lines) before abstract symbols.

3. Structure & predictability  
   • Keep a consistent routine; preview any changes to reduce anxiety.  
   • Use a daily visual schedule and timer.

4. Short, focused work periods  
   • Break long assignments into chunks with movement or music breaks (3–10 min tasks).  
   • Seat the student near the teacher to catch inattention early.

5. Positive behavioral supports  
   • Phrase corrections positively (“Let’s try it this way”) and use immediate praise.  
   • Teach explicit social rules (turn-taking, personal space) with role-play.

B. Specific Strategies by Subject
• Reading/Language  
  – Exploit verbal strengths—guided reading, repeated reading, paired reading aloud.  
  – Use phonics plus sight-word approaches; reinforce comprehension with pictures, retelling, story maps.

• Math  
  – Hands-on materials (coins, number rods), visual models, songs for facts.  
  – Teach one concept at a time; frequent review.  
  – Allow calculator or math apps for higher grades.

• Writing/Fine Motor  
  – Provide pencil grips, slant boards, or keyboarding alternatives.  
  – Graphic organizers for written expression.  
  – Encourage speech-to-text software if writing output limits content.

• Science & Social Studies  
  – Field trips (with hearing protection if needed) and experiments.  
  – Use multi-sensory demonstrations, videos, and verbal explanations.  
  – Connect topics to personal stories—excellent way to remember facts.

C. Classroom & Environment
• Seating: good lighting, away from loud HVAC or bell speakers (noise sensitivity).  
• Ear defenders/headphones available for fire drills, cafeteria, music class.  
• Provide a calm-down corner or break card.  
• Pair with a friendly peer mentor for group work.

D. Transition to Adulthood
• Encourage vocational programs that use strong

<gold_response>
Williams syndrome: Williams syndrome is a rare disorder that can lead to problems with development. It is passed down in families (inherited). Williams syndrome is caused by not having a copy of several genes. Parents may not have any family history of the condition. However, people with Williams syndrome have a 50% chance of passing the disorder on to each of their children. It often occurs randomly. Williams syndrome occurs in about 1 in 8,000 births. One of the 25 missing genes is the gene that produces elastin, a protein that allows blood vessels and other tissues in the body to stretch. It is likely that missing a copy of this gene results in the narrowing of blood vessels, stretchy skin, and flexible joints seen in this condition. Symptoms of Williams syndrome are: - Delayed speech that may later turn into strong speaking ability and strong learning by hearing - Developmental delay - Easily distracted, attention deficit disorder (ADD) - Feeding problems including colic, reflux, and vomiting - Inward bend of the small finger - Learning disorders - Mild to moderate intellectual disability - Personality traits including being very friendly, trusting strangers, fearing loud sounds or physical contact, and being interested in music - Short, compared to the rest of the person's family - Sunken chest The face and mouth of someone with Williams syndrome may show: - A flattened nasal bridge with small upturned nose - Long ridges in the skin that run from the nose to the upper lip - Prominent lips with an open mouth - Skin that covers the inner corner of the eye - Partially missing teeth, defective tooth enamel, or small, widely spaced teeth Signs include: - Narrowing of some blood vessels - Farsightedness - High blood calcium level that may cause seizures and rigid muscles - High blood pressure - Slack joints that may change to stiffness as the person gets older - Unusual star-like pattern in iris of the eye Tests for Williams syndrome include: - Blood pressure check - Blood test for a missing piece of chromosome 7 (FISH test) - Echocardiography combined with Doppler ultrasound - Kidney ultrasound There is no cure for Williams syndrome. Avoid taking extra calcium and vitamin D. Treat high blood calcium, if it occurs. Blood vessel narrowing can be a major health problem. It is treated based on how severe it is. Physical therapy is helpful to people with joint stiffness. Developmental and speech therapy can also help. For example, having strong verbal skills can help make up for other weaknesses. Other treatments are based on the person's symptoms. It can help to have treatment coordinated by a geneticist who is experienced with Williams syndrome. A support group can be helpful for emotional support and for giving and receiving practical advice. The following organization provides additional information about Williams Syndrome: Williams Syndrome Association -- www.williams-syndrome.org About 75% of people with Williams syndrome have some intellectual disability. Most people will not live as long as normal due to the various medical issues and other possible complications. Most people require full-time caregivers and often live in supervised group homes. Complications may include: - Calcium deposits in the kidney and other kidney problems - Death (in rare cases from anesthesia) - Heart failure due to narrowed blood vessels - Pain in the abdomen Many of the symptoms and signs of Williams syndrome may not be obvious at birth. Call your health care provider if your child has features similar to those of Williams syndrome. Seek genetic counseling if you have a family history of Williams syndrome. There is no known way to prevent the genetic problem that causes Williams syndrome. Prenatal testing is available for couples with a family history of Williams syndrome who wish to conceive. Updated by: Chad Haldeman-Englert, MD, FACMG, Fullerton Genetics Center, Asheville, NC. Review provided by VeriMed Healthcare Network. Also reviewed by David Zieve, MD, MHA, Isla Ogilvie, PhD, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Lewy Body Dementia (LBD)  – sometimes called Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) – is the second-most common degenerative dementia after Alzheimer’s disease (AD), yet it is still under-recognized. Below is a plain-language overview, followed by reliable sources for deeper reading and support.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. What is Lewy Body Dementia?
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Definition  
  LBD is a progressive brain disease caused by the build-up of abnormal protein clumps called Lewy bodies (made of α-synuclein) in brain cells. These same proteins are involved in Parkinson’s disease; that is why LBD shows a mix of Alzheimer-like memory problems and Parkinson-like motor symptoms.

• Who gets it?  
  – About 1.4 million Americans (worldwide estimates 3–4 million).  
  – Usually appears after age 50–55 (average onset ~70), but can occur earlier.  
  – Slight male predominance.  
  – Most cases are sporadic; rare families carry gene mutations (e.g., SNCA, GBA).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2. Key Symptoms (often appear together but fluctuate day to day)
--------------------------------------------------------------------
1. Cognitive decline  
   – Problems with attention, planning, multitasking; memory may be less impaired early on than in Alzheimer’s.  
   – Marked fluctuations (“good” and “bad” days or hours).

2. Visual hallucinations (up to 80 %)  
   – Vivid, well-formed images of people or animals; often early in the disease.

3. Parkinson-like motor features  
   – Slowness (bradykinesia), stiffness, shuffling gait, stooped posture, loss of facial expression, tremor (less prominent than in Parkinson’s disease).

4. REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD)  
   – Acting out dreams (talking, punching, falling out of bed) years before other symptoms.

5. Autonomic dysfunction  
   – Dizziness or fainting (low blood pressure), constipation, urinary urgency, erectile dysfunction, temperature or sweating abnormalities.

6. Mood / behavioral changes  
   – Depression, apathy, anxiety, delusions, sensitivity to certain drugs (see section 4).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3. How LBD differs from Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s
--------------------------------------------------------------------
• Compared with Alzheimer’s  
  – Memory loss milder early but attention & visuospatial problems worse.  
  – More fluctuations and hallucinations.  
  – Motor symptoms appear early (within one year of dementia) whereas AD rarely shows parkinsonism until late, if at all.

• Compared with Parkinson’s disease dementia (PDD)  
  – Rule of 1-year: if dementia symptoms develop before or at the same time as parkinsonism, doctors call it DLB; if dementia appears more than a year after established Parkinson’s, they call it PDD. Pathologically they are very similar, and treatment principles overlap.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4. Diagnosis
--------------------------------------------------------------------
There is no single blood test. Doctors rely on:  
• Detailed history from patient and care-partner.  
• Neuro exam for fluctuations, hallucinations, parkinsonism.  
• Cognitive testing.  
• Brain imaging:  
  – MRI/CT mainly to rule out strokes or tumors.  
  – DaT-SPECT (dopamine transporter scan) or cardiac MIBG scan can support the diagnosis where available.  
• Sleep study if REM sleep behavior disorder suspected.  
• Lab work (thyroid, B-12, syphilis/HIV) to exclude other causes.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5. Treatment and Management
--------------------------------------------------------------------
LBD is currently incurable, but symptoms can often be improved; treatment must be individualized and reassessed frequently because of sensitivities to medications.

1) Cognitive & Psychiatric  
   • Cholinesterase inhibitors (rivastigmine, donepezil) – often improve cognition, hallucinations, and fluctuations better in LBD than in AD.  
   • Memantine – modest benefit in some.  
   • Antipsychotics – USE WITH CAUTION. Up to 50 % of people with LBD have severe, even fatal reactions (rigidity, worsened cognition). If absolutely necessary, specialists favor low doses of quetiapine or clozapine; avoid haloperidol, risperidone, olanzapine.  
   • SSRIs or SNRIs for depression/anxiety.

2) Motor  
   • Low-dose carbidopa/levodopa may help slowness and stiffness, but can worsen hallucinations; dose titration is delicate.  
   • Exercise, physical & occupational therapy, safe-mobility training.

3) Sleep  
   • Melatonin or very low-dose clonazepam for REM sleep behavior disorder.  
   • Good sleep hygiene.

4) Autonomic symptoms  
   • Hydration, compression stockings, midodrine or fludrocortisone for low

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5. Treatment and Management
--------------------------------------------------------------------
LBD is currently incurable, but symptoms can often be improved; treatment must be individualized and reassessed frequently because of sensitivities to medications.

1) Cognitive & Psychiatric

   • Memantine – modest benefit in some.  
   • Antipsychotics – USE WITH CAUTION. Up to 50 % of people with LBD have severe, even fatal reactions (rigidity, worsened cognition). If absolutely necessary, specialists favor low doses of quetiapine or clozapine; avoid haloperidol, risperidone, olanzapine.  
   • SSRIs or SNRIs for depression/anxiety.

2) Motor

   • Exercise, physical & occupational therapy, safe-mobility training.

3) Sleep  
   • Melatonin or very low-dose clonazepam for REM sleep behavior disorder.

4) Autonomic symptoms

Protein deposits, called Lewy bodies, develop in nerve cells in the brain regions involved in thinking, memory and movement (motor control). Lewy body dementia causes a progressive decline in mental abilities. People with Lewy body dementia may experience visual hallucinations, and changes in alertness and attention. Other effects include Parkinson's disease-like symptoms such as rigid muscles, slow movement and tremors. Lewy body dementia care at Mayo Clinic

predicted_text:
Cystic fibrosis (CF) is considered a rare disease.

• United States  
  – About 30,000–35,000 people are currently living with CF.  
  – Roughly 1,000 new babies are diagnosed each year.  
  – Overall frequency: about 1 in 3,200 live births.  
  – By ethnic group:  
    • People of Northern-European ancestry: ≈ 1 in 2,500–3,500 births.  
    • African Americans: ≈ 1 in 15,000–17,000 births.  
    • Asian Americans: ≈ 1 in 30,000–35,000 births.

• Worldwide  
  – An estimated 70,000–100,000 people have cystic fibrosis.

Carrier rate  
About 1 in 25–30 people of Northern-European descent (and about 1 in 50–60 people in the general U.S. population) carry a single faulty CF gene but do not have the disease themselves.

Bottom line  
CF is uncommon overall, but it is one of the most frequent life-shortening genetic disorders in people of European heritage.
