predicted_text:
Preventing atherosclerosis—the progressive hardening and narrowing of the arteries—mostly comes down to controlling the same risk factors that cause it. The good news: almost all of those factors respond well to everyday lifestyle choices plus, when needed, timely medical treatment.

1. Know (and control) the “ABCs”
   • A = A1c / blood sugar: Keep fasting blood glucose < 100 mg/dL (or the target set by your doctor if you have diabetes).  
   • B = Blood pressure: Aim for < 120/80 mm Hg; definitely treat consistently elevated pressures ≥ 130/80.  
   • C = Cholesterol: LDL (“bad”) cholesterol ideally < 100 mg/dL (< 70 if you already have heart disease or diabetes); HDL > 40 (men) or > 50 (women); triglycerides < 150.

2. Eat for artery health  
   • Base most meals on vegetables, fruits, beans, lentils, nuts, seeds, and whole grains.  
   • Choose healthy fats: extra-virgin olive, canola, avocado, nuts; fatty fish (salmon, sardines, trout) 2×/week for omega-3s.  
   • Limit saturated fat (red/processed meat, butter, full-fat dairy, coconut/palm oils) to < 6 % of total calories; avoid trans fats completely.  
   • Cut down added sugars and refined carbs (sodas, pastries, white bread).  
   • Watch salt: stay at or below 1,500–2,300 mg sodium/day to keep blood pressure down.  
   • If you drink alcohol, keep it moderate (≤ 1 drink/day for women, ≤ 2 for men)—or skip altogether.

3. Move more, sit less  
   • Minimum goal: 150 minutes/week of moderate activity (brisk walking, cycling, swimming) or 75 minutes of vigorous exercise.  
   • Add muscle-strengthening exercises on 2+ days a week.  
   • Break up long periods of sitting; even 5-minute movement breaks help.

4. Maintain (or reach) a healthy weight  
   • Even a 5–10 % weight loss lowers blood pressure, improves cholesterol, and reduces diabetes risk.

5. Quit tobacco in all forms  
   • Smoking is one of the strongest accelerators of plaque buildup. Quitting drops heart-attack risk by ~50 % within a year. Seek help if needed—counseling, nicotine replacement, or medications double success rates.

6. Manage stress and get good sleep  
   • Chronic stress, depression, and short sleep (< 6 hours) raise inflammatory chemicals linked to atherosclerosis. Techniques: mindfulness, yoga, breathing exercises, counseling, setting a regular sleep schedule.

7. Stay up-to-date with medical care  
   • Lipid panel, blood pressure, and glucose checks at least every 3–5 years starting at age 20, or more often if you have risk factors.  
   • Discuss statins, ezetimibe, or other cholesterol-lowering drugs if lifestyle isn’t enough.  
   • Ask whether low-dose aspirin is appropriate; it’s no longer recommended for everyone, only for specific higher-risk groups.  
   • Manage co-existing conditions (diabetes, kidney disease, autoimmune disorders).

8. Special considerations  
   • Women: Pregnancy complications (preeclampsia, gestational diabetes) signal higher lifetime risk—start prevention early.  
   • Family history: If a parent or sibling had early heart disease (< 55 ♂, < 65 ♀), talk to your clinician about earlier screening and possibly calcium scoring.  
   • Air quality: Avoid secondhand smoke and heavy air pollution when possible; both irritate blood vessels.

Bottom line  
Atherosclerosis usually develops silently for decades. The combination of a heart-healthy diet, regular physical activity, tobacco avoidance, weight control, stress management, and evidence-based medical care can delay, halt, or even partially reverse plaque buildup. Partner with your healthcare team to personalize targets and monitor progress, and remember that every positive change—no matter how small—moves your arteries in the right direction.

<gold_response>
Atherosclerosis (PREVENTION): Taking action to control your risk factors can help prevent or delay atherosclerosis and its related diseases. Your risk for atherosclerosis increases with the number of risk factors you have. One step you can take is to adopt a healthy lifestyle, which can include: Heart-Healthy Eating. Adopt heart-healthy eating habits, which include eating different fruits and vegetables (including beans and peas), whole grains, lean meats, poultry without skin, seafood, and fat-free or low-fat milk and dairy products. A heart-healthy diet is low in sodium, added sugar, solid fats, and refined grains. Following a heart-healthy diet is an important part of a healthy lifestyle. Physical Activity. Be as physically active as you can. Physical activity can improve your fitness level and your health. Ask your doctor what types and amounts of activity are safe for you. Read more about Physical Activity and Your Heart. Quit Smoking. If you smoke, quit. Smoking can damage and tighten blood vessels and raise your risk for atherosclerosis. Talk with your doctor about programs and products that can help you quit. Also, try to avoid secondhand smoke. Read more about Smoking and Your Heart. Weight Control. If you’re overweight or obese, work with your doctor to create a reasonable weight-loss plan. Controlling your weight helps you control risk factors for atherosclerosis. Other steps that can prevent or delay atherosclerosis include knowing your family history of atherosclerosis. If you or someone in your family has an atherosclerosis-related disease, be sure to tell your doctor. If lifestyle changes aren’t enough, your doctor may prescribe medicines to control your atherosclerosis risk factors. Take all of your medicines as your doctor advises.  
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
How to help prevent conjunctivitis (“pink eye”)

1. Practice excellent hand hygiene  
   • Wash hands often with soap and warm water for at least 20 seconds, especially after touching your face or blowing your nose.  
   • If soap and water aren’t available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer (≥60 % alcohol).

2. Keep your hands away from your eyes  
   • Rubbing or touching the eyes transfers germs and allergens directly to the conjunctiva.  
   • Teach children to use a clean tissue instead of their fingers if the eye itches.

3. Do not share personal items  
   • Towels, washcloths, pillowcases, cosmetics (mascara, eyeliner, eye shadow) and contact-lens solutions or cases can all carry infectious agents.  
   • Replace eye makeup every 3–4 months; discard any used while infected.

4. Disinfect and replace contact-lens supplies  
   • Clean lenses exactly as instructed by your eye-care provider.  
   • Replace storage cases every 1–3 months.  
   • Never “top off” old solution or sleep in lenses not approved for overnight wear.

5. Stay home while contagious  
   • Viral and bacterial conjunctivitis spread easily for roughly as long as the eyes are red, tearing, or producing discharge.  
   • Children usually may return to school 24 hours after starting antibiotic drops for confirmed bacterial conjunctivitis, or when symptoms are clearly improving for viral cases (follow school or doctor’s policy).

6. Control allergy-related conjunctivitis  
   • Keep windows closed during high-pollen days; use air conditioning and HEPA filters.  
   • Shower and change clothes after spending time outdoors.  
   • Use prescribed allergy eye drops or oral antihistamines as directed.

7. Protect eyes from irritants  
   • Wear swim goggles in chlorinated pools.  
   • Use safety glasses when exposed to dust, chemicals, or fumes.  
   • Rinse eyes with clean water or saline if an irritant gets in them.

8. Clean high-touch surfaces  
   • Wipe down doorknobs, faucets, remote controls, phones, keyboards, and toys with a household disinfectant, especially if someone in the home is infected.

9. Take precautions with newborns  
   • All babies in the United States receive antibiotic eye drops at birth to prevent severe neonatal conjunctivitis—keep prenatal appointments so this isn’t missed.

10. Keep the immune system healthy  
    • Adequate sleep, balanced nutrition, physical activity, and up-to-date vaccinations (e.g., measles) reduce overall infection risk.

When to seek medical advice  
• Moderate-to-severe pain, blurred vision, sensitivity to light, intense redness, or no improvement within 24–48 hours of starting treatment.  
• Any eye redness in a newborn.  
• Worsening symptoms if you wear contact lenses.

Following these simple preventive steps can sharply lower your chances of getting or spreading conjunctivitis.

   • Use prescribed allergy eye drops or oral antihistamines as directed.

7. Protect eyes from irritants  
   • Wear swim goggles in chlorinated pools.  
   • Use safety glasses when exposed to dust, chemicals, or fumes.  
   • Rinse eyes with clean water or saline if an irritant gets in them.

8. Clean high-touch surfaces  
   • Wipe down doorknobs, faucets, remote controls, phones, keyboards, and toys with a household disinfectant, especially if someone in the home is infected.

9. Take precautions with newborns  
   • All babies in the United States receive antibiotic eye drops at birth to prevent severe neonatal conjunctivitis—keep prenatal appointments so this isn’t missed.

10. Keep the immune system healthy  
    • Adequate sleep, balanced nutrition, physical activity, and up-to-date vaccinations (e.g., measles) reduce overall infection risk.

When to seek medical advice  
• Moderate-to-severe pain, blurred vision, sensitivity to light, intense redness, or no improvement within 24–48 hours of starting treatment.  
• Any eye redness in a newborn.  
• Worsening symptoms if you wear contact lenses.

Following these simple preventive steps can sharply lower your chances of getting or spreading conjunctivitis.

predicted_text:
How to Help Prevent Diabetes (Especially Type 2)

Important note – Type 1 diabetes is an autoimmune condition and, at present, cannot be prevented. Most prevention advice focuses on type 2 diabetes, which accounts for about 90 % of all cases. The good news: many people can delay or avoid type 2 diabetes with everyday lifestyle choices.

1. Know Your Risk
• Family history of diabetes  
• Age ≥ 45 years  
• Overweight or obesity (BMI ≥ 25, or ≥ 23 for many Asian populations)  
• Sedentary lifestyle  
• History of gestational diabetes or delivering a baby > 9 lb  
• Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)  
• High blood pressure, abnormal cholesterol, or cardiovascular disease  
• Certain ethnic backgrounds (e.g., African-American, Hispanic/Latino, Native American, Asian-American, Pacific Islander)

Ask your clinician for a fasting glucose or A1C test if you have risk factors or every 3 years after age 45.

2. Stay (or Reach) a Healthy Weight
Losing just 5–10 % of starting weight can cut diabetes risk by roughly half in people with pre-diabetes. A slow loss of 1–2 lb (0.5–1 kg) per week is considered safe and sustainable.

3. Eat for Blood-Sugar Control
• Emphasize vegetables, fruits, beans/legumes, nuts, seeds, and whole-grain products.  
• Choose carbohydrate sources high in fiber (≥ 3 g per serving). Fiber slows glucose absorption.  
• Replace sugary drinks (soda, sweet tea, juices) with water, sparkling water, or unsweetened beverages.  
• Prefer lean protein: fish, skinless poultry, tofu, lentils, eggs, low-fat dairy.  
• Use healthy fats: olive, canola, or other vegetable oils; avocado; nuts.  
• Limit: refined grains (white bread, white rice), pastries, candy, processed or red meats, fried foods, trans fats, and high-sodium packaged meals.  
• “Plate method”: fill ½ plate with non-starchy veggies, ¼ with lean protein, ¼ with high-fiber starch or whole grain, plus fruit or dairy on the side.

4. Move Your Body Regularly
• Aim for at least 150 minutes a week of moderate-intensity aerobic activity (brisk walking, cycling, swimming, dancing).  
• Add resistance/strength training 2–3 times a week to build muscle, which improves insulin sensitivity.  
• Break up long sitting periods—stand or walk a few minutes every half hour.  
• If new to exercise, start small (10 minutes a day) and build up.

5. Sleep Well
• Adults generally need 7–9 hours per night.  
• Poor sleep or sleep apnea can worsen insulin resistance; ask about testing if you snore loudly or feel very tired despite sleep.

6. Don’t Smoke & Limit Alcohol
• Smoking raises diabetes risk by 30–40 %. Get help quitting.  
• If you drink, keep it moderate: women ≤ 1 drink/day, men ≤ 2 drinks/day.

7. Manage Stress
Chronic stress hormones counteract insulin. Techniques: brisk walking, yoga, meditation, breathing exercises, counseling, adequate leisure time.

8. Keep Up with Regular Checkups
• Blood pressure, cholesterol, and A1C or fasting glucose checks.  
• Vaccinations, eye and foot exams, and dental care support overall health.  
• If you already have pre-diabetes, ask about formal Diabetes Prevention Programs (DPP) or medication such as metformin when lifestyle change alone is not enough.

9. Pregnancy Considerations
• Before pregnancy, aim for a healthy weight and active lifestyle.  
• During pregnancy follow prenatal screening for gestational diabetes (usually 24–28 weeks). Early action protects both mother and baby.

10. Kids & Teens
• Encourage at least 60 minutes of physical activity daily.  
• Limit screen time, offer balanced meals, and avoid sugary drinks.

When to Seek Professional Help
• You have risk factors and have never been tested.  
• You notice symptoms – excessive thirst, frequent urination, unexplained fatigue, blurred vision, or sudden weight change.  
• You have pre-diabetes and need structured support.

Bottom line
Most cases of type 2 diabetes can be delayed or prevented by maintaining a healthy weight, choosing nutrient-dense foods, staying physically active, getting adequate sleep, and working with your healthcare team for early screening and, if needed, medications or a structured diabetes-prevention program.

This information is for general education and does not replace individual medical advice. If you have specific concerns, please consult your healthcare provider.

predicted_text:
Ways to Lower Your Risk of Lung Cancer

1. Don’t start smoking  
   • Cigarette, cigar and pipe smoking remain the single biggest cause of lung cancer.  
   • If you’ve never smoked, don’t start. Nicotine-replacement products or counseling can help if you feel tempted.

2. Quit if you do smoke  
   • Quitting at any age lowers your risk almost immediately and the benefit grows every year you stay smoke-free.  
   • Help resources: 1-800-QUIT-NOW, smokefree.gov, smartphone quit-apps, counseling and FDA-approved medications.

3. Stay away from second-hand smoke  
   • Ask people not to smoke in your home, car or around children.  
   • Choose smoke-free restaurants, hotels and public spaces when possible.

4. Test your home for radon  
   • Radon is an odorless, radioactive gas that seeps from soil and is the #2 cause of lung cancer.  
   • Low-cost test kits are sold at hardware stores or via your state radon program.  
   • If levels are high, licensed contractors can install mitigation systems.

5. Protect yourself at work  
   • Follow safety rules if you work around asbestos, silica dust, diesel exhaust, arsenic, beryllium, chromium, nickel or other lung irritants.  
   • Use proper respirators, ventilation and protective clothing supplied by your employer.  
   • Report inadequate protection to supervisors or OSHA (in the U.S.).

6. Keep indoor and outdoor air as clean as possible  
   • Limit the use of wood-burning stoves, avoid burning trash, and ensure good ventilation when cooking or using strong chemicals.  
   • Pay attention to local air-quality alerts and exercise indoors on high-pollution days if you have breathing problems.

7. Maintain a generally healthy lifestyle  
   • Eat plenty of fruits and vegetables—natural antioxidants may help protect lung tissue.  
   • Stay physically active most days of the week; exercise improves lung function and immune health.  
   • Keep a healthy weight and limit alcohol to no more than 1 drink/day for women and 2 for men.  
   • There is no proof that high-dose vitamin or mineral supplements prevent lung cancer; some (e.g., high-dose beta-carotene in smokers) may actually increase risk.

8. Consider screening if you are at high risk  
   • A yearly low-dose CT scan is recommended for adults 50–80 years old who:  
     – Currently smoke or quit within the past 15 years, AND  
     – Have a 20 “pack-year” history or more (e.g., 1 pack/day for 20 years).  
   • Talk with your clinician about the benefits and potential harms (false positives, radiation).

9. Keep your vaccinations up to date  
   • Flu and pneumococcal vaccines won’t prevent cancer, but they lower your chance of serious lung infections, keeping lungs healthier overall.

10. Know that not every case is preventable  
   • Genetics and unavoidable environmental factors play a role. Reducing controllable risks, however, markedly lowers your odds and improves overall lung health.

When to seek help:  
• If you have difficulty quitting tobacco, persistent cough, coughing up blood, chest pain, unexplained weight loss or shortness of breath, see your health-care provider.

Reliable resources  
• American Lung Association (lung.org)  
• Centers for Disease Control and Prevention – Radon (cdc.gov/radon)  
• National Cancer Institute’s quit line: 1-877-44U-QUIT

Summary: The single most effective step is to avoid all tobacco smoke. Add radon testing, workplace and air-quality protections, a healthy lifestyle, and appropriate screening to further lower your risk of lung cancer.

Answer:

At present there is no guaranteed way to “prevent” schizophrenia because the illness results from a complicated mix of genes, brain-development factors, and life experiences that scientists do not yet fully understand.  What research does show, however, is that certain actions—especially when started early—may lower a person’s risk or lessen the severity of the disorder if it does emerge.

1. Before Birth and Early Childhood  
•  Obtain good prenatal care.  A healthy pregnancy that includes regular obstetric visits, vaccination as advised, avoidance of smoking, alcohol, and street drugs, and good control of medical problems (e.g., diabetes, high blood pressure) reduces several brain-development risks linked to schizophrenia.  
•  Prevent and treat infections.  Maternal infections such as influenza, rubella, toxoplasmosis and certain nutritional deficiencies have been associated with increased risk for the child. Vaccination, hand-washing, and prompt medical care make a difference.  
•  Ensure adequate folic acid and other nutrients during pregnancy; breast-feed when possible; and provide children with a balanced diet rich in fruits, vegetables, fish or other sources of omega-3 fatty acids, iron, vitamin D, and B-vitamins.  
•  Minimize early brain injury.  Safe delivery practices, reducing exposure to lead or other toxins, wearing bicycle helmets and seat belts, and preventing child head trauma all matter.  
•  Provide a nurturing, low-stress, and abuse-free environment.  Early life adversity and severe, chronic stress increase later vulnerability to psychotic disorders.

2. Childhood through Adolescence  
•  Protect sleep.  Chronic sleep loss, especially in teenagers, can increase stress-hormone levels and disturb brain circuits involved in thinking and emotion.  
•  Discourage alcohol or recreational drug use—especially cannabis (marijuana), synthetic cannabinoids (“K2,” “Spice”), LSD, and amphetamine-type stimulants.  Cannabis use before age 15, intensive daily/weekly use, or use of high-THC strains is one of the clearest preventable environmental risks for schizophrenia-spectrum disorders.  
•  Foster social connection and coping skills.  Bullying, isolation, and high family tension (“expressed emotion”) can worsen risk.  Supportive friendships, constructive extracurricular activities, and open communication at home are protective.  
•  Encourage regular physical activity.  Exercise supports healthy brain development and eases anxiety and depression.  

3. For People at Higher Genetic Risk (family history of schizophrenia or bipolar disorder)  
•  Learn early-warning signs: persistent social withdrawal, drop in school/work performance, unusual perceptual changes, new odd beliefs, or marked change in mood.  
•  Seek prompt evaluation from a mental-health professional familiar with “clinical high risk” or “prodromal” services.  Studies show that specialized cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), family psychoeducation, and—where appropriate—very low-dose antipsychotic or other medications can cut the chance of progression to full psychosis by 30–60 %.  
•  Omega-3 fatty acids (1–1.4 g/day of EPA/DHA) have shown promise in some trials for youth at ultra-high risk, though findings are mixed; ask a clinician before starting supplements.  
•  Treat depression, anxiety, ADHD, or substance-use problems early.  Co-existing disorders add stress to the developing brain and can be addressed with therapy and, when needed, medication.  

4. General Lifestyle Measures for Brain Health  
•  Maintain a balanced diet, healthy body weight, regular aerobic exercise, and adequate vitamin D levels.  
•  Manage stress with relaxation techniques (mindfulness, yoga, breathing), structured daily routines, and realistic goal-setting.  
•  Cultivate strong, supportive relationships and stay engaged in school, work, or community activities.  
•  Limit or avoid nicotine; although common in people with schizophrenia, tobacco does not prevent the illness and adds health problems.  

5. Early Treatment If Symptoms Appear  
Even when prevention is not possible, starting effective treatment quickly (within weeks rather than months) after the first psychotic episode greatly improves long-term outlook—less cognitive decline, better social recovery, and lower relapse rates.  Families who notice early changes should not “wait and see” but rather schedule a mental-health evaluation.

Key Takeaways  
•  Schizophrenia cannot yet be fully prevented, but risk can be reduced.  
•  Protecting the developing brain—from pregnancy through young adulthood—is the most important opportunity.  
•  Avoiding cannabis and other psychoactive substances, reducing chronic stress, treating mental-health problems early, and obtaining prompt professional help when warning signs arise all make a meaningful difference.  
•  People with a family history should be particularly proactive about prevention and early intervention.  

If you or someone you know is experiencing possible early signs of psychosis, call a mental-health professional, your family doctor, or a specialized early-psychosis program right away.

Important: A heart attack (also called a myocardial infarction) is a medical emergency. Always call your local emergency number (in the U.S., 9-1-1) at the first sign of symptoms. The information below is for general education and is not a substitute for professional medical care.

1. Recognize the warning signs
• Chest discomfort: pressure, squeezing, fullness, or pain that lasts more than a few minutes or goes away and comes back  
• Discomfort in one or both arms, the back, neck, jaw, or stomach  
• Shortness of breath  
• Cold sweat, nausea, light-headedness, or sudden fatigue  
Symptoms can be different in women, older adults, and people with diabetes (e.g., milder chest pain, primarily shortness of breath, or sudden tiredness).

2. What to do immediately
• Call 9-1-1 (or your local emergency number). Do NOT drive yourself to the hospital unless you have absolutely no other option.  
• Stop what you’re doing, sit or lie down, and try to stay calm.  
• If you have been prescribed nitroglycerin, take it as instructed.  
• Chew (don’t just swallow) one regular-strength aspirin (325 mg) or two low-dose aspirin (81 mg each) while waiting for EMS—unless you are allergic, have been told by a doctor not to take aspirin, or have active bleeding.  
• If the person collapses and is unresponsive, begin CPR (hard and fast chest compressions in the center of the chest at 100–120/min) and use an AED if available.

3. What happens in the ambulance or emergency department
• Continuous heart monitoring (ECG) and oxygen if needed.  
• Blood tests (troponin) to confirm heart muscle damage.  
• Pain control (usually nitroglycerin; sometimes morphine).  
• Quick decision about opening the blocked artery:

   – Primary PCI (angioplasty with or without stent): preferred, ideally within 90 minutes of first medical contact.  
   – Thrombolytic (“clot-busting”) medication: used if PCI can’t be done quickly (generally within 12 hours of symptom onset).

• Additional medicines: antiplatelets (aspirin plus clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel), anticoagulants (heparin), beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors/ARBs, statins.

4. Possible procedures
• Percutaneous coronary intervention (angioplasty/stent)  
• Coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) if multiple or complicated blockages

5. Hospital recovery
• Cardiac monitoring for rhythm problems  
• Imaging (echocardiogram) to assess heart function  
• Graduated activity and education about risk-factor control

6. After leaving the hospital
• Medicines you’ll likely continue: aspirin, a second antiplatelet (for at least 6–12 months if you received a stent), beta-blocker, ACE inhibitor or ARB, statin, and sometimes nitroglycerin as needed.  
• Cardiac rehabilitation: supervised exercise, dietary counseling, stress management, and education.  
• Lifestyle changes: stop smoking, control blood pressure and diabetes, maintain a heart-healthy diet (high in vegetables, fruits, whole grains; low in saturated fat, trans fat, and sodium), achieve/maintain a healthy weight, and get regular physical activity as advised.  
• Follow-up visits: usually within 1–2 weeks after discharge, then regularly to monitor heart function and medication effects.

7. When to seek urgent follow-up (after a heart attack)
• New or worsening chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, fainting, or swelling in the legs/feet.  
• Side effects from medications (e.g., severe dizziness, coughing up blood, unusual bruising).

Key takeaway: Time is muscle. Calling emergency services immediately and getting rapid treatment (PCI or clot-busting medication) saves heart muscle and lives. Ongoing medication, cardiac rehab, and lifestyle changes are essential to prevent another heart attack.

Heart attack (Treatment): IMMEDIATE TREATMENT - You will be hooked up to a heart monitor, so the health care team can see how regularly your heart is beating. - You will receive oxygen so that your heart doesn't have to work as hard. - An intravenous line (IV) will be placed into one of your veins. Medicines and fluids pass through this IV. - You may get nitroglycerin and morphine to help reduce chest pain. - You may receive aspirin, unless it would not be safe for you. In that case, you will be given another medicine that prevents blood clots. - Dangerous abnormal heartbeats (arrhythmias) may be treated with medicine or electric shocks. EMERGENCY PROCEDURES Angioplasty is a procedure to open narrowed or blocked blood vessels that supply blood to the heart. - Angioplasty is often the first choice of treatment. It should be done within 90 minutes after you get to the hospital, and usually no later than 12 hours after a heart attack. - A stent is a small, metal mesh tube that opens up (expands) inside a coronary artery. A stent is usually placed after or during angioplasty. It helps prevent the artery from closing up again. You may be given drugs to break up the clot. This is called thrombolytic therapy. It is best if these drugs are given soon after the onset of symptoms, usually no later than 12 hours after it and ideally within 30 minutes of arriving to the hospital. Some people may also have heart bypass surgery to open narrowed or blocked blood vessels that supply blood to the heart. This procedure is also called coronary artery bypass grafting and/or open heart surgery. TREATMENT AFTER A HEART ATTACK After several days, you will be discharged from the hospital. You will likely need to take medicines, some for the rest of your life. Always talk to your provider before stopping or changing how you take any medicines. Stopping certain medicines can be deadly. While under the care of your health care team, you will learn: - How to take medicines to treat your heart problem and prevent more heart attacks - How to eat a heart-healthy diet - How to be active and exercise safely - What to do when you have chest pain - How to stop smoking Strong emotions are common after a heart attack. - You may feel sad - You may feel anxious and worry about being careful about everything you do All of these feelings are normal. They go away for most people after 2 or 3 weeks. You may also feel tired when you leave the hospital to go home. Most people who have had a heart attack take part in a cardiac rehabilitation program.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
“Auto-immune blood disorder” is a general phrase for any condition in which a person’s immune system mistakenly makes antibodies that attack one or more components of the blood or the tissues that make blood. Depending on what is targeted, the problem can involve:

• Red blood cells – Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA)  
• Platelets – Immune (autoimmune) thrombocytopenic purpura, or ITP  
• White blood cells – Autoimmune neutropenia or lymphopenia  
• Clotting factors – Acquired hemophilia (antibodies against factor VIII, IX, etc.)  
• Cells in the bone marrow – Aplastic anemia with autoimmune features, pure red-cell aplasia

Because the body is destroying its own blood elements, people can develop anemia (fatigue, shortness of breath), easy bruising or bleeding, frequent infections, or, less commonly, clotting problems. Treatment usually aims at slowing or stopping the immune attack (corticosteroids, immunosuppressive drugs, monoclonal antibodies, IV immunoglobulin) and replacing or supporting the missing blood component (transfusions, growth factors, splenectomy in some platelet disorders).

In short, autoimmune blood disorders are illnesses in which the immune system attacks a person’s own blood cells or clotting proteins, leading to anemia, bleeding, infection risk, or clotting abnormalities.

The reference answer will be provided in these tags:
<gold_response>
Autoimmune disorders: An autoimmune disorder occurs when the body's immune system attacks and destroys healthy body tissue by mistake. There are more than 80 types of autoimmune disorders. The blood cells in the body's immune system help protect against harmful substances. Examples include bacteria, viruses, toxins, cancer cells, and blood and tissue from outside the body. These substances contain antigens. The immune system produces antibodies against these antigens that enable it to destroy these harmful substances. When you have an autoimmune disorder, your immune system does not distinguish between healthy tissue and antigens. As a result, the body sets off a reaction that destroys normal tissues. The exact cause of autoimmune disorders is unknown. One theory is that some microorganisms (such as bacteria or viruses) or drugs may trigger changes that confuse the immune system. This may happen more often in people who have genes that make them more prone to autoimmune disorders. An autoimmune disorder may result in: - The destruction of body tissue - Abnormal growth of an organ - Changes in organ function An autoimmune disorder may affect one or more organ or tissue types. Areas often affected by autoimmune disorders include: - Blood vessels - Connective tissues - Endocrine glands such as the thyroid or pancreas - Joints - Muscles - Red blood cells - Skin A person may have more than one autoimmune disorder at the same time. Common autoimmune disorders include: - Addison disease - Celiac disease - sprue (gluten-sensitive enteropathy) - Dermatomyositis - Graves disease - Hashimoto thyroiditis - Multiple sclerosis - Myasthenia gravis - Pernicious anemia - Reactive arthritis - Rheumatoid arthritis - Sjögren syndrome - Systemic lupus erythematosus - Type I diabetes Symptoms will vary based on the type and location of the faulty immune response. Common symptoms include: - Fatigue - Fever - General ill-feeling (malaise) - Joint pain - Rash The health care provider will do a physical exam. Signs depend on the type of disease. Types of treatments include: - Supplements to replace a substance that the body lacks, such as thyroid hormone, vitamin B12, or insulin, due to the autoimmune disease - Blood transfusions if blood is affected - Physical therapy to help with movement if the bones, joints, or muscles are affected Many people take medicines to reduce the immune system's abnormal response. These are often called immunosuppressive medicines. Examples include corticosteroids (such as prednisone) and nonsteroid drugs such as azathioprine, cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate, sirolimus, or tacrolimus. Targeted drugs called tumor necrosis factor (TFN) blockers can be used for some diseases. The outcome depends on the disease. Most autoimmune diseases are chronic, but many can be controlled with treatment. Symptoms of autoimmune disorders can come and go. When symptoms get worse, it is called a flare-up. Complications depend on the disease. Medicines used to suppress the immune system can cause severe side effects, such as higher risk of infections. predicted_text:
The exact cause of bipolar disorder is still not fully understood, but research shows that several factors work together to raise a person’s risk. They can be grouped into three broad categories:

1. Genetics (family history)  
• Bipolar disorder tends to run in families.  
• First-degree relatives (parent, brother, sister, child) of a person with bipolar disorder have a much higher chance of developing the illness than someone in the general population.  
• No single “bipolar gene” has been found; instead, many different genes each contribute a small amount to overall risk.

2. Biology of the brain and body  
• Neurotransmitter imbalances – altered levels or sensitivity to brain chemicals such as serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine.  
• Differences in brain structure or function – imaging studies show subtle variations in areas that regulate emotion (e.g., prefrontal cortex, amygdala, hippocampus).  
• Hormonal and circadian (sleep–wake) rhythm disruptions – changes in thyroid function, cortisol, or the body’s internal clock can trigger episodes.  
• Medical illnesses or medicines – thyroid disease, multiple sclerosis, corticosteroids, and some antidepressants can precipitate mood swings in susceptible people.

3. Environmental and life-event triggers  
These factors do not “create” bipolar disorder on their own, but they can bring on the first episode or worsen the course of the illness in someone who is biologically vulnerable:  
• Severe or chronic stress (loss of a loved one, job changes, financial or relationship crises)  
• Traumatic experiences (physical, emotional, or sexual abuse; war; disasters)  
• Sleep deprivation or irregular sleep schedules  
• Substance use (alcohol, stimulants, cannabis, certain prescription or over-the-counter drugs)  
• Major life changes (marriage, childbirth, moving)  
• Seasonal light changes (some people cycle with the seasons)

Key points to remember  
• Bipolar disorder is the result of an interplay between inherited vulnerability and environmental stressors—not a personal weakness, character flaw, or anything one can simply “snap out of.”  
• Because multiple factors are involved, causes and triggers vary from person to person.  
• Identifying personal risk factors (family history, sleep patterns, stress triggers, substance use, medical conditions) is important for prevention and treatment planning.

predicted_text:
Pancreatic enzymes are natural digestive chemicals made by the pancreas, the banana-shaped gland that sits just behind the stomach.  When you eat, the pancreas releases these enzymes into the first part of the small intestine (the duodenum).  There they break food down into tiny particles your body can absorb and use for energy, growth, and repair.

Main pancreatic enzymes  
• Amylase – splits complex carbohydrates (starches) into simple sugars.  
• Lipase – breaks dietary fats into fatty acids and glycerol.  
• Proteases (trypsin, chymotrypsin, elastase, etc.) – cut proteins into small peptides and amino acids.

Because they are so powerful, the enzymes leave the pancreas in an inactive “pro-enzyme” form and become fully activated only after they reach the intestine.  If the pancreas is damaged (for example, by chronic pancreatitis, cystic fibrosis, pancreatic cancer, or after certain surgeries), it may not make enough of these enzymes; doctors can then prescribe pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy—capsules that supply the same digestive enzymes.

In short, pancreatic enzymes are the body’s own digestive tools that turn the fats, proteins, and carbohydrates in food into nutrients your intestines can absorb.

(Information provided for general understanding; it is not a substitute for professional medical advice.)

Pancreatic cancer: Pancreatic cancer is cancer that starts in the pancreas. The pancreas is a large organ behind the stomach. It makes and releases enzymes into the intestines that help the body digest and absorb food, especially fats. The pancreas also makes and releases insulin and glucagon. These are hormones that help the body control blood sugar levels. There are different types of pancreatic cancers. The type depends on the cell the cancer develops in. Examples include: - Adenocarcinoma, the most common type of pancreatic cancer - Other more rare types include glucagonoma, insulinoma, islet cell tumor, VIPoma The exact cause of pancreatic cancer is unknown. It is more common in persons who: - Are obese - Have a diet high in fat and low in fruits and vegetables - Have diabetes - Have long-term exposure to certain chemicals - Have long-term inflammation of the pancreas (chronic pancreatitis) - Smoke Pancreatic cancer is slightly more common in women than in men. The risk increases with age. Family history of the disease also slightly increases the chance of developing this cancer. A tumor (cancer) in the pancreas may grow without any symptoms at first. This means the cancer is often advanced when it is first found. Symptoms of pancreatic cancer include: - Diarrhea - Dark urine and clay-colored stools - Fatigue and weakness - Sudden increase in blood sugar level (diabetes) - Jaundice (a yellow color in the skin, mucous membranes, or white part of the eyes) and itching of the skin - Loss of appetite and weight loss - Nausea and vomiting - Pain or discomfort in the upper part of the belly or abdomen The doctor will perform a physical exam and ask about your symptoms. During the exam, the doctor may feel a lump (mass) in your abdomen. Blood tests that may be ordered include: - Complete blood count (CBC) - Liver function tests - Serum bilirubin Imaging tests that may be ordered include: - CT scan of the abdomen - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) - Endoscopic ultrasound - MRI of the abdomen Diagnosis of pancreatic cancer (and what type) is made by a pancreatic biopsy. If tests confirm you have pancreatic cancer, more tests will be done to see how far the cancer has spread within and outside the pancreas. This is called staging. Staging helps guide treatment and gives you an idea of what to expect. Treatment for adenocarcinoma depends on the stage of the tumor. Surgery may be done if the tumor has not spread or has spread very little. Along with surgery, chemotherapy or radiation therapy or both may be used before or after surgery. A small number of people can be cured with this treatment approach. When the tumor has not spread out of the pancreas but cannot be surgically removed, chemotherapy and radiation therapy together may be recommended. When the tumor has spread (metastasized) to other organs such as the liver, chemotherapy alone is usually used. With advanced cancer, the goal of treatment is to manage pain and other symptoms. For example, if the tube that carries bile is blocked by the pancreatic tumor, a procedure to place a tiny metal tube (stent) may be done to open the blockage. This can help relieve loss of appetite, jaundice, and itching of the skin. You can ease the stress of illness by joining a cancer support group. Sharing with others who have common experiences and problems can help you not feel alone. Some people with pancreatic cancer that can be surgically removed are cured. But in most people, the tumor has spread and cannot be completely removed at the time of diagnosis. Chemotherapy and radiation are often given after surgery to increase the cure rate (this is called adjuvant therapy). For pancreatic cancer that cannot be removed completely with surgery or cancer that has spread beyond the pancreas, a cure is not possible. In this case, chemotherapy is given to improve and extend one's life. Call for an appointment with your health care provider if you have: - Abdominal pain that does not go away - Back pain - Loss of appetite - Unexplained fatigue or weight loss - Other symptoms of this disorder Preventive measures include: - If you smoke, now is the time to quit. - Keep a diet high in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. - Exercise regularly to stay at a healthy weight. Editorial team.

predicted_text:
Below is general health information only. It should not be used to diagnose or treat any illness. If you or someone you know may have bulimia (bulimia nervosa), consider talking with a licensed health-care professional as soon as possible.

Common warning signs and symptoms of bulimia

1. Eating-behavior clues  
   • Repeated episodes of eating unusually large amounts of food in a short time (binges)  
   • Feeling unable to control what or how much is eaten during a binge  
   • Compensatory behaviors designed to “undo” the calories, such as self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives, diuretics, diet pills, fasting, or exercising excessively  
   • Frequent trips to the bathroom during or right after meals

2. Physical signs  
   • Sore throat, hoarse voice, or chronic heartburn/reflux  
   • Swollen cheeks or jaw (enlarged salivary glands)  
   • Dental problems—cavities, eroded enamel, tooth sensitivity (stomach acid exposure)  
   • Cuts or calluses on the backs of the hands or knuckles (from using fingers to induce vomiting)  
   • Abdominal pain, bloating, or constipation  
   • Irregular or missed menstrual periods  
   • Dehydration, dizziness, or fainting spells  
   • Electrolyte imbalances that can cause muscle cramps, irregular heartbeat, or fatigue  
   • Fluctuating weight—sometimes within the normal range, sometimes slightly under- or overweight

3. Emotional and behavioral changes  
   • Intense fear of gaining weight, preoccupation with body size or shape  
   • Feeling shame, guilt, or depression related to eating habits  
   • Social withdrawal, eating in secret, or avoiding meals with others  
   • Irritability, mood swings, or anxiety

If you suspect bulimia, prompt evaluation matters; the condition can lead to serious medical complications. A physician, mental-health professional, or registered dietitian with eating-disorder expertise can provide personalized assessment and treatment options. In emergencies (e.g., chest pain, severe weakness, suicidal thoughts), call your local emergency number right away.

During these episodes, the person feels a lack of control over the eating. Binges lead to self-disgust, which causes purging to prevent weight gain. Purging may include: - Forcing oneself to vomit - Excessive exercise - Using laxatives, enemas, or diuretics (water pills) Purging often brings a sense of relief. People with bulimia are often at a normal weight, but they may see themselves as being overweight. Because the person's weight is often normal, other people may not notice this eating disorder. Symptoms that other people can see include: - Spending a lot of time exercising - Suddenly eating large amounts of food or buying large amounts of food that disappear right away - Regularly going to the bathroom right after meals - Throwing away packages of laxatives, diet pills, emetics (drugs that cause vomiting), or diuretics

predicted_text:
Treatments for Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) are aimed at reducing symptoms, helping boys reach typical milestones, and supporting men’s long-term health.  No single plan works for everyone, so care is usually provided by a team that can include an endocrinologist, urologist/fertility specialist, primary-care clinician, psychologist, speech/occupational therapist, and sometimes a breast or orthopedic surgeon.  Commonly used options are listed below.

1.  Testosterone (T) replacement  
   •  Goal: supply the hormone that the testes make in lower-than-normal amounts, starting when levels normally rise in puberty.  
   •  Benefits: deeper voice, facial/body hair, increased muscle mass, improved energy and mood, stronger bones, enlargement of penis/testes to more typical size, prevention of anemia, and possible improvement in school performance/behavior.  
   •  When started: usually around 11–14 years; adults who never received T can start at any age if no contraindication.  
   •  Forms: intramuscular injections every 1–12 weeks, skin gel/lotion applied daily, transdermal patch, or longer-acting implantation pellets.  
   •  Monitoring: blood counts, liver function, cholesterol, PSA (in older men), bone density.

2.  Speech, language, occupational and physical therapy  
   •  Boys with KS often have delays in speech, coordination, or fine-motor skills. Early intervention (ideally before age 3) improves classroom performance and self-confidence.  
   •  Physical therapy helps core strength and coordination, reducing the “clumsiness” some boys feel.

3.  Educational support  
   •  Many boys have subtle learning disabilities (reading comprehension, executive function). Individualized education plans (IEPs), tutoring, or extra time on tests can make a big difference.

4.  Psychological counseling & social-skills training  
   •  Addresses shyness, anxiety, attention-deficit issues, and self-esteem.  
   •  Support groups can help adolescents and adults feel less isolated.

5.  Fertility treatment / preservation  
   •  Most men with Klinefelter’s make little or no sperm, but about half have small numbers present in tiny pockets of the testes.  
   •  Testicular sperm extraction or micro-TESE combined with intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) can allow some couples to have biologic children. Success rates vary by center (roughly 30–50 % when sperm are found).  
   •  Experimental options in early adolescence (cryopreservation of testicular tissue or sperm if present) are being studied.  
   •  Counseling about donor sperm, adoption, or child-free living is also part of comprehensive care.

6.  Treatment of enlarged breast tissue (gynecomastia)  
   •  About two-thirds of adolescent boys/adult men have visible breast growth.  
   •  Mild cases may improve on testosterone therapy and weight control.  
   •  Persistent or cosmetically bothersome cases can be corrected with liposuction or subcutaneous mastectomy performed by a plastic surgeon.

7.  Bone-health measures  
   •  Low testosterone and low vitamin D may thin bones.  
   •  Weight-bearing exercise, calcium/vitamin D supplements, and—if bone density is low or fractures occur—bisphosphonate or other bone-strengthening medicines are used.

8.  Metabolic and general health management  
   •  Men with KS have a higher risk of type 2 diabetes, high cholesterol, and blood clots. Regular screening (blood pressure, fasting glucose, lipid panel) and a heart-healthy lifestyle are recommended.  
   •  Sleep apnea screening, vaccinations, and routine cancer screenings follow general population guidelines, with the addition of breast examination.

9.  Other hormone options in childhood  
   •  Short courses of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) or low-dose testosterone may be used in toddlers who have micropenis to promote growth before puberty.

Key points to remember  
•  Early diagnosis (ideally in childhood) allows early speech and motor therapies and timely start of testosterone.  
•  Treatments address symptoms; they do not “cure” the extra chromosome.  
•  Regular follow-up helps tailor the plan as needs change—from assistance in school to fertility counseling and management of adult health risks.

Always discuss options with a qualified healthcare professional who knows your or your child’s full medical history.

<gold_response>
Klinefelter syndrome (Treatment): If you or your son is diagnosed with Klinefelter syndrome, your health care team may include a doctor who specializes in diagnosing and treating disorders involving the body's glands and hormones (endocrinologist), a speech therapist, a pediatrician, a physical therapist, a genetic counselor, a reproductive medicine or infertility specialist, and a counselor or psychologist. Although there's no way to repair the sex chromosome changes due to Klinefelter syndrome, treatments can help minimize its effects. The earlier a diagnosis is made and treatment is started, the greater the benefits. But it's never too late to get help. Treatment for Klinefelter syndrome may include: - Testosterone replacement therapy. Starting at the time of the usual onset of puberty, testosterone replacement can be given to help stimulate changes that normally occur at puberty, such as developing a deeper voice, growing facial and body hair, and increasing muscle mass and penis size. Testosterone therapy can also improve bone density and reduce the risk of fractures. It will not result in testicle enlargement or improve infertility. - Breast tissue removal. In males who develop enlarged breasts, excess breast tissue can be removed by a plastic surgeon, leaving a more normal-looking chest. - Speech and physical therapy. These treatments can help boys with Klinefelter syndrome overcome problems with speech, language and muscle weakness. - Educational evaluation and support. Some boys with Klinefelter syndrome have trouble learning and socializing and can benefit from extra assistance. Talk to your child's teacher, school counselor or school nurse about what kind of support might help. - Fertility treatment. Most men with Klinefelter syndrome are unable to father children because few or no sperm are produced in the testicles. For some men with minimal sperm production, a procedure called intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) may help. During ICSI, sperm is removed from the testicle with a biopsy needle and injected directly into the egg. - Psychological counseling. Having Klinefelter syndrome can be a challenge, especially during puberty and young adulthood. For men with the condition, coping with infertility can be difficult. A family therapist, counselor or psychologist can help work through the emotional issues.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
When the gall-bladder is “non-functioning” (low or no ejection of bile, sometimes called biliary dyskinesia or chronic acalculous cholecystitis) people usually experience the same kinds of attacks they would have if they had gallstones. Typical complaints include:

• Steady pain or pressure in the right upper abdomen or in the “pit” of the stomach; pain may spread to the right shoulder blade, mid-back, or chest.  
• Pain or a feeling of fullness that starts 15-30 minutes after eating—especially after a fatty, fried, or greasy meal.  
• Nausea and/or vomiting during or after these attacks.  
• Bloating, belching, indigestion, or gassy discomfort.  
• Early satiety (feeling full quickly) or a persistent sour/metallic taste.  
• Intolerance of fatty foods—people often learn that fried foods, creamy sauces, cheese, ice-cream, nuts, or bacon “set them off.”  
• Intermittent cramping, burning, or dull ache in the upper abdomen.  
• Episodic diarrhea or loose, light-colored stools.  
• Less commonly: low-grade fever, chills, or mild jaundice (yellowing of skin/eyes) if inflammation or bile duct blockage also develops.

Because these symptoms overlap with other gastrointestinal problems (ulcer, reflux, irritable bowel, pancreatitis, heart conditions, etc.), diagnosis usually requires an ultrasound to rule out stones and a HIDA scan with CCK injection to measure the gall-bladder ejection fraction. Persistent biliary-type pain with a low ejection fraction (<30–35 %) is considered evidence of a poorly functioning gallbladder.

Seek medical care promptly if pain is severe, lasts more than a few hours, is accompanied by fever, jaundice, chest pressure, or if you cannot keep fluids down.

Gallbladder removal - open (Why the Procedure is Performed): You may need this surgery if you have pain or other symptoms from gallstones. You may also need surgery if your gallbladder is not working normally. Common symptoms may include: - Indigestion, including bloating, heartburn, and gas - Nausea and vomiting - Pain after eating, usually in the upper right or upper middle area of your belly (epigastric pain) The most common way to remove the gallbladder is by using a medical instrument called a laparoscope (laparoscopic cholecystectomy). Open gallbladder surgery is used when laparoscopic surgery cannot be done safely. In some cases, the surgeon needs to switch to an open surgery if laparoscopic surgery cannot be successfully continued. Other reasons for removing the gallbladder by open surgery: - Unexpected bleeding during the laparoscopic operation - Obesity - Pancreatitis (inflammation in the pancreas) - Pregnancy (third trimester) - Severe liver problems - Past surgeries in the same area of your belly
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Main things that can make a child gain too much weight

1. What and how much they eat  
   • Large portion sizes  
   • Frequent fast-food or restaurant meals  
   • High-calorie snacks, sugary drinks, juice and sports drinks  
   • Skipping breakfast (often leads to overeating later)

2. How active they are  
   • Not enough daily play, sports or other exercise  
   • Too much “screen time” (TV, tablets, phones, video games)  
   • Low-activity school days: short or no recess, limited physical-education classes

3. Family and home influences  
   • Parents or siblings with obesity (partly genetic, partly shared habits)  
   • Food kept in the house, mealtime routines, reward-with-food practices  
   • Lack of safe outdoor space or money for sports programs

4. Biology and genetics  
   • Some children inherit a tendency to store fat more easily  
   • Certain medical conditions or rare genetic syndromes (e.g., Prader-Willi)  
   • Medications that can increase appetite or slow metabolism (steroids, some seizure or mood medicines)

5. Emotional and social factors  
   • Stress, anxiety, depression, bullying—can trigger overeating or “comfort” eating  
   • Lack of sleep: tired children often crave high-calorie foods and are less active

6. Community and school environment  
   • Easy availability of inexpensive, high-calorie foods and beverages  
   • Few grocery stores with fresh produce in some neighborhoods  
   • Schools that sell sugary drinks/snacks or limit physical activity time

7. Prenatal and early-life influences  
   • Excess weight gain or diabetes during pregnancy  
   • Smoking during pregnancy  
   • Rapid weight gain during infancy  
   • Not being breast-fed (small but measurable effect)

Key point: Childhood obesity usually results from a combination of these factors, not just one. Modifying eating habits, increasing physical activity, supporting emotional well-being, and creating a healthy home and community environment all play a role in prevention and treatment.

(Information provided for general education; for personal advice please consult your child’s healthcare professional.)

predicted_text:
Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is not a single disease but a group of conditions that all produce abnormally high blood pressure in the arteries that carry blood from the heart to the lungs.  Doctors divide the causes into several broad categories, but for a consumer-level overview you can think of them in five major groups:

1. Problems that start in the lung arteries themselves  
   • Idiopathic (no known cause) or “primary” pulmonary arterial hypertension  
   • Hereditary forms caused by gene mutations (e.g., BMPR2)  
   • Drug and toxin exposure – appetite-suppressant pills (fenfluramine, dexfenfluramine), methamphetamines, cocaine, some chemotherapy drugs  
   • Associated diseases: connective-tissue disorders (scleroderma, lupus), HIV infection, liver disease with portal hypertension, congenital heart defects, sickle-cell disease, schistosomiasis, thyroid disorders, certain blood or metabolic disorders

2. Heart diseases on the left side of the heart  
   • Left-sided heart failure (weak heart muscle)  
   • Diseases of the mitral or aortic valves  
   • Congenital or acquired conditions that raise pressure in the left atrium/ventricle  
   When pressure backs up from the left heart, it raises pressure in the lung vessels.

3. Lung diseases and chronic shortage of oxygen  
   • COPD (emphysema, chronic bronchitis)  
   • Interstitial lung diseases (pulmonary fibrosis)  
   • Severe, untreated sleep apnea or obesity hypoventilation syndrome  
   • Cystic fibrosis  
   • Chronic high-altitude exposure or any long-standing low-oxygen state (e.g., advanced neuromuscular disease affecting breathing)  

4. Chronic blood clots or blockages in the lung arteries  
   • Chronic thrombo-embolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) – clots that never fully clear or scar the arteries  
   • Other rare blockages: tumors, parasites, or foreign material

5. Other rare or multifactorial causes  
   • Certain inflammatory or metabolic diseases (sarcoidosis, glycogen-storage disease)  
   • Tumors pressing on or growing into pulmonary vessels  
   • Congenital narrowing of the pulmonary arteries  
   • Unknown or mixed causes (“multifactorial”)

Key points for consumers  
• Pulmonary hypertension is often secondary to another condition, so finding and treating the underlying cause is critical.  
• Some forms are hereditary or drug-related, so family history and medication history matter.  
• Symptoms (shortness of breath, fatigue, chest pain, swelling) are non-specific, so diagnosis requires specialized testing (echocardiogram, right-heart catheterization).  
• Early evaluation is important because treatments and outcomes depend heavily on the specific cause.

predicted_text:
The overwhelming majority of teeth are lost for just two reasons:

1. Gum (periodontal) disease  
   • Bacterial infection destroys the bone and soft tissue that hold teeth in place.  
   • It is responsible for more adult tooth loss than any other condition.  
   • Risk rises with poor oral hygiene, smoking, uncontrolled diabetes, certain medications, and genetic susceptibility.

2. Untreated tooth decay (dental caries)  
   • Cavities that are not restored eventually damage so much tooth structure that the tooth breaks or must be extracted.  
   • Decay can also lead to abscesses that require removal.

Other—but far less common—causes include:  
• Trauma or accident (sports injury, fall, etc.)  
• Failed root-canal or other dental treatment  
• Severe tooth wear from grinding (bruxism) or erosion from acid reflux/acidic drinks  
• Congenital or systemic conditions that weaken teeth or bone (e.g., advanced osteoporosis, cancer treatment side-effects)

Preventive steps—twice-daily brushing with fluoride toothpaste, daily flossing, regular dental check-ups/cleanings, a balanced low-sugar diet, and avoiding tobacco—greatly reduce the risk of both decay and gum disease, the two main culprits behind tooth loss.

predicted_text:
The chance of developing type 2 diabetes goes up when certain characteristics or habits are present. Doctors group them into two broad categories—things you can’t change (non-modifiable) and things you usually can (modifiable).

NON-MODIFIABLE RISK FACTORS  
• Age – risk starts to rise around 40–45 years and climbs each decade thereafter.  
• Family history – having a parent, brother or sister with type 2 diabetes roughly doubles your risk.  
• Ethnic background – people of African, Hispanic/Latino, Native American, Alaska Native, Pacific Islander, South Asian, or East Asian descent develop the disease more often and at younger ages.  
• Personal medical history  
  – Gestational diabetes or giving birth to a baby weighing > 9 lb (4 kg).  
  – Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).  
  – Certain endocrine disorders (e.g., Cushing’s syndrome).  
• Past history of pre-diabetes (impaired fasting glucose or impaired glucose tolerance).

MODIFIABLE OR PARTLY MODIFIABLE RISK FACTORS  
• Excess body weight – especially abdominal (“belly”) obesity; a body-mass index ≥ 25 kg/m² (≥ 23 kg/m² in Asian populations) or a waist circumference > 40 inches (102 cm) in men or > 35 inches (88 cm) in women greatly raises risk.  
• Physical inactivity – exercising less than 150 minutes a week of moderate activity.  
• Unhealthy eating patterns – high intakes of sugary drinks, refined carbs, red/processed meats, or saturated fats; low fiber, fruit and vegetable intake.  
• High blood pressure (≥ 130/80 mm Hg) or being treated for hypertension.  
• Abnormal blood lipids – low HDL (“good”) cholesterol (< 40 mg/dL in men, < 50 mg/dL in women) and/or high triglycerides (≥ 250 mg/dL).  
• Smoking – both cigarettes and some forms of vaping are linked to insulin resistance.  
• Sleep problems – chronic sleep deprivation, shift work, and obstructive sleep apnea.  
• Certain medicines – long-term use of glucocorticoids (steroids), some antipsychotics, and others can increase blood-sugar levels.  
• Depression and chronic stress – may lead to hormonal changes and lifestyle patterns that raise risk.  
• Heavy alcohol use – can contribute to pancreatitis, obesity, and poor glucose control.

HOW TO USE THIS INFORMATION  
While you can’t change your genes or your age, addressing modifiable factors—losing even 5–7 % of body weight, moving more, choosing healthier foods, quitting smoking, and treating blood-pressure or lipid problems—can cut the chance of progressing from pre-diabetes to diabetes by 40-70 percent in major studies. If you believe you are at risk, ask your health-care provider about screening and preventive programs (such as the CDC-recognized Diabetes Prevention Program).

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disease that affects many organs, but its symptoms are seen most often in the lungs and digestive system.  Not every person with CF has every sign listed below, and the timing and severity can vary from infancy through adulthood.

COMMON RESPIRATORY (LUNG & SINUS) SYMPTOMS  
•  Persistent cough that produces thick mucus (phlegm)  
•  Recurrent lung or sinus infections (pneumonia, bronchitis, sinusitis)  
•  Wheezing or shortness of breath  
•  Frequent stuffy nose or nasal polyps  
•  Chest congestion or a “hacking” cough that won’t go away  
•  Clubbing (widening and rounding) of the fingertips over time

DIGESTIVE & NUTRITIONAL SYMPTOMS  
•  Poor weight gain or difficulty growing despite a good appetite  
•  Frequent, bulky, greasy or foul-smelling stools  
•  Abdominal bloating, gas, or pain  
•  Intestinal blockages (in newborns this may appear as meconium ileus—failure to pass the first stool)  
•  Chronic constipation or rectal prolapse  
•  Deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) leading to anemia, easy bruising, night blindness, or bone problems  
•  Pancreatitis (episodes of severe abdominal pain from inflammation of the pancreas)  
•  CF-related diabetes in older children or adults

OTHER HALLMARK OR BODY-WIDE SIGNS  
•  “Salty” taste to the skin or salty sweat (parents often notice this when kissing their child)  
•  Dehydration or heat intolerance, especially in hot weather or during exercise  
•  Male infertility (due to absence or blockage of the vas deferens) and reduced fertility in some women  
•  Delayed puberty or irregular menstrual cycles  
•  Osteoporosis or bone fractures in teens and adults

EARLY SIGNS IN BABIES  
•  Salty skin  
•  Meconium ileus (bowel obstruction)  
•  Poor weight gain or growth (“failure to thrive”)  
•  Recurrent respiratory infections or chronic cough

WHEN TO SEEK MEDICAL CARE  
•  Any child or adult with persistent cough, frequent lung infections, poor growth, or unusually salty sweat should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.  
•  A sweat chloride test or genetic testing is used to confirm the diagnosis.

what are the symptoms for cystic fibrosis

The response will be provided in these tags:
<response>
Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disease that affects many organs, but its symptoms are seen most often in the lungs and digestive system.  Not every person with CF has every sign listed below, and the timing and severity can vary from infancy through adulthood.

COMMON RESPIRATORY (LUNG & SINUS) SYMPTOMS  
•  Persistent cough that produces thick mucus (phlegm)  
•  Recurrent lung or sinus infections (pneumonia, bronchitis, sinusitis)  
•  Wheezing or shortness of breath  
•  Frequent stuffy nose or nasal polyps  
•  Chest congestion or a “hacking” cough that won’t go away  
•  Clubbing (widening and rounding) of the fingertips over time

DIGESTIVE & NUTRITIONAL SYMPTOMS  
•  Poor weight gain or difficulty growing despite a good appetite  
•  Frequent, bulky, greasy or foul-smelling stools  
•  Abdominal bloating, gas, or pain  
•  Intestinal blockages (in newborns this may appear as meconium ileus—failure to pass the first stool)  
•  Chronic constipation or rectal prolapse  
•  Deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) leading to anemia, easy bruising, night blindness, or bone problems  
•  Pancreatitis (episodes of severe abdominal pain from inflammation of the pancreas)  
•  CF-related diabetes in older children or adults

OTHER HALLMARK OR BODY-WIDE SIGNS  
•  “Salty” taste to the skin or salty sweat (parents often notice this when kissing their child)  
•  Dehydration or heat intolerance, especially in hot weather or during exercise  
•  Male infertility (due to absence or blockage of the vas deferens) and reduced fertility in some women  
•  Delayed puberty or irregular menstrual cycles  
•  Osteoporosis or bone fractures in teens and adults

EARLY SIGNS IN BABIES  
•  Salty skin  
•  Meconium ileus (bowel obstruction)  
•  Poor weight gain or growth (“failure to thrive”)  
•  Recurrent respiratory infections or chronic cough

WHEN TO SEEK MEDICAL CARE  
•  Any child or adult with persistent cough, frequent lung infections, poor growth, or unusually salty sweat should be evaluated by a healthcare professional.  
•  A sweat chloride test or genetic testing is used to confirm the diagnosis.

Because cystic fibrosis symptoms resemble those of other conditions, an early, accurate diagnosis by a healthcare provider familiar with CF is important.  Treatment is individualized and has improved greatly in recent years.

This information is for educational purposes and is not a substitute for professional medical advice. If you suspect CF or have questions about the symptoms you’re experiencing, consult a qualified healthcare provider.
</response>

Most men with early-stage prostate cancer feel completely normal; the tumor is usually “silent” until it is large enough to press on the urethra or spread outside the gland.  When symptoms do appear, they may include:

Urinary changes  
• Needing to urinate more often, especially at night  
• Weak, slow or interrupted urine stream  
• Trouble starting or stopping the flow of urine  
• Feeling that the bladder doesn’t empty completely  
• Pain or burning during urination  
• Loss of bladder control (rare)

Blood in urine or semen (hematuria / hematospermia)

Ejaculation problems  
• Painful ejaculation  
• Decreased volume of semen

Sexual difficulties  
• Erectile dysfunction (new or worsening)  
• Reduced sexual desire

Pain or pressure  
• Dull, aching pain in the lower back, hips, pelvis, thighs, or rectum  
• Discomfort or pain when sitting (if the prostate is enlarged)  
• Bone pain (hips, spine, ribs)—may indicate cancer has spread

General or systemic signs (usually with advanced disease)  
• Unexplained weight loss  
• Fatigue  
• Swelling in the legs or feet  

Important points  
• Benign prostate enlargement (BPH), infections, kidney stones, and other conditions can cause the same symptoms; only a clinician can determine the cause.  
• Because early prostate cancer is often symptom-free, regular check-ups and, when appropriate, PSA blood tests and digital rectal exams are important for men who are at average or higher risk (age 50+ for most men; earlier for men of African ancestry or those with a strong family history).  
• If you notice any of the changes listed above, see your health-care provider promptly for evaluation.

<gold_response>
What are the symptoms of Prostate Cancer?: Symptoms Most cancers in their early, most treatable stages don't cause any symptoms. Early prostate cancer usually does not cause symptoms. However, if prostate cancer develops and is not treated, it can cause these symptoms: - a need to urinate frequently, especially at night - difficulty starting urination or holding back urine - inability to urinate - weak or interrupted flow of urine - painful or burning urination - difficulty in having an erection - painful ejaculation - blood in urine or semen - pain or stiffness in the lower back, hips, or upper thighs. a need to urinate frequently, especially at night difficulty starting urination or holding back urine inability to urinate weak or interrupted flow of urine painful or burning urination difficulty in having an erection painful ejaculation blood in urine or semen pain or stiffness in the lower back, hips, or upper thighs. Any of these symptoms may be caused by cancer, but more often they are due to enlargement of the prostate, which is not cancer. If You Have Symptoms If you have any of these symptoms, see your doctor or a urologist to find out if you need treatment. A urologist is a doctor who specializes in treating diseases of the genitourinary system. The doctor will ask questions about your medical history and perform an exam to try to find the cause of the prostate problems. The PSA Test The doctor may also suggest a blood test to check your prostate specific antigen, or PSA, level. PSA levels can be high not only in men who have prostate cancer, but also in men with an enlarged prostate gland and men with infections of the prostate. PSA tests may be very useful for early cancer diagnosis. However, PSA tests alone do not always tell whether or not cancer is present. PSA screening for prostate cancer is not perfect. (Screening tests check for disease in a person who shows no symptoms.) Most men with mildly elevated PSA do not have prostate cancer, and many men with prostate cancer have normal levels of PSA. A recent study revealed that men with low prostate specific antigen levels, or PSA, may still have prostate cancer. Also, the digital rectal exam can miss many prostate cancers. Other Tests The doctor may order other exams, including ultrasound, MRI, or CT scans, to learn more about the cause of the symptoms. But to confirm the presence of cancer, doctors must perform a biopsy. During a biopsy, the doctor uses needles to remove small tissue samples from the prostate and then looks at the samples under a microscope. If Cancer is Present If a biopsy shows that cancer is present, the doctor will report on the grade of the tumor. Doctors describe a tumor as low, medium, or high-grade cancer, based on the way it appears under the microscope. One way of grading prostate cancer, called the Gleason system, uses scores of 2 to 10. Another system uses G1 through G4. The higher the score, the higher the grade of the tumor. High-grade tumors grow more quickly and are more likely to spread than low-grade tumors.
</gold_response>

predicted_text:
Headaches have many possible causes.  Doctors group them into two broad categories—“primary” headaches, which are headaches themselves (the brain tissue is healthy but the pain pathways are over-active), and “secondary” headaches, in which pain is a symptom of another medical condition.  Below are the most common culprits and triggers.

1. Primary (stand-alone) headaches  
   • Tension-type headache – often a dull, tight, “band-like” pain around the head or at the back of the neck; stress, fatigue, poor posture, eye strain, or jaw clenching are common triggers.  
   • Migraine – throbbing or pulsating pain (often one-sided), sometimes with nausea, light or sound sensitivity, visual “aura,” hormonal shifts, certain foods (e.g., aged cheese, red wine), lack of sleep, skipped meals, or weather changes can bring on attacks.  
   • Cluster headache – intense, stabbing pain around one eye, occurring in clusters (daily for weeks, then remitting); often accompanied by eye redness, tearing, or nasal congestion; more common in men and in smokers.  
   • Other primary types – e.g., exertional or cough headaches, “ice-pick” (stabbing) headaches, and medication-overuse headaches (see below).

2. Secondary (symptom-related) headaches  
   • Sinus or allergy congestion – dull, pressure-like pain in the face/forehead cheeks, worsens when bending forward.  
   • Viral infections such as flu, COVID-19, or the common cold.  
   • Fever-related illnesses, meningitis, encephalitis (seek urgent care if fever is high, neck is stiff, or confusion is present).  
   • Dehydration, hunger, or low blood sugar.  
   • High blood pressure (especially very high “hypertensive emergency”).  
   • Concussion or other head/neck injury.  
   • Dental or jaw (TMJ) problems.  
   • Eye problems—uncorrected vision, glaucoma, prolonged screen use.  
   • Hormonal changes—menstruation, pregnancy, menopause, birth-control pills, hormone therapy.  
   • Medication side effects or medication-overuse (“rebound”)—many pain relievers, caffeine, opioids, triptans, and decongestants can cause daily headaches if used too often.  
   • Caffeine withdrawal or excess alcohol (“hangover”).  
   • Carbon monoxide exposure (headache in multiple people in the same space—emergency).  
   • Spinal fluid leak after lumbar puncture or epidural.  
   • Blood vessel disorders—stroke, aneurysm, temporal arteritis (new headache after age 50 with scalp tenderness or jaw pain warrants urgent evaluation).  
   • Brain tumor or other mass (rare, but considered if headaches are new, progressive, or accompanied by seizures or neurological changes).  

Common lifestyle triggers across many headache types  
   • Emotional stress, anxiety, or depression  
   • Lack of, or excess, sleep; jet lag  
   • Skipped meals or dehydration  
   • Poor posture, neck muscle tension  
   • Bright lights, loud noise, strong smells  
   • Certain foods/drinks (aged cheeses, processed meats, artificial sweeteners, MSG, chocolate, red wine)  
   • Weather or altitude changes  
   • Alcohol, smoking, or recreational drug use  

When to seek medical help right away  
   • “Worst headache of your life,” sudden (“thunderclap”) onset  
   • Headache with fever, neck stiffness, rash, confusion, seizure, vision loss, weakness, or trouble speaking  
   • New or worsening headaches after a head injury  
   • New headaches after age 50, or headaches that steadily get worse  
   • Headaches that interfere with daily life despite over-the-counter treatment  
   • Headache triggered by coughing, sneezing, or exertion in someone who never has headaches  

Bottom line  
Most headaches are benign and related to tension, migraine, or lifestyle factors, but some signal a more serious problem.  Keeping a headache diary (time, location, triggers, foods, sleep, stress) and reviewing it with your healthcare provider can help pinpoint causes and guide treatment.  If in doubt—or if red-flag symptoms are present—seek medical evaluation promptly.

Headache (Causes): The most common type of headache is tension headache. It is likely caused by tight muscles in your shoulders, neck, scalp, and jaw. A tension headache: - May be related to stress, depression, anxiety, a head injury, or holding your head and neck in an abnormal position. - Tends to be on both sides of your head. It often starts at the back of the head and spreads forward. The pain may feel dull or squeezing, like a tight band or vice. Your shoulders, neck, or jaw may feel tight or sore. A migraine headache involves severe pain. It usually occurs with other symptoms, such as vision changes, sensitivity to sound or light, or nausea. With a migraine: - The pain may be throbbing, pounding, or pulsating. It tends to begin on one side of your head. It may spread to both sides. - The headache may be associated with an aura. This is a group of warning symptoms that start before your headache. The pain usually gets worse as you try to move around. - Migraines may be triggered by foods, such as chocolate, certain cheeses, or monosodium glutamate (MSG). Caffeine withdrawal, lack of sleep, and alcohol may also be triggers. Rebound headaches are headaches that keep coming back. They often occur from overuse of pain medicines. For this reason, these headaches are also called medicine overuse headaches. People who take pain medicine more than 3 days a week on a regular basis can develop this type of headache. Other types of headaches: - Cluster headache is a sharp, very painful headache that occurs daily, sometimes up to several times a day for months. It then goes away for weeks to months. In some people, the headaches never come back. The headache usually lasts less than an hour. It tends to occur at the same times every day. - Sinus headache causes pain in the front of the head and face. It is due to swelling in the sinus passages behind the cheeks, nose, and eyes. The pain is worse when you bend forward and when you first wake up in the morning. - Headaches may occur if you have a cold, the flu, a fever, or premenstrual syndrome. - Headache due to a disorder called temporal arteritis. This is a swollen, inflamed artery that supplies blood to part of the head, temple, and neck area. In rare cases, a headache can be a sign of something more serious, such as: - Bleeding in the area between the brain and the thin tissue that covers the brain (subarachnoid hemorrhage) - Blood pressure that is very high - Brain infection, such as meningitis or encephalitis, or abscess - Brain tumor - Buildup of fluid inside the skull that leads to brain swelling (hydrocephalus) - Buildup of pressure inside the skull that appears to be, but is not a tumor (pseudotumor cerebri) - Carbon monoxide poisoning - Lack of oxygen during sleep (sleep apnea) - Problems with the blood vessels and bleeding in the brain, such as arteriovenous malformation (AVM), brain aneurysm, or stroke
</gold_response>
